Complete overall enjoyment. The story is otherwise from what the title suggests.
The new approach on the issues of the adolescents in the genre was a real catcher. Just amazing, never lets you get bored. Also the character setting is amazing. 
The unique approach to bullying, self contradiction, love conflicts is perfect.
At first I thought that this must be some cliched harem anime with all the girls at school and imoutou- onii chan stuff, but it's totally different.
Story- 9
the story is amazing. it catches your attention right from the first episode and then continues on to deal with the different kinds of problems faced by theadolescents.\n\n
Art- 9\n
art is also great. the animation is deep and smooth.\n\n
Sound- 9\n
the opening - "kimi no sei" is so catchy and amazing. also the slow paced ending was a very good pairing tio the opening.\n\n
Character-10\n
outstanding character developement. the complexity of Sakuta, maturity of Mai san both pair up perfectly. The support characters like Kaede, Nodoka, Futaba, Kunimi are also completely fitting. \n
Plus the mysterious Shouko san is also a big reason I'll be waiting for the second season (if there will be any).\n\n
Totally worth binge watching.

I'm gonna save you the pain and say just stop reading these reviews. Most are triggered Monogatari fans who think this show steals everything. While I haven't seen any of the Monogatari series, I don't see this as a helpful thing to mention for potential fans. 
This anime is something else. I personally didn't expect much from this, maybe like a fanservicey type of drama. What I got was instead my new favourite anime of all time.
The story isn't exactly anything special, but I've never seen a take on Adolescence like this. Basically the characters each go through Adolescence syndrome, and they have to findways around it and fix their problems before things go south. Again, nothing too special.


The art is amazing, I dare say compareable to Your Name in terms of charm and quality. Everything blends together so nicely and it is pleasing to the eye. There are some minor errors here and there but overall the art just couldn't get any better. 


The OP and EDs are fun to listen to. For each major character arc, the end themes are sung by that character with their own special lighting and mood. This was a nice touch of detail and all the voices were beautiful. 


The characters are what really makes this show so special. The man himself, Sakuta, isn't your average MC meant to ponder to a typical person. His snarkiness is legendary. He has his own personality and his own beliefs, he's not an empty hollow shell. Just like him, all the other characters aren't there to simply fulfill a role. They have their own problems and personalities, making them feel "human", as opposed to many characters.


The last thing I want to mention is the teachable moments this show offers. There is a lot of life advice here that can be used in our everyday real lives. The problems each character go through can be relayed to anyone out there who may be struggling in a similar way. I think that this level of writing, along with the characters themselves are what truly make this anime so special. This is a 10/10, nearly perfect anime.

I WOULD 100% RECOMMEND THIS ANIME.
I love this anime because of how it makes all the stuff that can't really happen feel real. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is a overall 10/10 for me. It reveals the characters and their qualities at a perfect pace and does not ever feel like the art our sounds were out of place. What really made this anime standout for me was the story. The story was not very complex so it was easy to follow and enjoy. It had a the perfect pace and was not predictable at all. I originally clickedon it because of the bunny girl but the story hooked me in like roadhog from overwatch. It could have had a little more fanservice but the amazing art made up for that. The characters were very well rounded and sometimes cliched a bit too much, but who doesn't love cliche anime from time to time (ONLY SOME SCENES.) I'm probably going to revisit this anime when the movie comes out so that's it for now.

Yikes. The exaggerated hatred in some of these reviews compelled me to write one. This may not be the best anime created but it’s pretty damn good. Also, this anime is not Monogatari and is not meant to be compared to Monogatari. Monogatari is not the better version of this show. Believe it or not, not everyone likes pedophiles as MCs. 
Moving on, Bunny Girl Senpai is a show that tries to tackle a variety of issues associated with puberty (I would say the issues go beyond just puberty though). Sakuta is our protagonist, a smart-ass pervert of a loner who encounters different instances ofAdolescence Syndrome, which is a syndrome that pretty much manifests whatever the problem the person is going through in a supernatural way. There is a lot of pseudoscience bullshit here, but it didn’t affect my enjoyment of the show, because pseudoscience bullshit is pretty much the norm for these type of shows. Each arc deals with a different case of Adolescence Syndrome, usually taking 3 episodes for the resolution of each arc. I will say that the show does not reach the highs of the first arc again, which I found amazing, but each arc was quality in its own right.


Now what’s to like about this show? For one, the banter between Mai and Sakuta is enjoyable, as well as the fact that they act naturally around each other. You won’t find the romance stagnant like other anime shows where it takes the MC 300 episodes to be around the girl he likes without squeaking like an idiot. That’s a plus in my book. Two, the show does not shy away from tackling topics such as bullying, the sexualization of minors and girls, insecurity in maintaining friends, terrible parents, etc; and for the most part, it tries to do it in a genuine way. Can the progress and development of the characters feel a bit forced at times? Absolutely, but I never felt like things were rushed to the point of being absurd. Which bring us to three, the characters. Yes, I won’t deny that the characters (Mainly Futaba) can seem like vehicles for the issue that the writer is intending on focusing on, but they have enough of their own personality that I found them distinct enough to actually give a damn about them during their arcs. I even shed a tear or two in some parts, but that’s neither here nor there.


The animation for this show is generic, but it does it job. Not much to say about it. The soundtrack is solid.


Overall, this a great anime. I definitely recommend it.

This show I think has to be the surprise smash hit of not only the Fall but of the year in my eyes. Honestly only even started this cause I wanted to see even more of what Cloverworks had before The Promised Neverland. But holy cow am I glad I did. 
Fantastic show in all regards. I don't think there's a single overt, glaring issue with this show. don't even think I'm exaggerating. Maybe a little but still like come on. It's really incredible. Feels like Oregairu and Sakurasou before it. A sophisticated look at young love. done right and with maturity. Treating these youngadults as such and not comedic fodder. The whole cast is kept small and intimate while showing us depth to each one of them. 


This show did such a good job of translating the seemingly complicated idea of Puberty Syndrome into something that made sense over the multiple arcs and made us care for the new focal female character. Each arc had me reeling and getting pretty emotional each time. The writing and character work are truly commendable. Sakuta and his snark really helped set him more apart than most of his contemporaries. Mai and her take no shit attitude was refreshing as well. Their bond was the heart this show needed. 


this is undoubtedly one of the years best. A must see for drama and romance fans. Astounding.


10/10. ❤❤🐰.

Please note this review is intended to be read by those that have finished watching Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai and while care has been taken to minimize story related spoilers there may still be spoilers within character analysis. You have been warned. 
Based off a popular light novel of the same name Seishun Buta Yarou Wa Bunny Girl Sempai No Yume Wo Minai which is better known by its English title Rascal Does not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai is a romance, comedy, supernatural and school genre anime that gives us the opportunity to see what will happen if a teenageboy who always approached his life with cynicism due to his bad rep that came about due to the intervention of a supernatural event that only he and his family had encountered were to meet not just one but a series of girls that are suffering from the same syndrome that has changed the life of not just him but his family as well. A condition that goes by the name of Puberty syndrome that according to rumors is caused by a teenager’s sensitivity to the many issues that transpire during this period of their life and the sense of instability that can come about from experiencing them. While animes that make use of supernatural themes that combine them with other genres like romance isn’t itself rare within the field of anime the premise for Rascal is one that can be said to be rather unique as while allowing the mc Sakuta to encounter many different girls whose unique problems are the cause of their syndromes rather than make use of abilities that would allow them to solve them in one go the series instead takes the opposite approach and takes a more methodical approach as it allows us to see the whole process of how the origin of the problem is identified and how Sakuta helps the girl gradually overcome the struggles that come with it and eventually freeing her from it. This approach I felt was rather unique as in addition to the other genre’s it also added in a sense of mystery to the series as to help each girl Sakuta and co had to get to know them as individuals and slowly piece together each clue that they find as they try to figure out what the problem is. This act of combining the act of solving a mystery with character development I felt was interesting and was one of the main reasons that drew me to watch this anime. The first episode of the series while doing a great job at introducing the series main setting and characters also did well In showing the peculiar effects that Puberty syndrome can cause to the people that suffer from it and proved intriguing enough that I would watch this series to the very end. 


The overall story of the series takes place within the modern day within the confines of Kanagawa prefecture and follows the life of Sakuta Azusagawa a second-year high school student who attends the local Minegahara High school. Sakuta whose life has been adversely affected by a traumatic event in the past that not only ensured that he has few friends but also be labeled by others within the school as a delinquent that is to be avoided at all costs. While out wandering the local library Sakuta has a seemingly supernatural encounter with a high school girl that’s dressed in the rather eye-catching outfit of a bunny girl. But despite this enchanting attire, Sakuta is the only one that is able to see her much to the surprise of both. Seeing this the girl introduces herself to him introducing herself as none other than Mai Sakurajima a popular actress and idol that is on hiatus. Mai astounded that she has finally been able to find someone that is able to see her reveals to Sakuta the reason for her attire which is to determine whether anyone else but her can see herself because for some reason she has seemingly become not just invisible to others physically but also mentally as well. As Sakuta listens to Mai’s problem he starts to realize the similarity that this has with the problems that had so affected his family in the past and as a result of this curiosity decides to help her find out the true cause of this problem while at the same time trying to determine what the underlying cause for these problems are. Along the way, while helping Mai try to figure out and overcome the underlying problems that are causing her invisibility Sakuta also starts to encounter an increasing number of girls who not only are experiencing similar effects to Mai but are also having these adversely affect their lives much like it had for Sakuta in the past. Sakuta while loathe to help others finds himself unable to stop himself from trying to help them overcome the problems that caused them to develop such a condition perhaps out of a desire to save them or maybe to prove to himself and others that the condition that caused so much change to his life was not fake and was in fact real. Whichever the reason one things for certain for Sakuta’s seemingly average life as a high school student is able to become much more interesting. 


Sakuta Azusagawa 


Sakuta Azusagawa portrayed by veteran voice actor Kaito Ishikawa of Gate and Owari No Seraph game is one of the main characters of the series and is the main protagonist of the series. A second-year student that attends the local high school Sakuta from initial appearances is seen to be a quiet, calm and collected person by nature that seemingly approaches his life with a degree of cynicism that’s rarely seen among people his age. Despite this cynical nature of his and his seemingly laid-back attitude Sakuta is someone that can be seen to be intelligent, understanding and earnest and can be surprisingly perceptive as well. While Sakuta’s laid-back attitude can often give people the impression that he’s not giving his best at things and is a bad trait of his the opposite is instead true. Sakuta’s laid-back nature while often giving people the wrong impression of him can be seen to be something of a time skipper for Sakuta that reflects his true personality for while appearing to be laid back beneath this nature of his Sakuta is in fact a particularly sharp person that thanks to his perceptive skills is able to offer surprisingly sharp comments that while bypassing traditional conversational convention gets straight to the heart of the matter. This desire to get to the heart of a matter without wasting precious time in pointless chatter can be said to be one of the hallmarks of Sakuta’s personality. As a result of both his cynicism and a result of his past at the beginning of the series Sakuta was widely seen as someone to be avoided and while not lacking in friends he had precious few people that he can trust outside of them. This lack of bonds with his peers and the sense of isolation that he got from them soon caused Sakuta to develop a sense of caution that he applies to his everyday life which is shown in the fact that he is not willing to trust someone’s word at face value and always strives to find everything that he can about something before making a decision something that will put him in good stead as the series goes on. However, despite Sakuta’s determination to live a low key life that avoids all the types of drama that life can throw at you it can be seen that he is someone that cares deeply about his friends and indeed is someone that cannot avoid helping those that are in obvious trouble despite the bother that this would have caused him which is showed in his attempts to help not only Mai but each of the girls that he encounters throughout the series and showing that despite his nature he is someone that is helpful, honest and determined to help people until their problems are solved. A prominent trait of Sakuta’s that comes about as a result of his cynical nature is the fact that he is able to crack off random jokes and witty comments at will something that I felt was not just interesting but also aid in taking off some of the tension that comes about as Sakuta and Mai encounter the various situations that impact not just them but also their friends as well. 


As the series goes on and Sakuta’s character is expanded upon Sakuta’s personality gradually starts to change. At the beginning of the series largely due to the isolation that he gets subjected to by his peers Sakuta was someone that treated bonds and relationships with others somewhat cautiously as if always expecting the worst to happen in them. While shown to be very loyal to his friends Sakuta was however shown to be wary of strangers and was unwilling to trust them until they proved that their request was genuine. However, once he is satisfied that their requests were genuine and that they really needed help Sakuta’s attitude would change from that of wariness to one that would be determined to help them solve their problems. This aspect of his character is shown best in how he decided to help Mai in her quest to solve the mystery that caused her to become invisible to society. Thought Mai while somewhat famous was still someone that was largely a stranger to him Sakuta not only worked hard to determine what was the underlying cause behind the problem but also worked hard to determine the conditions that would allow it to be solved. This shows that despite his loner like attitude Sakuta is someone that cares deeply about the plight of others and would do all he can to help those people that he had managed to bond with and understand something that is shown to a degree in all the relationships that he ends up forging as the series goes on. Despite his determined nature that would suggest that Sakuta would prefer to solve situations with brash decisions Sakuta is someone that can be surprisingly considerate of the needs of others and is willing to make short-term sacrifices that while potentially causing him trouble also allows him to get to the best possible deal out of a given situation in the long term a trait that is shown well in the relationship that he establishes with Mai within the series and the steps that he takes to make that relationship a success. This side of Sakuta that showed that beneath his quiet and brash nature lay someone that was willing to make short-term sacrifices in exchange for securing a better overall outcome I thought was one that suited Sakuta well and did well to both contrast his character while adding more depth to him. The character of Sakuta I felt was an interesting one whose attitude to life and to bonds in general contrasted well with the care that he can display towards his friends as well as the lengths to which he will go to help those that are in need. While his cynicism and his witty comebacks and jokes may sound out of place at times, I felt that these served well to balance out the many tense situations that can result from the various problems that he meets over the course of the series. At the same time, I felt that his innate nature also served well to enable him to become a balancer of sorts within the series where he can provide logical questions and answers to Mai that not only expand the plot but also stop them from making rash decisions. 


Mai Sakurajima 


Mai Sakurajima portrayed by veteran seiyuu Asami Seto of Tokyo Ghoul and Strike the Blood fame is one of the main characters of the series and is the main heroine of the series. A third-year student that attends the same high school as Sakuta Mai in her initial appearances is seen to be a quiet and direct person by nature that while polite and considerate to others had a curious tendency to maintain a distance from her classmates. As a result of this loner like attitude Mai in the beginning of the series while a relatively well-known person within the school due to her fame as an actress was someone that was followed by many nasty comments and rumors that came about as a result of her late entry into school and her skip to senior year which ensured that despite her fame she was largely seen as an outsider by her peers. As a result of this, it's perhaps unsurprising that this would lead Mai to adopt an attitude that ensured that she was wary of any person that approached her. However, despite this wariness of outsiders, she was not averse to bonding with people that have shown themselves worthy of her trust as shown in the interaction that she had with Sakuta that proved to be the spark that started their bond. Once with friends that she can trust however it can be seen that beneath her icy nature Mai is someone that’s intelligent, perceptive, responsible and understanding by nature. Despite gaining perhaps the first friend since she entered high school it can be seen that she still values the sense of freedom that she gets from being a loner. However, it can be seen that rather than push people away as she would have in the past the friendship that she has established with Sakuta has opened her eyes somewhat to the advantages that having friends can bring to her life and while more accepting of this fact doesn’t stop her from expressing a somewhat playful attitude in reaction to Sakuta’s attempts to integrate her into society. While the effects of Mai’s friendship with Sakuta did well in dispelling the initial distrust that Mai had towards friendship it also had the effect of improving the view that she had towards school as well as Mai as the series went on no longer viewed it as something to be avoided and instead approached it with a seriousness and diligence that matched well with her position as a senior. 


As the series goes on and as Mai’s personality is gradually revealed and expanded upon it can be seen that Mai’s invisibility problem is something that is borne out of the many struggles that she has with living the dual life of being both a student and a celebrity. While certainly enjoying the fame and the fortune that comes from being an actress and the fact that she through her actions can bring happiness to the many fans that support her it can be seen that this also caused within Mai a sense of unease as while loving the world that showbiz offers her this also created a belief within her that she was merely living under the terms that were set by her mother and was nothing more than a tool for her. As a result of this belief which not only caused Mai’s relationship with her mother to break down but also caused her to view her life as an actress to be nothing more than a manufactured personality that did not reflect her true self this created a struggle within Mai that proved to be the catalyst that started her crisis while at the same time leading her to meet someone that would truly change her life. Though at first viewing the fact that was invisible to everyone with some degree of amusement this was soon replaced by a deep fear as Mai began to realize that if it got worst, she would not only be forgotten as an actress but also as a person as well. As a result of this fear Mai began to realize that more than anything the bonds that she has established with her friends is something that she rather than trying to avoid should instead learn to embrace as while her career as an actress may be important to her this pales in comparison that outside of that Mai’s real persona actually no one that she can rely on and help her when she needed it the most. Due to this Mai’s bond with Sakuta gradually began to improve as she was able to witness firsthand the kind of efforts that he put in to help her despite how weak their bonds were. While improving the relationship that she had with Sakuta this act of friendship also opened Mai’s eyes to the fact that while her career as an actress was indeed one that was created by her mother the love of showbiz and the life that came with it was not fake and indeed was something that she genuinely loved and that if she wanted to overcome the inner struggle that was causing her crisis she must learn to embrace the fact that while grateful to her mother for building her career Mai must learn to walk her own path in life. As a result of this life-changing experience, Mai in the aftermath of this crisis began to gradually change her attitude toward life. While still quiet Mai gradually becomes much more talkative and more willing to take the initiative in her interactions with Sakuta which is best shown in the fact that she openly chides him and teases him often which while doing well in shredding the last of her loner like attitudes away also shows the gradual change of their relationship from friendship to romance. Though working hard in the aftermath to rebuild her career into the life that she wants to live Mai also takes great care to treasure every moment that she spends with her beloved despite the inexperience that both have in the art of romance. This development in their bonds I felt while certainly welcome was one that I felt represented well the kind of lessons that Mai learned from her interaction with Sakuta and her determination to live the life that she rather than her mother wants. 


Tomoe Koga 


Tomoe Koga portrayed by veteran seiyuu singer Nao Touyama of Beatless and Asterisk Wars fame is one of the main supporting characters of the series and is the main heroine of her respective arc within the series. A first-year student that attends the same school as Sakuta and Mai Tomoe at the beginning of the series from initial appearances is seen to be a kind, caring and quiet person by nature that tries to approach each day with cheerfulness. A friendly, teasing and intelligent person by nature Tomoe while possessing traits that would usually have ensured that she possess healthy levels of self-confidence within her is shown instead to be someone that gets flustered and embarrassed quite easily and indeed is someone that can be seen to be sensitive to the moods of her friends as well as the latest trends that they are going through at the moment. While obviously loyal to her friends it can be seen that this rather than being loyalty is more along the lines of reliance on them. Despite the ease in which Tomoe can become embarrassed it can be seen rather amusingly that she’s brave enough to argue with others over the simplest of things and while these arguments are rarely serious ones, they are still ones that do well in providing a sense of amusement to the series. One of the best examples of this was the argument that took place between her and Sakuta during their first date when they argued with each other via text messages. 


As the series goes on however and more of Tomoe’s personality is revealed it can be seen that interestingly despite Tomoe’s perceived sense of popularity within the school and the number of friends that she can call upon to help her when she needs it the sense of pride that should come back as a result is not present. Rather than a sense of pride, it can be seen that beneath her kind and caring nature Tomoe is someone that too is wrestling with a deep fear of what will happen if all of her friends would forget her. While Tomoe’s surface personality of being a kind and caring person is indeed genuine it can be seen that the importance that she places on the forging of friendships and bonds with others and her need to not just fit in but also maintain that level of relationship borders on a sense of desperation that is rarely seen among schoolgirls. As Tomoe’s past and the pain that she suffered in the past is gradually revealed it can be seen that this sense of desperation to both forge friendships and maintain bonds with her friends is a result of her desire to not relive the pain and sense of isolation that she had not just experienced but grew to fear when she was in middle school. A condition that reminded Sakuta well of the time that his sister Kaede experienced the same level of pain that came about due to the outbreak of puberty syndrome within her when she was in middle school and contributed greatly to his decision to help her. At the beginning of the series, Tomoe’s first impression of Sakuta was not a positive one as she saw him as not just lacking in terms of romance matters but also somewhat rude due to his direct nature as well. At the same time, she often found himself quarreling with him for the simplest of reasons which gave her endless levels of frustration. However, despite this over time Tomoe’s friendship with Sakuta began to improve as a result of the fact that for the first time she was able to forge a friendship with someone that knew not just the number of inner struggles that she was hiding beneath the surface but at the same time provide her with a sense of bluntness that provided a calming effect that made her realize that he would never betray the friendship that has been forged between them. As a result of this Tomoe’s personality gradually began to level out and while still retaining the kind and caring personality traits that define her she also comes to realize that true friends are those that you are able to be honest to with in all things and that no matter how well she tries to fit in as long as secrets remain your friends will still maintain a distance between you and them. While losing much of the desperation that was most prominent about her character it can be seen rather amusingly that she still retained the wittiness that truly made her character stand out something that I was really glad to see as this was the perfect counter to Sakuta’s cynical nature and their little quarrels are always amusing to see. The character of Tomoe I felt was an interesting one whose underlying core struggle I felt was well done and contrasted well with not just her personality but also reflected upon one of the core issues that high school girls her age could suffer from if they moved from one location to the next to attend the next level of school as they progressed in their education. 


Rio Futaba 


Rio Futaba portrayed by veteran seiyuu Atsumi Tanezaki of Owari No Seraph fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is the main heroine of her respective arc within the series. A second year student that attends the same high school as Sakuta Futaba along with Sakuta’s friend Yuma can be said to be the only true friends that the former had within the school until Mai came along thanks to the fact that they were classmates that went through the first year of high school together. From her initial appearance, Futaba is seen to be curious, intelligent and logical person by nature that prefers to believe in solid facts before making any kind of assumption. This belief in trusting actual evidence versus believing in something that cannot be substantiated such as supernatural events resonates well with the fact that she’s a member of the school’s science club a role that’s further enhanced by the lab coat and glasses that she wears that reinforces the image that she’s not just an intelligent girl but one that acts as the voice of logic and intelligence within the series. True to her role as someone that believes firmly in logic Futaba is someone that is calm, attentive and composed by nature and while largely remaining indifferent to both the interactions that she has with Sakuta and the many problems that he brings to her she also doesn’t display any sense of frustration at him for bringing them to her. This shows that while she may view the problems that are brought to her as troublesome, she still views it as a challenge that was brought to her by a trusted friend and while difficult to see it can be seen that Futaba likes the fact that she will be of some assistance to someone that can be said to be her closest friend.  A good indication of this sense of friendship that she has with Sakuta is the witty comebacks that she exchanges with him every time he brings her a new problem. However, despite being a realist and despite having a background in science Futaba was seen to be someone that didn’t behave like a normal science-minded person. While Futaba is someone that tries hard to come up with deductions on the various problems that she is presented by Sakuta with logic that is based off the knowledge and data that she has to hand it can be seen that surprisingly she is someone that’s capable of branching out and thinking outside of the box when things make no logical sense something that I felt was quite surprising for her. At the same time while regarded as someone that had both looks and intelligence within the school it can be seen that Futaba didn’t treat others that may be less intelligent than her any differently and would take great care to explain to them how she got to a particular deduction in a precise and easily understood manner showing that beneath her indifferent nature Futaba was also someone that was considerate. 


As the series goes on however and more of Futaba’s personality is expanded upon it can be seen that she also has many struggles that she seemingly hides beneath her surface personality. Despite possessing both looks and intelligence it can be seen that Futaba rather than embracing these qualities of hers that would have ensured that she has no shortage of friends instead does the opposite of adopting instead the path of a loner that while giving her peace of mind also ensures that she has few friends. While seemingly content with the solitude that comes from being a loner and the small circle of friends that are centered around Sakuta and Yuma who can be said to be her closest friends it can be seen that this is far from the truth. While it can be said that Futaba does enjoy the time that she is able to spend with her friends both in helping them in solving the many problems that can come from living as a teenager and in solving the problems that Sakuta brings to her it can be seen that beneath this Futaba actually has a secret fear that one day both of these dear friends will eventually leave her and make her alone again. This sense of fear that she got from the thought that one day she will be alone once more when used in combination with the sense of inferiority that she feels about her body soon caused within Futaba a split in her personality that manifested itself in a very science like way. At the beginning of the crisis, Futaba while certainly curious about the split persona and the reason that led to its creation was largely tolerant about it and indeed seemed to view it with a degree of amusement. However, as the crisis deepened this sense of amusement began to fade and was replaced by an increasing sense of fear due to the actions of the persona that showed the hidden feelings that she had for so long been hiding from her friends. However while certainly fearful of the effects that this would have on her life Futaba began to gradually realize that this manifestation of her hidden feelings was no one’s fault but her own for if she had been more willing to accept the hidden feelings and fears that she had then maybe she would not just have more friends but also be able to live a high school life that was full of laughter and fun times with her friends instead of being secluded in a science lab every lunchtime with nothing but the beakers to keep her company. In the aftermath of the crisis Futaba while largely retaining her core personality traits of being a rational, intelligent and curious person began to show a more positive attitude to life and began to show more of her feelings openly rather than conceal them as she did in the past. At the same time Futaba while still far from securing dozens of new friends begins making gradual attempts to expand her circle of friends which is shown in the fact that she managed to establish a surprising friendship with Mai in the aftermath. While accepting the fact that while its true that Sakuta and Yuma may indeed leave her in the future until that day arrives, she would ensure that she will enjoy thoroughly the time that she can spend with her two best friends. The character of Futaba I felt was an interesting character whose core struggle and the evolution of her character reflected well on one of the deepest fears that high school students would develop as they approach their senior years. I felt that Futaba’s gradual evolution from someone that kept much of her fears and true feelings hidden while trying to enjoy each day with her friends to someone that was not just more open with her feelings but also more willing to expand her circle of friends was well done and showed just how much she had learned from her previous error and how much she wants to remedy it by enjoying the time left to her in high school.  


Nodoka Toyohama 


Nodoka Toyohama portrayed by veteran seiyuu singer Maaya Uchida of Charlotte and Yamada and the Seven Witches fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is the heroine of her respective arc within the series. A teenage idol and a member of the popular Idol group Sweet Bullet Nodoka from initial appearances is seen to be a confident, prideful and competitive person by nature that while showing well the qualities that idols may be expected to display makes Nodoka a difficult person to get to know personally. True to her career as an idol Nodoka is someone that is seen to be intelligent and fast thinking and while showing some curious attitudes towards her career as an idol is seen to love the role and works hard to fulfill the many roles that are assigned to her in that field. Despite the flashy looks that Nodoka possesses that would otherwise suggest that she will be a difficult person to get to know it can be seen that rather the opposite is true. While certainly, a prideful and competitive person by nature Nodoka was also someone that was both perceptive and understanding skills that while useful to an idol also do well in allowing her to see the true reason for someone’s actions. This within the series is shown well in the relationship that she establishes with Sakuta as while the two of the them did not have the best of first impressions their relationship gradually improved as a result of Nodoka seeing and understanding the depth of love that he feels for her half-sister Mai.  


As the series goes on and Nodoka’s personality is expanded upon it can be seen that despite Nodoka’s positive and cheerful nature she also has many struggles that she keeps from both her family and from her half-sister Mai someone that she not only idolizes but respects greatly. In the beginning, while shown to be someone that idolized her half-sister it can be seen that despite the positive attitude that she has towards her that Nodoka actually conceals a sense of resentment towards Mai that created within her an inferiority complex that expanded every time she saw one of Mai’s performances. While Nadoka knows very well that despite all the efforts that she puts into as an idol she will never be able to get close to Mai at the beginning of the series she was seemingly content with this glad to be at least able to carve out her own place within the entertainment field that was free from both her mother and Mai. However as the crisis that involved both her and Mai deepened and after seeing the effects that Mai had in her attempts to keep the situation between them a secret from the media this attitude of remaining content gradually began to vanish and instead be replaced by a sense of open resentment of Mai and a belief that no matter how much she did she is still unnecessary in the larger scheme of things a belief that was also fueled by the large number of feelings that she had bottled within her. However in the aftermath of not just discovering that the main reason for her sense of resentment was fake and after realizing that rather than being seen as a rival Mai was instead treating her like an actual sister this sense of resentment began to vanish and be replaced by both a genuine sense of gratitude and a new sense of determination to prove to not just Mai but to everyone that supported her as well that she will be able to make her own mark on the entertainment field as well. The character of Nodoka I felt was an interesting that demonstrated well the kind of challenges that can come from having a sibling whose career is continuously being compared to yours as you progress in life and the challenges that it can cause to both the mental state and the physical state of one’s mind and the view to which they view their jobs. The evolution of Nodoka from someone that while appearing to support and idolize Mai was secretly hiding her resentment of the fact that she was always being seen as second fiddle to Mai to someone that realized that her resentment towards her was not just misplaced but also the fact that Mai never saw her as an outsider and instead saw her as family I felt was well done and demonstrated well that no matter the fame that one can secure and the distance it causes between siblings it cannot suppress the bonds that are forged between family members.  


Kaede 


Kaede Azusagawa portrayed by veteran seiyuu Yurika Kubo of Youkoso and High School Fleet fame is one of the main supporting characters of the series and is the heroine of her respective arc within the series. A middle school student and Sakuta’s younger sister that lives with him Kaede from initial appearances is seen to be a quiet, curious and positive person by nature that was shown to have a deep bond with her brother. While curious Kaede was also shown to be rather prone to making misunderstandings which is best shown when she meets Mai for the first time. In the beginning of the series as a result of a serious bullying event that caused her to experience a rather traumatic event in the past Kaede largely stayed at home and indeed stayed away from all aspects of society whether its phones, internet, and tv instead opting to spend most of her time either with her cat or with her brother. As a result of this lifestyle, Kaede in the beginning was shown to be extremely wary of outsiders and would get spooked quite easily despite the attempts by both Sakuta and the visitors to calm her. As a result of this fear Kaede was shown to have a heavy reliance on her brother and indeed from looking at the relationship that exists between them it can be deduced that to Kaede her brother is akin to her emotional foundation as it is only with his support can Kaede continue to exist within the world after the trauma that she went through when she was younger. 


As the series goes on however and Kaede’s personality and past is revealed her personality gradually starts to change. While noted at the beginning of the series to be someone that was both wary of others and at the same time someone that got scared of others easily as the series goes on this aspect of her personality begins to gradually change. As a result of being both the younger sister of Sakuta as well as the fact that she lives with him as well Kaede throughout the series had the opportunity to meet many of the girls that Sakuta had met over the course of the series and witnessed first hand both the types of struggles that each girl was going through as well as their determined attempts to overcome the problems that had not just constrained them but also caused them much hardship whether physically and emotionally something that Kaede had also encountered in the past and can easily relate to. As a result of seeing these girls work so hard to overcome the problems that were bothering them Kaede also began to realize that while she too may have problems that have also caused her great emotional pain unlike these girls she was not only taking no steps to overcome them but was also dragging down her dear brother and stopping him from enjoying the life that he wanted with Mai. As a result of this realization Kaede while still wary and scared of others as before gradually tried to take steps to both overcome not just her fear of strangers but also strive to not only become independent of her brother but also take the first steps in her journey to reintegrate back into society. While the journey itself was anything but easy Kaede as she embarked on her journey of reintegrating herself back into society began to show marked improvements to her personality that showed well the fruits of the labors that her determination to succeed had managed to awaken. While still a quiet girl Kaede’s attitude toward others began to gradually improve and though still wary of strangers towards those that she knows well like Mai she is able to converse with normally and is able to bond well as well. At the same time while still wary of electronic items that would allow her to talk to others directly Kaede rather than be scared and avoid it every time it rings as she had done in the past at least tries to try to answer it. Arguably the best example of Kaede’s attempt to integrate herself back into society is her creation of a wish diary that as the name implies contains the wishes of the items that she wants to be able to do herself as proof of her attempt to integrate herself back into society. While most of these wishes are simple matters to Kaede they are far more than that as to her they are akin to giant hurdles that she must learn to surmount if she wants to be able to overcome the trauma that had for so long held her back. One of the most important wishes within the wish book is without a doubt the wish that stated clearly that she wanted to go to school. To Kaede, this was perhaps her most important but at the same time, her hardest wish for it was her time at middle school that was the main origin point for the trauma that had so changed her life. However conversely the school can also be said to be the final hurdle that she must overcome if she was to overcome her trauma and accomplish her goal. The wish book concept I felt was an interesting idea for while it showed the many wishes that Kaede wanted to accomplish it also had the effect of showing the depths of her Kaede’s determination to not just accomplish these goals but by doing so be able to take her first steps into integrating herself back into society, as a result I felt it was a perfect complement to Kaede’s character. 


The character of Kaede I felt was an interesting one and her core struggle of a bullying incident that caused her to not just lose her memories of the events but cause an entirely new personality to not just be created but replace her default one was a surprising move. At the same time, I felt that linking Kaede’s social anxiety which is a result of the trauma that she suffered in school with the bullying was interesting as while social anxiety has many different causes bullying in a school setting is by far the most common cause. The effects by the cast and by Kaede herself to overcome her trauma within the series was an aspect that I thought was done really well with her determination to take the first steps out of her apartment and her attempts to go to school despite the trauma being especially well done and was something that was both heartwarming and something that resonated well within my heart because the pain from bullying is something that I have also suffered as well. 


AMV 


In terms of animation, I thought that the series animation was something that was really well done within the series being not just bright and rich in variety but also relatively clear as well. This aspect of the animation also served well to showcase not just the main setting of the Kanagawa prefecture but also served to enhance its beauty to the viewer. The various locations that were featured within the series I thought was not just well animated but also featured a great deal of variety to them as well. While these locations were relatively simple ones that wouldn’t be out of place within any city, I thought that this simplicity was actually an advantage of the series as these locations were both relevant to high school students that serve as the series main cast and at the same time resonating with the series main theme of social problems that are being experienced by teenagers. The character designs for the series main and support cast I thought was something that was done really well as while each was unique, I felt that they reflected well on the social status that each character adhered too within the series. 


In terms of music, the series made use of one opening and ending theme for the series which was Kimi No Sei that was performed by the Peggies and Fukashigi no Carte. The ending theme of Fukashigi No Carte is rather notable in this case as while the lyrics for the song remain the same the ending theme is sung by the seiyuu’s that portray the heroines for their respective arcs when the series start their respective arcs. This aspect of the series I felt was interesting as while it allowed the seiyuu’s themselves to show off their vocal talent it also highlighted the fact that their respective heroine was the current heroine within the story. Both the opening and ending themes I felt were excellent ones that while catchy gave me contrasting impressions on them with the former giving me a sense of excitement as if drawing me in an adventure while the latter had a relaxing feel to it that gave the impression that the adventure was now over and that it was time to relax until the next one starts. In terms of voice acting, I felt that the series voice cast all did an excellent job at portraying their assigned roles within the series whether these were main or support ones. In particular, I feel that Kaito Ishikawa, Asami Seto, Nao Touyama, Atsumi Tanezaki, Maaya Uchida and Yurika Kubo deserve special praise as I felt that they all did a fantastic job in portraying the characters of Sakuta, Mai, Tomoe, Futaba, Nodoka and Kaede respectively. While she didn’t have a large role within the series, I felt that Inori Minase also did well in portraying the character of Shoko a character that proved vital across several arcs within the series. 


Overall conclusion 


Overall Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai was an interesting anime that I really enjoyed and is arguably one of the best animes that aired this anime season. In my opinion its main strengths that allowed it to truly stand out in my eyes was its interesting premise, interesting and well thought out story, well designed and developed characters and a skillful combination of creative social problems and story arcs that made great use of the series main theme of the unique pressure and struggles that teenagers struggle with within society. 


The overall premise of the series I felt was definitely one of the highlights of the series and while at first it may appear to be a standard school-based romance story that would allow Sakuta and Mai to become an eventual couple this simple idea soon collapsed as the series went on to expand the plot by introducing the main problem that each of the characters struggle with which is the puberty syndrome. Perhaps more than anyone within society teenagers are particularly vulnerable to sudden changes to not just society itself but also to how society sees them as well largely due to the fact that they are at an age where they are starting to take their first steps into a place that until now was largely unknown to them which is society. While most teenagers would gladly laugh off such pressures and focus on the chief advantages that being a teen gives you such as taking it easy and falling in love with the girl of your dreams not all problems can be dealt with this way. For as free as society can appear to be there are also many problems that can cause others great pain through even the simplest of offhand comments and beliefs pain that if left unchecked can cause even larger problems. Even in a free society, not all problems can be revealed to others in confidence as society can often be unforgiving on those that speak of problems that can be considered impossible as Sakuta and the main cast found out. Faced with the potential display of ridicule, distrust and the potential rise of nasty rumors the sufferers only choice is to bury their problems inside them and hide it from society as they live out their lives until either it's forgotten or it surfaces in a most unexpected manner. Puberty syndrome while a fictional affliction was an idea that I felt made great use of the social aspect of the theme as while showing the kind of physical effects that it can cause to those that suffer from it the affection also allowed the visualization of some of the more common problems that not only exists within society but ones that society often has a hand in causing whether intentionally or not. 


The overall story that made use of such an interesting premise and theme I felt was another of the series main highlights. While animes that make use of multiple story arcs within the overall plot are by no means rare I felt that Rascal’s overall plot was rather special in that while it made use of five main story arcs that correspond to each of the volumes that the series covers the story arcs themselves never seem to be a series of short stories as I have experienced in the past. This is due to the fact that each story arc within the series rather than being a stand-alone adventure that served as a detour for the main plot is instead very much part of the main plot and while the individual events of those arcs are rarely mentioned the fact that they are mentioned at all helps reinforce the fact that while Sakuta’s journey of helping the girls may have been hard it was one that not only allowed him to gain new friends but also break them out of the struggle that society was putting them under. Something that not only helped Sakuta develop as a character but also allow the girls to not just do the same but allow them to show the fruits of their labor outside of their respective arc. Each of the story arcs that were featured within the series as well as the heroines that acted as the arcs central focus I felt was really well done as each of the problems that they face not only matched the heroines social status but also showed the many unique problems that can come from both their feelings towards their status as well as societies view on them as well. These problems I felt while relatively simple ones were paired well with both the unique themes that each arc made use of and the unique feelings and circumstances that each heroine possessed that led them to become a victim of the puberty syndrome until Sakuta came along. The manner of how Sakuta and co-managed to solve the core struggles that each of the heroines were burdened with I felt was interesting as rather than being an outsider Sakuta was someone who had been in their shoes and as a result knew full well the kind of pain that can come from not having anyone believe your story. Seeing Sakuta not just try to understand and bond with each of the heroines as a person but also try to understand their core struggle and the circumstances that led to it before embarking on an attempt to solve it was something that I really enjoyed seeing as Sakuta despite having no reason to actually help the girls with their problems not only decides to do so but in the process not just help the girls solve their problems but also in the process overturn the dire reputation  that society has labeled him with by forming not just bonds but also friendships with the girls as well. In a way it can be said that the shared sense of pain that Sakuta and each of the girls had suffered as a result of the struggle that they went through as a result of contracting Puberty syndrome while a hard journey also allowed them to realize that while society can indeed be a hard place to live in they now realize that they are no longer alone in their struggle for through their shared pain they have found the one thing that they can always rely on when trying to live their lives and take the first steps into society. 


In overall Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai was an interesting anime that provided us with the opportunity to look into not just the kind of struggles that teenagers can experience within society but also the kind of pain that some aspects of society can have on the fragile mind of the next generation. The combination of its use of a real life but often neglected aspect of society which is the effects that the pressures of society can have on the fragile minds of teenagers and the use of the supernatural, romance and mystery genre’s while seemingly unwieldy at first glance I felt proved to be not just a unexpectedly potent combination that worked surprisingly well together but also provided a solid foundation that allowed us to see not just the kind of struggles that can exist within the teenagers that live within society but also the kind of trauma and circumstances that can lead to their formation. At the same time, this combination of genres also allowed us to understand not just the kind of negative feelings that result from such trauma but also appreciate the kind of positive feelings and actions that are needed to overcome it. As a final score I would say that Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai easily deserves a final score of 10/10.

Mid Series Review - This is a review written after watching 7 episodes of this amazingly well crafted series. This review contains plot spoilers and some amount of constructive criticism.
Story- To start of when i first saw this anime's cover art i expected it be one of those extremely cliche ecchi anime but like many i was very suprised once i watched the first ten minutes of the first episode , the story is just incredibly well thought out, it keeps you immersed and suprises you in every single episode (especially in the 6th episode when sakuta returns back to the previous day again).The only criticism i have  is the concept itself the puberty syndrome feels like a large plothole like the one in orange where the time travelling letters are never explained properly it just happens.If this is explained properly in the episodes to come the story is just perfect.


Art- The art is stunning and perfectly suits the theme of this anime, the background constantly changes according to the situation but it always has that light heated feel especially in the scene where sakuta regains his memory of mai and rushes out of the classroom to confess his love.


Sound- The sound is as good as this anime looks, it just goes right along with the theme and the voice actors do a great job with portraying the characters , although the opening is kind of underwhelming compared to the ending which i personally like more.


Characters- There is only word to describe the characters brilliant , all the characters are incredibly well written especially the main character sakuta is one of the reasons I find this series as entertaining as it is. I feel that anime badass/smart guys are cliche i.e not interested in anything(girls) and always on top no matter what and are generally just unfazed no matter what the situation , but sakuta on the other feels relatable( except for the getting a hot seenpai part :p) , he just wants to be a normal person and instead of being the annoying white knight who comes to every girls rescue he just lets things play out and does his best to help each character out.i could go on for  a while because mai and futaba(science girl) are also extremely well written characters (watch episode 7 for futaba character development not your average anime nerd girl) and mai's equally hilarious comebacks to sakuta are super entertaining the more screen time the two  have together the better the anime gets.


Enjoyment- Oregairu is one of my favorite school anime because the main character was entertaining as hell , this anime is right up there with oregairu for the same reason. Sakuta just makes this anime a delight to watch , his hilarious interactions with the other characters kicking koga(junior girl) in the butt and being taken to the police station and the best is when he tells that senior that he stepped on shit with the same shoe he kicked him with in the railway station fight scene was just hilarious.


Overall- Upto this point in the anime it is just completely entertaining and makes me  want the next episode to come out instantly because its just so good but i do hope that the upcoming episodes address the puberty syndrome properly and not let it become a major plothole , other than that would 10/10 recommend this series.

Spoiler Free Review:
Oh boy! What can I tell you about this anime... Well lets see... ITS AMAZING!
I decided to go ahead and watch the anime without researching it or reading about it at all. At first I was skeptical when I saw that the cover was a bunny girl and that even the very title of the anime has "Bunny Girl" in it, but BOY I WAS WRONG! 
As I was watching the first episode I got nothing but Kimi no Na wa vibes from it for some reason, even though the story has nothing to do with it as it is something that Ihave never seen before in any anime. The Art style is outstanding! (So many cute anime grills! ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) ) The Soundtrack, boy it  definitly has one of my favorite anime OPs this season! And the characters!... man dont get me started on them... the main characters are by far my favorite! The humor and the jokes the characters make are on point! (Something that other anime studios should learn from)\n
Overall giving it a solid 9/10. If you liked Kimi no Na wa or other Romance animes you are definitly going to love this one, so go ahead and give it a go! <3

Rascal Does Not Dream of a Bunny Girl Senpai at a glance can definitely be mistaken as a typical ecchi harem. The name and thumbnail picture certainly doesn't help with this. As a big fan of SNAFU my friend kept telling me to check this show out and I finally did. As of this moment only six episodes have aired and I have rewatched all of it twice. I don't regret a single moment of it. 
For starters, I just want to mention Hajime Kamoshida, who is the writer for this story. He has written both Sakurasou no Pet na Kanojo as well as JustBecause! which I have not watched yet. After watching this show I became in absolute awe on how well he delivers his concepts and characters. Sakurasou was one of my all time favorites, but he hits home for me once again this time with a realistic story about adolescence, environment, and unrequited love.


Adolescence is certainly not a topic that is covered often in anime (if not at all) and although I feel like they over exaggerate the concept of adolescence a little bit, the urge to always to be liked by others and to maintain a certain status really hit home for me. This reminded me of the days of when I was in high school of how everyone seem like "sheep" all of which who just follow the ongoing trend of today's culture. This always has bothered me as I was one of the few kids who distanced myself from those types of people. Fortunately for me I was still able to find a group of friends I could be myself with. Bunny Girl Senpai exemplifies this concept this so well and so effectively and I applaud Hajime Kamoshida for understanding how the culture is the way it is today. As a viewer it has taught me that people can be extremely self-conscious of themselves in today's social society, and are always striving to impress others at the expense of their own true self. Meanwhile people who suffer from adolescence, loneliness, and depression can be easily forgotten about but are in a need of emotional help and support.


I am going to touch on environment really quickly, and how it ties in with Adolescence. In Japanese culture,there is a term known as "reading the air". Although there is no direct translation to this from Japanese to English, it essentially is being able to figure out the general mood and atmosphere that is around you. What do people think about you? Are they thinking badly of you? Are they spreading rumors? Do they hate me? The amount of pressure from this social pressure is too much to bare for some. Some change themselves in order to fit with the rest of society, however others are too scared to even leave their front door. 


Aside from this interesting plot, the characters displayed in this show is nothing short from amazing. The main characters undergo a lot depth and development all of which are logical and relatable. The passive-aggressive relationship between the main couple constantly keeps me on my toes as well as providing great comedic relief. If I could only learn the charisma of these characters, I would. 

As of writing this the six episodes to me divides into two character development arcs, one arc for Mai and another one for Koga. Both of them were enough to bring tears to my eyes and I am thoroughly impressed how invested I was into these characters in such a short amount of time.


I seriously recommend re-watching this now or after it is completed. I picked up a lot after watching it the second time around. It can be a little tricky to grasp everything it is trying to throw at you, but once you understand it's concepts it is both fulfilling and rewarding. The psychological Japanese concept of "reading the air" and the concept of "La Place's Demon" made me very interested into looking more into what these terms mean. I advise you pay attention to every single dialogue there it is, as you will come out questioning both yourself, today's society, and hidden symbolic meanings.


All in all I absolutely adore this anime. It's been a while since I felt this "genuine" feeling from a show and it is both original and deep. It's been one heck of a ride so far.

“Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai” does one thing very well.  That is, taking the commonly done and quite stale school drama and turns it into something much more interesting with its usage of ‘Puberty Syndrome’, a supernatural disease that visualizes the characters social issues in a more creative and engaging way.
Unfortunately, it doesn’t have a lot to praise after that.
On the surface— this show, based of the title and artwork, is not what it seems. But with that being said, it doesn’t make the show better than what it is.
The biggest problem is the characters. Immediately we are presented with themain character Sakuta being incredibly brash and quick witted. This makes sense at first, but the show doesn’t waste any time in abusing this. Sakuta constantly comes off as fake, forced, and incredibly out of place. It was clear he was an attempt at a sort of larger than life character, but the writing utterly fails at producing this image. When you compare him to other characters in a similar situation, like Kyon from The Melancholy of Suzumiya Haruhi, or Araragi from Monogatari, the world built around them is much more suited for the way they act. In Kyon’s case, he is surrounded by complete weirdos, in every sense of the word. Him being the only normal one, the show was able to execute his “straight man” behavior in a hilariously unique way. In the case of the show more compared to Bunny Girl, Monogatari, the whole world is built on the character interaction being a sort of battle for the high ground. In Bunny Girl, there is no ‘battle for the conversational high ground’. It is just Sakuta imposing his incredible wit and intelligence on everyone else, somehow always having a quote worthy response to any situation. Nobody else is like him or responds with retorts that actually live up to his. The best example is the scene where he gets into a fight with the dudes harassing Tomoe. Not only does he end up winning the fight in the most ridiculously contrived way, but he shouts out a cringey line that nobody seems to care about. The show constantly does this with him. I never cringe when watching anime. This show made me. The other girl characters are mostly just flat and forgettable. I will say that Mai is decently written, but the other girls really never get a chance to stand out in any way. They feel more as just ploys to the narrative, especially Tomoe and Nodoka. This isn’t really a bad thing, but it certainly doesn’t make them memorable. 


The writing has seen some criticism in its “pretentious” way of describing the Puberty Syndrome by linking it to the workings of quantum physics. I am not going to pretend like I understand quantum physics in the first place like others have, but I will say that it adds a layer of confusion that didn’t need to be there in the first place. I don’t really want to be lectured an extremely hard concept to grasp fully just to understand why Mai is disappearing. Even people who have praised the show called the quantum physics tie-ins B.S.


The art and character design is very lackluster. Sakuta and his male friend have literally the exact same haircut. The color of his hair is almost identical to Tomoe. There is a random character that looks exactly like Futaba at the end of one of the episodes. Mai and Shouko look way too similar. The school uniforms are just brown and ugly. The art in general is dull and uninspired. Just your typical stuff.


The sound in the show is alright. There are some good piano tracks, although they play one of them all the time, you probably know which one I am referring to. The OP is weird. The actual song they use is great, but the problem is the actual animation that is going on behind it. Random shots and CG crowds is not a good look. The ED is great, and the touch with having the different Seiyuu sing it was nice.


The experience with Bunny Girl Senpai (which the title still doesn’t seemingly have any meaning) is a sort of strange one. It does things nicely, particularly the endings to each arc, but has too many downfalls to become anything more than just mediocre. I really wanted to like this more, because the setting is so easy to watch and enjoy.


It is obvious that this show tries everything it can to become an instant classic, and while that is respectable, it just doesn’t get the job done.

Clicked because Sexy Bunny Girl
First episode and I’m pretty much hooked
Bunny Girl Senpai revolves around the theory of Adolescence Syndrome. Something related to quantum physics theories which I have some knowledge of. Therefore, I can relate the characters to oregairu, Bakemonogatari as well as the format of the anime to Steins Gate.
The male MC has a ‘honest’ characteristic in a sense that he’s introverted. He doesn’t care about other’s thoughts about him, expresses what he feels blatantly and is ‘ruthless’ in a sense. 
He is humorous, understanding and also kind deep down. He isn’t like many typical high school male MCs and is extremely badassespecially his methods of communication. He just goes about telling people what he truly feels and is hella smooth with his speeches and characteristic also, to be frank none of the characters are very ‘typical’




The female MC (new waifu Bunny Senpai) on the other hand is matured, cute and loveable.

She is very different from the male MC as she on the other hand is a famous celebrity on hiatus and no one really knows anything about her.


The anime is very intriguing because it implements it’s own theories like Steins Gate.

Adolescence Syndrome in the context of this anime explains the things we face in high school, more specifically the negative things like getting cyber bullied or having no friends and putting those mental negativity into physical negativity like getting cyber bullied and end up being injured physically.


A spoiler example would be Bunny Girl Senpai. Her fame had begun to interrupt her life and she cannot go about anywhere without being recognised and this had left her to dream of being in a place where no one recognised her.


This has led her to go on hiatus from her career but slowly people began to not notice her to the point where she can’t even be seen or remembered by others except the male MC as well as certain other characters (not gonna spoil)

And apparently, those characters also eventually forget her after sleeping. The theories involved were definitely misused but still somehow plotted to make sense theoretically. Bunny Girl (Sakurajima Mai) was apparently a ‘part’ of the atmosphere, put blatantly.. Unnoticeable. A strong emotion was needed to override the atmosphere, to create a reason for Mai’s existence in the unconscious ignorance of others which makes up the atmosphere.


The anime carries on, with other misused but theoretically relatable theories for other incidents that happen after the Adolescence Syndrome incident. It’s very intriguing and will definitely get you craving for more.


Bunny Girl can at times be pretty cliche but that’s all part of developing the romance in this anime.


Honestly, the romance in here is undeniably one of the best. It doesn’t jump straight to the two MCs liking each other. The romance was matured, slow and developed. It emphasises the gaps between their characteristics and how they actually fit together perfectly, one being a rascal and the other one matured.

I really love seeing them together and well, don’t blame me for wishing a relationship like theirs.

The male MC didn’t immediately force her into a relationship and took it slow. He showed her how much he cared and eventually confesses, this provided much development for their relationship and I love it. 


Their romance then develops even more further up the anime and hell, I’m so jealous of them right now :/

The anime is also filled with very good development from every episode to the next and just very captivating, entertaining and good!



The plot is a hidden gem and taught me to never judge an anime by its cover.



As expected of ABC animation / Cloverworks, the art style was great as always. Bunny Girl Senpai was hot and extremely pretty. The imouto was cute and everything fit perfectly. Bunny Girl Senpai (Mai)’s character design was extremely cute and maybe abit erotic because she looks like a bunny, has a button nose and also bunny phone casing hair clip (accessories) basically and that is just lovely! The adaption was also extremely good!


The ED and OP fit perfectly with the animations for the ED always changing. And since the first episode did not really have a strict focus yet and was more of an intro, THE ED WAS SUNG BY ALL THE FEMALE MAIN CHARACTERS HOLY SHIT!!!  The concept of that is AMAZING and I loved it!



The voice acting was great, I don’t recognise the voice actors but they suit their characters to a T. Bunny Senpai has a mature tone and MC has a boring (idgaf) tone that fits with his persona and also his inner self very well.

Bare in mind this review is my personal opinion and is based on the first 3 episodes of the anime and thus there's lots of potential for this opinion to change.
I stumbled across this series with its standard long light novel title with a bunny girl plastered as the main image and thought I was in for a generic fanservice/moe style show with generic cardboard cut out MC getting his lucky pervert moments etcetera. I was pleasantly surprised that this isn't the case, and that it's quite the opposite with the story being more character based and quite well thought out.
Story-
Avoiding just giving a synopsisthe story stands out to me as a concept in general. Stumbling across an upperclassman in a bunny girl outfit in a library because she's disappearing from existence and wants to know when people can see her is one of the more bizarre brainchilds I've come across and I think thus far it's been quite fascinating, with certain scenes leaving me almost feeling shock and other emotions along with the characters. There's a strong psychological element, seeing how the different scenarios effect the characters and how they overcome each task, presented in a unique way to keep the story engaging.


Art-


I believe the art for the series although not standout is of a very good quality, there's no 'spot the MC' syndrome and there's enough variance in the appearance of all characters (not just the main focused characters) whereby its obvious some effort has been put into it.


Sound-


The quality and usage of the BGM in the show thus far I feel contributes dramatically to the whole feel and atmosphere (pardon the pun) of the show, and the lack thereof also, with ambient noise such as people speaking amongst themselves or air conditioning helping to set the scene and help viewers ground themselves in the story.


Characters- *incredibly minor menial spoilers here*


The characters in the show are what stands out, the way our main character is introduced to us for example, as a guy who keeps his head down and believes 'fighting the atmosphere is pointless' after a negative event in his life, to then have him build as a character over the course of the next two episodes through different experiences and contradict said message and fight the aforementioned atmosphere for the sake of another. The portrayal of a side character in the girlfriend of one of his friends telling him to stay away to save her and his friend's reputation, presenting a realistic look on ostracisation in school environments. The relationship between Sakuta and Mai is a big highlight, the way they bounce off of one another with his perverted yet sarcastic sense of humour and her attempts at acting grownup and act as if it isn't an issue.


Enjoyment-


So far I am thoroughly enjoying the show, and it's been the highlight of the season thus far personally, having me waiting with baited breath for each episode.


Overall-


To summarise this show surprised me, I believe the psychological element of the show is fascinating and the characters are very well built, would definitely recommend.

One of the best anime of recent seasons for sure. Don't judge an anime by its cover art though, seriously. I almost didn't watch this show because I thought it would have been another high school ecchi romantic comedy with no backbone of a plot. I was 100% wrong and so glad it turned out differently. This show came out of nowhere and blew all expectations (at least for me) out of the water. Definitely recommend that people watch. The story is strong and the characters are stronger. You find yourself really caring for these characters and their livelihood, which isn't a rare thing tofeel for characters of a show, but I'm an emotional person and I found myself in love with them. Over time I loved being familiar with the characters and their little habits and speech patterns. It was a fun ride.

Basically what I wanted from the Monogatari series.

Honestly though, do not be fooled by the cover art, this anime is great and is the best anime this season. Easily one of my top 15 animes now.
