I am being nothing short of truthful when I say that Bunny Girl Senpai is the best anime of the fall 2018 season for me; and by that I mean the best by a very long way.
I saw this anime on the list of upcoming anime around the first couple of days it was put on MAL back around the beginning of September. There was almost no information on it whatsoever. However simply by looking at the cover art for the series and the title I thought to myself that it would be the kind of anime for me to watch occasionally as a guiltypleasure. I mean the premise is a good looking girl in a bunny outfit, it only makes sense, right? But never have I so misjudged an anime before. I completely forgot that I added it to my to watch list until it suddenly popped up as a notification the day it started airing. Of course I was curious so I checked it out as intended. I also held back writing a review at first until now, when around half the episodes of the series are out. This was just to make sure I believed the series would stay consistently good. So with all that said:


I love the series. Now as aforementioned I was curious about this anime. Over the recent few years romance has slowly crept up and become one of, if not my favourite genre of anime. So naturally seeing this as a tag for a show that looked the way it did was intriguing to me. However after watching the series you can see that the tag is very much appropriate as it is very much a romance based anime, and a good one at that. One of the biggest complaints by people in regards to many romance anime especially is the idea of an extremely dense protagonist. There are many romance anime where the protagonist is extremely dense towards the love advances of the females within the anime. I was therefore really worried about this going into the anime, given my first impressions before starting. However again, I've never been so wrong. Sakuta is one of my favourite MC's in recent times. Sakuta knows what he wants, and he goes for it. He's extremely sarcastic and I love that. As I said, Sakuta pushes for the romance he wants and he's willing to fight for it. He's a nice and caring guy, whilst giving off a sarcastic and nonchalant impression. Therefore he's an actual relatable protagonist for me. I love that, because I often dislike and can't relate to the main character. 

In addition to this, the other main character, Mai Sakurajima, is to the same effect. She is also equally sarcastic and nonchalant about things. This is great as it means that the conversations which often happen between the two main characters are both comedic and enjoyable. The chemistry which they both have due to this being the case is what makes their budding romance so enjoyable to witness and to see grow over time. While Mai simply starts off as an extremely attractive girl in the perverted view of Sakuta, she slowly becomes so much more to him over time until he is willing to fight in many ways for her and what they have between them.


There is also a twist to the anime which entices me even more. Due to how I originally assumed the anime was going to be, I assumed that the idea of 'Puberty/Adolescence Syndrome' was simply going to be shoved into the plot to give an excuse to do things such as put Mai in the bunny costume. Therefore assuming it was going to be used for fan-service like that I thought nothing of it. However it actually is a very important and interesting dynamic to the series. To me, romance anime needs an important, unique dynamic like this. There is a lot of romance anime out there, and so something is needed to make a series with this tag stand out. Adolescence Syndrome is what that is for me in this case. It forms and drives the story, as well as putting the characters through situations which really builds and makes them understand their relationships with those around them. This mixed with it also having reference to ideas presented within quantum mechanics such as quantum entanglement and Laplace's Demon really settle it for me. 


I think overall this turned out to be one of the biggest shocks I've gotten from an anime in terms of how I perceived it was going to be versus how it turned out; and I mean that in the most positive sense possible. It's a story of romance and the forming and strengthening of relationships whilst going through the struggles of puberty. For CloverWorks to have taken a concept this open and simple and have it be expanded upon and made great to this extent is truly what I love about this show. 

Fall 2018 has been a phenomenal season for anime, and many great and enjoyable series have aired. However for me none could beat out Bunny Girl Senpai. Many people are now discovering this too and I'm simply glad to see it getting all the love and attention I believe it deserves. Oh, and both the opening and ending are both extremely good. Just an added bonus overall.


If you love romance anime with an element of mystery and a cast of enjoyable, sarcastic characters, then this is most definitely the anime I would recommend to you.

Have you ever watched something that is a literal pile of trash, no matter what angle you look at it from, and still somewhat enjoyed it? That's this anime.
Every fan of this show seems to think that the only feasible reason someone could possibly dislike this show is that the science used to explain what's happening is complete illogical bullshit. Spoiler alert: that's not why people hate this show.
Let's start with the worst part of the show by far: characters. Sakuta is a combination of the worst parts of Hachiman and Araragi, which is quite ironic since this is the most blatant ripoff of theMonogatari franchise to ever be conceived. Sakuta is an antisocial loser, who also happens to be an omnipotent deity that can solve any plausible problem plaguing any member of the cast by simply existing. Basically, he's just every cancerous LN trope combined into one character, masked by the Hachiman brand of relatability. The viewer is supposed to look at this empty, two-dimensional sack of shit and think, "Hey! That could be me! Man, this is such a great and relatable show." Sakuta is the Kirito of school romcoms. 


The rest of the characters don't happen to be much better. Unlike the two-dimensional Sakuta, every single girl in this show is one-dimensional. Legitimately every single character who has an arc exists solely for the purpose of her arc. Once their arc is gone, they proceed to fade in and out of existence. Mai becomes waifu-bait with no purpose or motivations, that short haired girl talks to Sakuta like twice just so that the viewer doesn't think she's dead or something, and Futaba goes back to explaining her insanely stupid scientific theories. The only character that actually exists outside of her arc is the incest bait sister, but that's only because her arc is last in the season and the viewer needs to know she exists before then.


The plot itself is mostly fine. It's just a copy paste of the Monogatari ~3 episode arc per girl. Except, instead of Araragi actually doing something interesting or cool, our god Sakuta descends and solves the arc's problem by using his poorly written light novel main character powers. In Monogatari, Araragi nearly never directly solves a character's problems. Instead, he assists the characters to overcome their problems themselves, recognize their own faults, etc. "People have to save themselves. One person saving another is impossible." But no, Hajime Kamoshida can't even plagiarize correctly. Sakuta literally fixes every problem himself and then the girls magically feel better once their problems are gone. Remember when that stacked up against Hachiman and was a focus of that show's plot? Once again, just as with the characters, good writing of any kind is sacrificed in favor of pandering to the average viewer.


EDIT: After some consideration, I've decided that it's reasonably fair to say that Bunny Girl plagiarizes Monogatari. Kaede's usage of third-person pronouns (referring to herself by her own name) is used in the exact same way with the exact same purpose as it is used with Sengoku (kinda hard to articulate this without spoilers). There are full, straight up conversations that are exactly the same between the series, and that happen in the exact same context. The prime example of this is the 6th episode of both this show and Bakemonogatari. Scroll to about 8:40 in Bake, and then to about 2:10 in this show of the 6th episode. If that's not plagiarism, I don't know what is. Furthermore, as I saw another reviewer point out, the whole bunny girl thing that serves literally no purpose in the show whatsoever can be viewed as a copy of the animal motifs that are ever-present in Monogatari. On the other hand, you can even take the very characters and link a lot of them between the two shows: 


Sakuta = Araragi: the classic generic LN protagonist whose main purpose is to help/save every character he meets. Obviously, Araragi is a complex, well-written, and overall good character, while Sakuta is none of those, but I digress. 

Mai = Senjougahara: tsundere main girl that mostly acts dere towards the MC (this may seem like a bit of a stretch, but bear with me).

Futaba = Hanekawa: one of the MC's best friends, wear glasses and is smart. 

Nodoka = Kanbaru: main girl's sister/has a sister-like relationship with her. Both of their arcs focus on their conflict with their big sister character. 

Kaede = Sengoku: little sister/little sister type character to the MC. Both are victims of bullying, which their arcs focus on (Nadeko's first arc). The events of Nadeko Medusa and Hitagi End are also similar to Kaede's arc (aforementioned third-person pronoun usage being an indication of a spoiler that I will not be saying). 

Koga is... also surprisingly similar to Nadeko. Once again, you've got the whole bullying thing playing a part in the arc and they both focus excessively on their appearance/behavior in order to be popular/fit in.


You can argue that a lot of these are common tropes, and they indeed are. But when there are conversations that are nearly word for word the same, and when you can draw a parallel between every single relevant character in one show to another, I see it as fair game to call this plagiarism. I mean, nearly every part of Bunny Girl can be found in Monogatari. END EDIT


Now, everyone's favorite part to criticize: the asinine metaphysics. Simply put, they just don't make sense. This show's scientific explanations are like watching Ben Shapiro debate someone. You just get spammed with a metric ton of information that doesn't really flow logically whatsoever, but hey, it sounds smart, so it must make sense. Basically, every single "scientific" explanation goes like this:


Kirito: "I am experiencing a supernatural phenomenon"

Futaba: "*relatively popular scientific concept that might be somewhat related to the supernatural phenomenon*"

Kirito: "Huh?"

Futaba: "*wall of text*" 

Kirito: "Oh ok"


Art and music: pretty good. Nothing to say here.


Now you might be thinking: how could I possibly give this show a 6/10 after everything I've said? yeah idk lol the show was pretty fun to watch


Final verdict:

Just go watch Monogatari instead.

[5.0/10]
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________
A blasé boy stands on a bridge, overlooking the ocean. Licentious thoughts pervade his mind, eager to be breathed to life, articulated so nonchalantly to whatever girl latches onto him. The aggressive one; the pariah at school who is spoken about in hushed voices that dart in and out of student’s mouths, settling at the breach between tact and uncivility. The boy views himself as an outsider and relates to this pariah, her plight is his own and due to that, he feels indebted to her. An ethereal toll which he must pay in order to regain a semblance of self-worth. But this outsider--this vagabond--edgingalong her school life eager to not make an impression on anyone, reveals herself as a lost, despondent figure who must retain a steely resolve, as any weakness would be immediately exploited and abused by the ones who have shunned her prior. This absence from reality; this vanished being, incapable of making an impression due to her affliction, is everything the boy needs. And he must save her. 


From there, a cascade of style erupts at the audience. A heterogeneous artistic smear across the pragmatic industry, transgressing norms whilst simultaneously accepting them, indulging in them and acquiescing to a standard that is so easy to punch through. A blithely swipe at normativity through the perspective of someone bored, sardonic, and fatigued by the constant battle against the restrictions, yet excited at the notion of being an erudite voice in the sea of retrograde production. What a perspicacious voice; what an apogee of style; what abrasive and caustic, annoying, biting, frames which flash between purpose and nonsense! An artifice of subversion and solipsism and hedonistic virtue. 


But enough about Monogatari.


Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai is a Light Novel adaptation by A-1 Studios’ subsidiary, Cloverworks. It attempts to interpret puberty as fantastical phenomena, hinged on emotion and hormones, which causes young adults to be afflicted by peculiar maladies. Similarly to Monogatari, Bunny Girl features a protagonist who is positively flooded with female archetypes. Each one struck by this sickness and each one in desperate need to be saved. And of course, Sakuta, our protagonist, does his best to aid all these poor, helpless, idiosyncratic, feeble, powerless women. More tepid wish-fulfillment than its sources of inspiration, but as a result, far less engaging in general. 


It seems as though the writer wanted to create a more mainstream, acceptable product while inhabiting those same ideas which brought so much energy to Monogatari. Instead, the misogyny remains but the interest disappears, as none of the artistic flourishes exist any longer. Shinbo’s eccentric dynamism isn’t there to give the unorthodox structure and profoundly witty and playful dialogue an arena to swell within. It all dissipates into mediocrity. Vibrant, piercing backgrounds turn into CG meshes with myopic gradients. Little to no shading exists at any one time, creating flat, innocuous scenery. An insipid grain of banalness infuses with what’s presented; a lack of portentousness and hedonism which made its inspiration so memorable creates only the mundane.


Bunny Girl lampshades cliché for only so long until it gives in and buckles under the weight of its production. Our ephemeral time spent with these characters feels even shorter once the final credits roll and they become nothing but fleeting thoughts and concepts. Threadbare metaphysics are mentioned to justify the ailments and, unfortunately, this misguided scientific slant is extraordinarily detrimental to any semblance of verisimilitude the series sought to create. The implementation of quantum mechanics was equally groan-worthy, as misunderstood explanations had a negative, ramifying effect on the rest of the series. Considering the definitions provided, we are left in a more frustrated state than we were when the phenomena were just that: phenomena. 


Not all is bad in the world of Bunny Girls and obsessive sisters, though, as the first arc did well to ease us into the structure of the series. The relationship between Sakuta and Mai was, if anything, cute. Due to the series’ more restrained approach towards the harem elements which it was inspired by, their relationship could play out convincingly enough as to not feel dissonant from the rest of the show’s tone. And while I wouldn’t classify it as funny, Bunny Girl has enough permeating wit that some of the interactions felt borderline inspired. Long train rides full of stodgy exposition became bearable due to the nature of the script and how it used the prosaic nature of its acerbic characters to its benefit. 


I appreciated how Kaede’s (Sakuta’s little sister) story starts in medias res, as we are treated to continuous revelations about what she went through and why exactly she’s such a shut-in cliché. While the explanation isn’t necessarily all too surprising and her arc is floundered by laconic and rushed melodrama, the standouts did particularly well.  Sakuta’s care for his little sister created for one of the show’s more deceptively detailed sequences, as it gave us an extended scene where they spend their final moments together before she relapses back into her old self. Her entire arc revolves around her going back to school after her affliction and while she struggled to get there during the day, they sneak into it at night together. It creates for a gripping kenopsia as they creep around the empty schoolyard—one we see many times throughout the series—and peak into her future classroom. The sense of dread hangs loosely in the air, and for once the series’ pithy observations take on a more artistic, expressive existence. 


Rascal is an easy watch, and that’s undoubtedly why it’s so popular and well regarded. The emotions are tangible, the plot is accessible, and the characters are smooth enough to digest without any need for interpretation or challenge. That’s not to diminish or belittle the series, but to examine why it isn’t just a facsimile of Monogatari. It sheds the weight of complex structure, characterization, and presentation in favor of a mainstream, safe, and maybe even relatable experience. There is no conniption to be had here; Bunny Girl isn’t heterodox or complicated. It’s essentially puberty: exaggerated, melodramatic, and sweaty, but far easier than what is initially expected.

--Review may contain spoilers--
Undoubtedly the best anime of Fall 2018, and probably one of the best in 2018, this anime much like Bakemonogatari and Oregairu, is about "Puberty Syndrome" - a supernatural phenomenon caused by instability and sensitivity during adolescence.
Story (10): Azusagawa Sakuta, a second year high-schooler, meets a senpai in a library and unexpectedly, dressed in a bunny girl costume. Sakuta notices that the everyone in the library except for himself was able to see her.  This senpai, also known as Sakurajima Mai, a famous celebrity, gradually becomes invisible and forgotten by people. Sakuta, who thinks this is "Puberty Syndrome" and has experiencedit before, decides to help her. And that's pretty much the summary of episode 1. The story is basically about Sakuta helping out people with "Puberty Syndrome" and reliving them from whatever instability they are having, thus ending the supernatural phenomenon they are having.


To me, this anime isn't just an anime, but a message as to how cruel our society has become, especially in high school. In real life, having instabilities during adolescence can cause serious mental issues and might lead to suicide. In every arc, the anime tells something about stuff that happen during adolescence. For example, isolation and fake rumor spreading in the first arc, anxiety in the third arc and the feeling of being constantly compared in the fourth arc. Almost every episode is relatable to someone who has difficulties in real life and I hope that viewers can change for the better.


Art (9): Don't have much to say for art. It's beautiful and something you'd expect to see in 2018.


Sound (9): Absolutely love the OP and ED. I enjoy them so much to the point where I might even replay them before watching/finish watching the anime.


Character (9): As an Oregairu fan, I absolutely love Sakuta's character. Much like Hachiman, he is a loner but is blunt and a savage, you'd just laugh at how straightforward he is. He doesn't care about the bad rumors about him in school and just lives the way he wants. The other characters are good too but I won't go much into them as it might spoil you.


Overall Enjoyment (9): Overall, this anime is perfect to end 2018 with. I'm super glad that someone created an anime with a mix of Bakemonogatari and Oregairu in it.

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai in Yume wo Minai, is one of the most commented anime of this season. And that does not surprise me, after all, it's an anime that attracts a lot of attention.
Story 7/10
The story of the Bunny, really does not have anything magnificent as some are saying. BUT, it is undeniably intriguing. The first episode is enough to catch anyone. The mystery that the anime introduces in the air in the first 10 minutes is really something that makes you watch the next episodes.
Art 8/10
The art of the bunny is flawless. It is not as chic as the artof other anime of the day. The art does very well what it proposes, as much in the design of the characters, as in the scenarios.


Sound 6/10


The sound of Bunny Girl is not something that attracts much attention. With the exception of OP and ED, one does not perceive the same emotion in the soundtrack. I do not say that the soundtrack is bad, on the contrary, the soundtrack is really good, BUT the direction fails to choose the appropriate moments of each one.


Character 9/10


Without doubt the best point of the Bunny. The characters are realistic, well-developed, engaging and consistent. The dialogues are incredible because the characters have minimal notion of how to speak as a human being. With this, the characters become full of life.


Enjoyment 8/10


Bunny Girl is the classic anime, where you expect it to be something generic, and this completely surprises you. It manages to be good to both the audience who wants to have fun, both for the audience they want to analyze and to try to get messages from it.


Overall 8/10


This is an anime that has great potential to be the best of the season and perhaps the year. It can be a subjective and objective anime at the same time, it has complex explanations of physics for the events and, even then, you can understand with a more lay explanation. So I'll give my vote of confidence to Bunny Girl, and I really believe it will be the best anime this season.

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai has been noted as if Monogatari and Oregairu had a love child...LA agrees with this and better yet, it's an anime that has it's own flair and charm to it to make it unique to it's contemporaries.
Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is about Puberty Syndrome, where abnormal experiences in teenagers are caused by instability where it affects many of the characters in this anime, think of it as a reverse, harsher Chunnibyou syndrome in which it's supernatural elements come intentionally or unintentionally real. Sakuta Azusagawa voiced by KaitoIshikawa has such a puberty syndrome of having a huge scar on his chest, but when he comes across his senior wearing a bunny costume in public, well we find out that this senior named Mai Sakurajima voiced by Asami Seto ALSO has Puberty Syndrome and thus Sakuta tries to cure Mai of her puberty syndrome and later on...several other girls with differing puberty syndromes whilst trying to have a relationship with Mai. Now the premise itself feels VERY much like a Monogatari series formula arcs, just less complicated, a stoic pervert of a main character tries to save girls with their supernatural problems...yeah...but again Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai has it's own uniqueness to it, not only because it's less complicated to Monogatari series (which is actually a good thing), but because Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is a character focused anime, we get to know these characters and how the puberty syndrome affects them ad then quickly we get invested in them and then..your hooked into not only their personalities and characters but how the puberty syndrome's supernatural element ties everything together into making great character development towards the main cast, heck even after their character arcs ended they have some to lot of relevance to the next character arc sometimes!. Why Oregairu is involved in this comparison, Mai and Sakuta are VERY similar in personalities to Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru.'s Yukino Yukinoshita and Hachiman Hikigaya respectively, heck Nao Touyama voices a character that has a crush to their respective protagonist's series!. But the comparison to Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru. stops there. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is by all accounts a character focused anime and not only strives but excels in this front, getting us invested in their characters, relationships and how intrinsic the supernatural element to each of the girls dilemma is tied to to their character development, allowing the character development to be further developed.


Character wise, due to the greatly investable characters, they at first land in the stereotypical but over their character arcs, they become evolving characters that also break their own stereotypes as well. Though Sakuta is probably the only one to NOT break this mold but nonetheless, Mai is the stoic kuudere type of character but with her character focused arc, she opens up expectedly but she has her own quirkiness to her, mainly because of her not taking Sakuta's shit and is a brilliant comparison to Sakuta's personality, really they were kinda meant to be together. Tomoe Koga voiced by Nao Touyama is Sakuta's junior and is the typical genki character yet she is much more complicated than being genki, as she has something with her desires of having lots of friends but needing to sacrifice her previous personality in order to do it. Rio Futaba voiced by Atsumi Tanezaki, a friend of Sakuta and is the main exposition fairy for the supernatural stuff that happens, but she has a fear of "being herself"...or just opening up and that gets her into trouble, Nodoka Toyohama voiced by Maaya Uchida, a popular idol but her having links to Mai, mainly of her having rivalry towards her and finally Sakuta's little sister Kaede voiced by Yurika Kubo, being emotionally scarred from cyber bullying caused her puberty syndrome to make her cut herself unintentionally but because of this she locked herself in her house and never left, she is your typical genki little sister but her puberty syndrome is what makes her somewhat unique to her archetype and probably gave off one of the more relatable and heartwarming and heartwrecking moments at the same time. Through this, LA's favourite character easily became......Mai, LA couldn't help it, and no it's not by default due to her increased screentime, it was her personality and her character development and sassy banter with Sakuta helped the majority of the time, Tomoe Koga and Rio Futuba was a close second and third.


Though Sakuta really doesn't change his personality or have any sort of backstory in the anime, it's through his interactions with the other characters that we kinda see his subtle hints of a backstory and what he's going through, he IS the narrative focus through the majority of the anime so this is a given really. The best examples of him developing along with the girl's character arc in question would be Mai's, Rio's and Kaede's.


Nonetheless Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai does excellently with it's characters, not only through their relationships with Sakuta but also be it outside of Sakuta as well as the greatly done character development of each of the character arcs given making each character much more multilayered and multifaceted characters breaking out of their stereotypes that you just can't help but get invested in their dilemma's and thus you get sucked into the plot even more.


On speaking of Rio Futaba, Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai does get the distinction of trying to explain the supernatural elements using Futaba going into quantum physics and whatnot, but all things considering, it kinda wasn't needed, as we the audience knows of the actions that produced the reaction of the character with the puberty syndrome in question and how it was cured through emotional means, quantum physics explanation wasn't needed, though Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai seems to mostly handwave it's own explanations either way. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai's flaws a VERY small to say the least even to the point of them being nitpicks than anything else, like Sakuta's intentional pervertedness being well intentional, fanservice is light to say the least, more or less characters dressing up in the most fanservice we get and with shipping it's there as well and finally would be how formulaic the anime is, but that's to be expected from a character focused arc format of an anime that it is.


In terms of animation, well CloverWorks seemed to slapped themselves out of their funk since Persona 5 the Animation, as the animation done by them is leagues above their previous work, detailed characters and beautiful backgrounds with little to no derps AT ALL. What can LA say, LA is impressed. Great and exotic character designs and good backgrounding and for being an anime that is alot more talkative than action-like, well maybe that's why CloverWorks excelled in it's animation because of it, nonetheless CloverWorks, LA is impressed, why couldn't you do the same level of animation for Persona 5?


In terms of voice work, LA freakin' loved this voice cast, Asami Seto did a great job as Mai, being a sassy stoic kuudere, Nao Touyama being Nao Touyama as in ALL the genki and LA loved her performance as Tomoe, Atsumi Tanezaki also somewhat channeling Asami Seto's stoicness and deadpaness as Rio, Maaya Uchida as Nodoka being a tsundere and finally Yurika Kubo doing the entire little sister scthick without being annoying (LA might be the rare few that felt this) showing off her range from outright moe to the complete opposite of a mature cadence. Seriously this voice cast was amazing.


Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai's ending was also handled pretty well too, as it did give off something of an open ended finale especially concerning Sakuta and Kaede but it tied off most of the plotlines involving Kaede though oddly Sakuta weirdly got the spotlight though it was more or less Sakuta getting past the situation that got him extremely depressed but nonetheless it was actually fine in a ways seeing things from his perspective as Kaede's older brother and all. All in all as much as the final arc did involve Kaede, it had as much to do with Sakuta as well and the ending was executed quite well getting the main cast involved and tying up any loose ends of the plot it had. 


Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai managed to be unique with it's contemporaries like Oregariu, the Monogatari series by the use of it's unique characters and effectively using it's supernatural element to develop their characters and make them investable as a result. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai was by far LA's Top 3 animes heck maybe LA's favourite anime of Fall 2018 and well deserves it's praise, great plot, great investable characters, detailed and great animation along with an amazing voice cast...what else can LA say?


Mai is best girl!

This is an early review made on episode 4. I usually don't do those, and I will change it by episode 12 if the show proves me wrong. So if you're in the future reading this just know that I was right.
 Bunny Girl is a story made by someone who probably read Bakemonogatari and Haruhi, really liked it, tried to write a story just like those two, and decided to copy everything down to the tiniest detail. And that would be great if not for one small mistake: they copied everything down to the tiniest detail in the surface level, but they never understoodwhy those structures and tropes where there, meaning that everything in Bunny Girl, while looking really good on the surface, is completely shallow on the most basic analysis.\n
 Yes, it has that quirky dialogue, but it is devoid of meaning and just wastes time.\n
 Yes, it has sci-fi, but it will tramp over it with the power of love and sunshine.\n
 Yes, it has supernatural events that will act as puzzles for the MC to solve as he grows as a person and helps the girls around him grow as well, but they are all shallow and represent nothing in symbolism to the story and only exist because that's how it went in Bakemonogatari and so they have to do it as well.\n
 Just to point out how much this is a carbon copy of Bake, the MC, who is a loner and hated by everyone, had a supernatural event happen to him some time ago which changed his life forever. After that, a girl he really cares about who helped him overcome it also falls to similar event, and he has to protect her. This all happened before the story starts. The real plot begins when the author accidentally meets and finds out about his main love interest's supernatural case and helps her overcome it. They fall madly in love, but he has to keep pursuing his harem of girls with problems that he must solve, with the second one being a younger girl who accidentally brings him into a loop which she can't solve herself.\n\n
  If I had to put Bunny Girl into two words it would be "wasted potential". \n
 By all means, watch the first episode. If you liked the atmosphere, go on and keep watching it. It is actually entertaining. But you will have to deal with the constant thought of "how much better this could be if just...".

I'll keep this short and not-so-sweet: Bunny Girl Senpai is the worst anime I've seen after School Days.
Story: It's s**t. They tried to copy the masterful storytelling of the Monogatari series but failed and it ended up being a clusterf**k. Some of the material - especially the quantum physics part - is so cringy that it could go on r/iamverysmart.
Art: Boooooring and generic like every generic anime out there. The character designs weren't even appealing. Every time Mai appeared on screen I felt like punching her face.
Sound: Average at best. The opening works better as a meme: "KIMI NO GEI KIMI NO GEI UWU"
Character: Thisis what I hated the most. The MC, not-Araragi-kun, isn't lovable but instead is an unabashed pervert. The main girl, not-Senjougahara, is annoying in every way: looks, voice, personality. In a way she's perfect for the MC but whatever. I've never truly hated a character like this before. Mai "not-Hitagi-Senjougahara" Sakurajima is the worst anime girl of 2018 and you can't change my mind. The rest of the girls weren't even worth remembering. Fine, I don't expect something like the toothbrush scene but the characters weren't even memorable.\n\n
Enjoyment: I would give a 0 if I could. I cringed all the way through and I know, I really must hate myself a lot to have sat through the entirety of this anime.\n\n
Overall, Bunny Girl Senpai is the worst anime of 2018 imo. I strongly recommend that you do not watch it. If you want a good story, watch the Monogatari series. If you have a fetish for bunny suits then watching h****i is more productive than watching this trainwreck of an anime.

Bunny Girl Senpai is a textbook example of never judge a book by its cover. From initial expection, it would seem to be nothing more than a typical ecchi anime featuring a dim witted protagonist surrounded by a harem of sexy girls clad in skimpy bunny suits. And you know what? I would have been completely ok with that. But after actually watching the anime, it becomes apparent that this anime offers something entirely different. Now is that special "something" going to please everyone? Well, based off of all of the love this anime has been receiving, it would seem that the majority of thisshow's audience would give a resounding yes. And for the most part, I'd agree.


Of course, that doesn't mean that this anime doesn't have its share of flaws.


Bunny Girl Senpai features a seemingly standard school setting. Sakuta is the protagonist of the story who's tasked with solving the problems of multiple girls. However, instead of these characters simply having typical teenage girl problems equipped with all of the drama that derives from these aforementioned issues, this anime adds a bit of a supernatural twist to the school drama genre. Dubbed "adolescence syndrome" by the anime, mysterious occurrences like the disappearance of one girl from the eyes and memories of the public or the spawning of a doppelganger of another girl coincide with the problems plaguing these characters. Each occurrence of adolescence syndrome almost perfectly embodies the type of obstacle being faced, and I personally believe that the inclusion of this supernatural element really increases the quality and intrigue of the anime. 


Unfortunately, I've noticed that it does seem to have a downside.


While an interesting concept, adolescence syndrome itself is never fully fleshed out. Although  each case of the syndrome is usually explained quite well through science or something to Sakuta by his intelligent friend Rio Futaba, the entire concept itself and why it exists in this universe is left vague. Of course, this would be completely inconsequential if this was a fantasy anime where magic and mystery were the norm. But the creators portray this show as something grounded in reality where the supernatural elements can be explained through logic and reason. And for me personally, that just doesn't quite work. Regardless, adolescence syndrome is still a fun addition to this anime that gives it a bit more flare. 


To give you a better understanding about what this anime's all about, I'd say that it's a sort of love child between OreGairu and The Monogatari Series. Bunny Girl Senpai has quite a few similarities to both of these anime, but I'm not here to compare and contrast these series. I will say, however, that Bunny Girl Senpai does one thing marginally better then the other two. And that would be its portrayal and execution of the relationship between its two protagonists. 


The first girl featured in this anime is none other than the titular bunny girl senpai herself, Mai. And as we seasoned anime veterans know, the first girl usually ends up as the main love interest for the protagonist. And in this case, I couldn't be happier. Mai is our first introduction to adolescence syndrome as we soon learn that more and more people are beginning to forget about her existence as time goes on. I won't spoil what exactly causes this phenomenon, but I will say that it stems from Mai's experiences in the modeling industry. Anyway, she starts to spend time with Sakuta, who also had a nasty experience with adolescence syndrome that gets properly explained near the end of the anime. And let me tell you, the highlight of Bunny Girl Senpai for me would definitely be the interactions that these two characters have. They have some great conversations that range from super cute to downright hilarious, and what Sakuta does for Mai at the end of episode three has to go down as one of the greatest moments of this anime season for me. Bunny Girl Senpai is a rare anime where the two protagonists actually end up as a couple early on in the show, and unlike the Monogatari Series, the main girl doesn't get completely shafted after she ends up with the hero. Mai plays an important and supportive role towards Sakuta throughout the entire anime, and for me is simply a very strong female lead.


After the conclusion of Mai's arc, the anime presents us with four more girls, each with their own character arc, suffering from adolescence syndrome that Sakuta goes out of his way to help out. And thankfully, each of these arcs feature great character interactions and are good in their own right. Like in Mai's segment, Sakuta has some memorable moments in Koga's arc, and Koga herself goes through some nice development throughout the few episodes that she's featured in. Futaba's arc was interesting, and although the imouto of Mai had the weakest arc in my opinion, it had some great moments featuring Mai herself. The final arc of the anime covers Kaede, the beloved panda suit wearing imouto of Sakuta. I actually felt the most emotion during her arc and thought it was a great way to conclude the anime. But like everything else with this show it seems, there was a problem with this. And that would be cramming five different arcs in a thirteen episode anime. Now none of the arcs felt rushed or lacking despite the minimal time they had to work with. It's just that the anime could have been a little more centered with either fewer arcs or more episodes.


Visually speaking, I felt that this anime left a little more to be desired. It's definitely not bad, but the artistic quality just feels a little lacking to me. The soundtrack is good, and the opening theme song is a nice tune that contains a nice dose of uwu. Voice actors do a nice job delivering lines, and I think that Kaede's seiyuu puts the most emotion into her role. My one complaint would be that while I liked Sakuta's voice actor, I feel like he could have put a bit more feeling into his part. I get that Sakuta is a nonchalant type of guy, but still. A bit more energy never hurt anyone, right?


Overall, while I wouldn't call this anime excellent by any sense of the word, it still ended up being quite the enjoyable show. The characters were fun, the scenarios were fun, and, well, it was simply a fun anime. Bunny Girl Senpai might not have introduced anything revolutionary to the anime medium, but it certainly won the hearts of many anime fans, and I'll admit that I too was swayed by its charm. I staunchly believe that this is an anime that will be remembered for seasons to come.

I honestly don't see where the hype for this series comes from.
Over 20+ years of watching anime and there's, if we're being honest here, nothing special about this anime at all.
The story line is dreadful.  It's a simple concept that is painfully dragged out over 13 episodes.  It was painful to watch but I wanted to complete the series, if for nothing more, so that I could write this review.  There is no reasoning presented for the visible wounds, a dearth of depth in telling any of the character's stories, no build to climax, and no clear resolution as to why anyonewas in their predicament.  As others have asked "Did a 13 year old write this?"


Characterization is non-existent. At no time did I ever feel connected to any of the characters.  No deeper inspection of the psyche or needs of them, their desires (besides the lust of a teenage boy), and no real bonding between them.  Every character looked like another cardboard cutout. 


The art is Fair - nothing to get excited about.  By the end of the series the artwork looks rushed.  As though even the artists were tired of these same characters.  As an example - look at the last hospital scene, when brother and sister are leaving, and you can literally see bad lines and coloring.



Overall - there are so many better anime series out there than this piece of junk.  This is like watching some of the horrible "filler" episodes in some popular anime titles.


Seriously... this one is pretty bad.

I know it is difficult to agree with someone who dislikes a show that appears to be objectively good and entertaining, in turn, it is easier to treat as pretentious or wannabe as in all cases, but my intention sincerely not that, I got bored from the same story always. 
I was impressed to see how it rained criticism about this anime, and obviously that made me suppose that it gives something to think about, something that does not happen to me long ago with an anime, so I decided to put the spoon, just to get rid of the doubt of how good thiswork is. 


Every time I see the genre "supernatural" I hope it is not by the use of the typical mediocre resource that the supernatural is only an alteration of reality, a temporal space paradox or anything else that arme a conflict or disadvantage that is responsible for covering the whole plot, to say it I can think of example "Your Name" with that "supernatural thing" that fucked reality and in turn, dramatized the lives of the protagonists and what mattered least was whether it had an explanation or not, not that I am bothered by the facilitation of progress, I only say that it is mediocre to resort to the supernatural for those reasons. 


In this case, the recourse of an invisible person is repeated, which coincidentally can only be seen by the protagonist. The supposed purpose of this does not need saying, but apparently so far, the anime does not do anything but fill almost the entire chapter with the standard boy and the girl related in a pseudo romantic antonym innovative but still does not stop look like Bakemonogatari (and obviously the wise person could not miss trying to give a logical explanation to the matter, but do not pay attention to him so I do not talk about him) 

I do not know if the secondary characters only serve to feed the mystery as expected, but I only hope that the anime will remember every two minutes that no one remembers who she is so that people with antegrade amnesia can also enjoy the anime , another thing that we all saw before. 

Normally I would tell me the cliches and topics but I already said that I got bored of the same story. 


In short, another anime in which the protagonist tries his best for a girl, had the opportunity to be original but chose to be one of the bunch full of things that everyone has seen before in a fiction.

For my part I leave it here, maybe I wait for the last episode to come out, so it saved me the irrelevant development of relationships between characters and burn my head recognizing cliches, enjoy the anime.


The review was written in English and that is not my language, if there are mistakes...

Teenage years. Yes, for me, my teenage years probably my best and worst years in my life. I was a very hyperactive and tomboy girl back then so I was very much have no sense of shame but because of those personalities, I developed a huge insecurity over those years just for my early adult years trying to fix them for me. Our social life were being judged by everyone back then with parents put their highest hope for us in those years. So, yeah... Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai or Bunny Girl Senpai for short is an anime revolving around AdolescenceSyndrome that took the stress and insecurity of a teenager into reality, making this anime very intriguing and yet, relatable for us.


The concept of Adolescence Syndrome is actually pretty simple. Think of some teenage problem that would come out of your brain and try to convey it into reality. But what makes Bunny Girl Senpai special is this anime made the explanation of these Adolescence Syndrome occurrences with more scientific explanations and a certain depth of lore or history behind those. I don't know why but I love that concept which made the show smarter from a simple premise of teenage problems. And because they were teenagers, adults often said they were just a bigger version of kids so the adults sometimes would not believe what they said including the occurrences of Adolescence Syndrome. This made teenagers must deal with Adolescence Syndrome by their own and that's partly why Sakuta is a great character.


In my opinion, the center of great character development of this anime came out from Sakuta. While still being himself, The Rascal wants to help anyone who developed Adolescence Syndrome just like Shoko-san did to him. He was driven by kindness offered by someone who actually believed in him but still retained his basic personality trait that is a rascal. He spoke out his perverted thoughts or everything in his mind bluntly but that's why Sakuta becoming a lovable character. He seemed like not hiding anything and made everyone around him love to share their problem with him. He is the kind of guy I really want to share my thoughts with. And while he is dubbed as a rascal, he is actually have a huge commitment in relationship. He even turned a girl down properly because his feelings towards Mai-san won't change even after that painfully repeated days *a sudden memory of eight repeated episodes came in*. He is an embodiment of how a harem light novel protagonist should act while facing so many girls at the same time. His commitment is one of a kind and I love him for that.


Not just that, I would like to say that Sakuta and Mai-san's relationship development could be the cutest and most natural romance development in this season and probably in this year. They were actually acting step by step and in a perfect pace. Those made every moment of their relationship development cute and made me squirm every time they showed some kind of small development.


How about the animation? I really like this anime's animation as I could see how much the animator poured their love in animating into this anime. What I really love about their animation is how they animate the expression of each characters which could make my heart skip a beat every time Mai-san blushes. With the addition of beautiful landscapes for the background, this anime is certainly a very good looking anime. As the first solo start for now standalone studio, CloverWorks who previously a sub-studio of A-1 Pictures, they certainly wanted to make their portfolio as good as possible with a very great debut that is Bunny Girl Senpai. Looking by how beautiful their animation is, I really could trust Cloverworks for adapting more anime in the future and really look forward for their future projects. Truly, a great way to start a reputation.


Then, let's talk about this anime's music and soundtrack. This anime has a huge advantage with the catchiest opening of this season with the song "Kimi no Sei" performed by the peggies. The song is ultimately catchy that every time the song begin, I know that you can't stop singing "kimi no sei... kimi no sei... kimi no sei de... watashi... UUUHHH..." and I think most of you unconsciously read that line with the song played inside your head. I guarantee that you would not want to skip the opening of this anime every time you watch an episode as this opening begin to seep into your head and keep repeating inside your head.


Overall, this anime has won many hearts including mine. Maybe, since this anime is already prepping itself for a movie sequel, the ending felt a little bit off but that's okay! We know that the movie is already on production and I really can't wait for the movie to solve one big question that surfaced in the very end.

Rascal does not dream of a Bunny Girl Senpai or lets just call it "Bunny girl" because I am not going to use that long name over and over again. 
First of all, if you are actually going to watch this show because of it's name, I hate to break it to you but this show has nothing to do with bunny girls. Its a bait. Yep! The writer baited you into watching something thats probably the anime of the year(atleast for me). 
Story: 9/10
The plot is actually pretty simple. A cheeky protagonist, Sakuta Asusagawa, helping out different girls in their problems. Problems known asPuberty syndrome. Now puberty syndrome itself means, "Abnormal experiences rumored on the internet to be caused by sensitivity and instability during adolescence". 

I really loved how they brought in different life problems that almost every teenager faces in this world. Problems varying from bullying to self harm and even changing yourself just for the sake of others to going through stress and depression. Teenagers go through so much in the school days and this show actually takes that concept and turns it into a supernatural-Quantum physics related story to make things interesting. Now I know what you might be thinking, "A guy helping out girls who are going through supernatural phenomenas? What is this? A new season for Monogatari?". Well to be honest yeah it does copy a little bit from Monogatari and a bit from Haruhi Suzumiya and from Oregairu as well. The best part is the writer took all these ideas and made something amazing which is not a trainwreck. The story itself is quite enjoyable and all those Quantum Physics/Mechanics refrences(dont worry business students, they actually explain those references) made it even great. 

In the end Sakuta just has to find all the solutions to the problems and the syndromes that his friends, sister and girlfriend is facing in order to live a peaceful life. One wrong move could cost him something big. 


Animation: 7/10 

The animation was actually pretty good in the start but it went downhill once the show started to bloom. Now I dont blame cloverworks for this because they decided to raise the budget of the movie(Sequel to this show) and dropped the budget of the show itself. It was a pretty good move to ensure that the movie turns out to be great because it contains the best arcs of the novels. Though I still dropped the ratings because I am sucker for animation and artstyle and it started to lack in the end and you can even notice how strange the facial expressions of the characters started to be. But alot of people will not mind this because the main focus of this show is on the story. 


Music: 8/10

The opening and the endings both are freaking gold. No, they are PLATINUM GOLD(A monogatari reference). I don't think I have even skipped both the op and ed once. The best thing about the openings and endings were that the Voice Actresses used to sing the op and ed of their respective arcs. I have no idea if there is much background music in this show, even if there is, its not noticeable. 


Characters: 8.5/10 (Bit of a spoiler)

      *Sakuta Asusagawa: The main male lead of Bunny girl and the rascal which the name of the show suggests. The whole story revolves around him and there is not much screen time for other characters apart from their respective arcs and apart from our bunny girl senpai. Sakuta for me was a cheeky guy but he is a normal guy, a student just like all of us. There is a limit to how much a person can take and even Sakuta had his limits and in the end he did bursted out. He helped out all his friends when they were going through the puberty syndrome and I wish I had a friend like him in real life. Sakuta is probably the male of the year for me.

      *Sakurajima Mai: The main female lead of the show and our very own Bunny girl senpai which the name of the show suggests. Guess the name is not a bait after all huh? No, it is. Mai is tsundere character that alot of people compare to Senjougahara from monogatari but she isn't even close to Senjougahara. The character designer was the same as Oregairu due to which people even compare her with Yukinon but again Mai senpai is fire while Yukinon was ice, they are so different. The only screentime she gets after her arc is all the romantic situations which the writer created. 

*Other Characters: All the other characters were briefly explained in their respective arc and we got to know alot about them due to their puberty syndrome. But every character had a little screen time once their arc ended which is why I'm not going indepth about the side characters. 


Enjoyment: 9/10

Now this show, even though I know it might seem to be a rip off of some of my favourite shows, it was still written by the author from one of my favorite show, "The pet girl of sakurasou". Personally I enjoyed this show alot. I enjoyed the heck out of it because how you could relate to some of the things in reality. It was just awe-inspiring. 


Personal statement:

Cyber bullying, self harm, dual personality, stress and depression now that is something that alot of writer dont even try to talk about. The show couldn't have been better for me as it was perfect just the way it is. An astounding protagonist with a tough life and teaching us all about how you should never give up. There is always a solution, doesn't matter how much time it takes, find the solution and solve the problem. At times you may feel down but you should always get back up and fix yourself because there are other people who need you. I can't wait for the movie and I am super hyped about it. 


I'll give it an overall rating of 9/10.

From episodes 1~3 it's a really interesting story and it makes you fall in love with the characters (mostly Bunny Senpai). You know the drill: girl is invisible, boy is the only one able to see her, they start to bond and he somehow wants to (and is able to??) stop the ~curse~ and she's visible again!!
Yes, all of that happens in the lapse of 3 episodes. This anime has 13 episodes. WHAT THE HELL HAPPENS IN THE REMAINING 10 EPISODES?!?!?!
I was already kinda skeptical before going to episode 4. I mean, it all moved SO fast... the romance (it was basically: episode 1 theymeet and find out about her "condition" -> episode 2 they spend the whole time together and trying to figure out how to reverse it/who else is able to see her -> episode 3 everything works out in the end), the resolution itself (it all happened in episode 3 and HONESTLY, it all felt like a series finale), the half-assed explanation as to what this syndrome is... But hey, I figured, I'm still in the beginning.


So in episode 4 they basically reintroduce an extra from episode 1 and they're like "remember that syndrome? this chick has it too, except hers is different" and the male MC is like "welp. guess i gotta help HER out now, then."


See, I didn't like this girl, I thought she was very lukewarm (personality-wise as well as plot-wise). And not just that, but she sort of became the focus for a while. I have a theory that every girl that shows up in the opening will inevitably have the puberty syndrome and alas, the ONLY one able to save them is... yep! MC-kun!


*sigh* this anime seems to be taking the turn I didn't want it to take. I thought it'd be mostly a comedy with some slight angst/drama but, well, apparently it is a HAREM.


So this is definitely not for me. If anyone watches the rest of this and it gets good, feel free to message me to talk about it. Otherwise, I'll just drop it.

Sakuta is like the most related character ever: he’s a male, he’s sarcastic, he breaths, he eats, he wears clothes, he even goes to school.  This man speaks to me on such a deep level.  Yo and that bunny girl be so real; she’s so realistic that she turns invisible, I remember when I turned invisible in high school, good times. And they’re dialogue together is so real that they literally talk about nothing.  10/10 show right here.  Real talk though, why do people like this show? I know I’m dumb, but I like to think I amsmart enough to get why this show is popular.  They do get that this show is just a harem right?  Regardless, here are my lose thoughts on this harem.


   To be frank, I only got threw five episodes of this harem.  So I know all the modern day Albert Einstein will be quick to say “you can’t judge a show only on a few episodes,” as if this statement is an argument and isn’t just admitting defeat and moving the goal post.  In any case, I will debunk this notion anyway via an example.  If a person was to go a restaurant and ordered a steak and the steak tasted terrible--the meat wasn’t fresh, it was microwaved, and covered in grease--what sane person would eat the whole steak and be like “now that I have completely finished my meal, I can say it was terrible.”  No, a normal person wouldn’t waste their time eating a terrible steak that the cooks clearly didn’t care enough to cook properly, so they would likely take a few bits and be done with it.  And it’s the same for anime.  Why would I waste my time watching a terrible show when I could just drop it and move on with my life?  And this notion that a show will get better is also ludicrous.  To bring the steak comparison back.  If I took two bits of this steak, why would I assume that the rest of the steak will taste any better?  It was cooked by the same chief; it was all cooked in the same kitchen with the same tools. Therefore, it is logical to assume that it will taste bad all around.  The same logic can be applied to anime.  Consequently, I’m gonna rip the first five episodes and rate the whole show because I know it isn’t gonna get any better.


   Episode one. Skimming through this episode one (to jog my memory), I kinda get why people might like this show.  This show has very shallow observations of reality that might confuse people into thinking this show is deep when it really isn’t.  For example, boring boy (Sakuta) says “everyone says ‘I’m bored’ or ‘isn’t there something more interesting out there lie Pet phrases.  But in reality, none of them are really looking for a change.”  The Breakfast Club called it wasn’t it’s script back.  But in all seriousness, lines like this never cease to make me roll my eyes.  It sounds super deep and philosophical, even though he is just making an observation to himself.  For example, I could look at a guy with a loud, expensive car and think to myself “only those with week perceptions of themselves and a hunger for the approval of others would waste their resources on such ostentatious possession.”  It is safe to say that that hypothetical example was pretentious and insulting to the viewer even.  I don’t need these pretentious monologues from this Eric Forman of a character to understand the concepts being presented.  The show would be so much more interesting if they didn’t waste so much time talking about the stuff happening in the show and left it up to us to figure it out.  Moreover, this would also make the show deeper because it would force the viewer to look deeper into each scenes to understand what is happening instead of having emo boy’s pretentious monologues.  And that was just one quote.0


   Surprisingly, the biggest insult of this episode (and by extension the whole show)  was not the CGI crowds--even though they were reason enough to drop the show.  Because, as I stated earlier, if the staff doesn’t care about their own show, why should I? With that being said, the actual biggest insult of the show was the utilization of the adolescent syndrome.  I get why the writes came up with this.  The syndrome is pretty much just a metaphysical way of showing the struggles of its characters.  So, it is pretty much the homunculi from the manga Homunculus, which is a manga I consider to be one of the best.  But the reason the homunculi are sick and the Adolescent syndrome is dumb all lies in how the show present the concepts.  Remember how I said the show would be better if it didn’t waste my time explaining things and just showed me what was happening and let me figure it out?  The same criticism applies to the syndrome as well, and boy does this show need to shut up.  Episode one wastes two minutes of screen time (which is a lot for an episode) dedicated to a scene were Eric and the Hermione looking girl talking about what is essentially nothing--referring to theorising about the adolescent syndrome.  And these scenes get worse; in later episodes, Hermione wastes even more off your time talking about quantum physics, with the time wasted bar reaching as high as five minutes in episode 4.  Homunculus also had scenes dedicated to Nakoshi and Ito trying to theorise what the homunculus are.  However, the presentations of both scenes couldn’t be more different.  In bunny girl, hermione’s explanations come off as info dumps, this feeling comes from how her theories never seem to be challenged--like the author expects us to take them as truth.  While in Homunculus, both Nakoshi and Ito have no idea what is going on, and we learn more from Nakoshi’s interactions with the homunculi more than any dialogue; on top of that, Ito does not even fully believe Nakoshi when he says he sees homunculi, which adds another layer of suspense to the mystery.  In Bunny girl, we get our answers too easily, which could all be solved by showing and not telling.  These scenes would be much better if they were scrapped for more scenes with bunny b!tch and MC just talking.


   The adolescent syndrome is not only explained to us in the most boring way possible, but it is also used for juvenile purposes.  This show is a harem, and how the harem lead finds his waifu’s is because he needs to white night them as they go through this “syndrome.”  The first thing in episode one is him encountering harem girl #1, bunny b!tch.  Her adolescent syndrome makes her invisible to people, except the white night can see her because the show needs to find a way for the protagonist to talk to her.  This is actually an easy fix: instead of having the MC meet her for the first time, have them be somewhat acquaintances beforehand.  Then the writers could make it like he’s jaded to her face therefore he can see her for who she really is or whatever.  It would be cory but objectively less arbitrary than how it is now, and it would utilize Sakuta’s established character traits. Because as it stands now, the show is Erased levels of arbitrary.  And I just want to state that that solution took me less time to come up with than it did for Harmony to explain Schrödinger’s cat fetish.


   Episode two introduced harem girl #2, and we got problems. If this show was to stop being so pretentious, get animation, get decent sound, and clean up the script, it could be a decent show.  But then I got reminded this show is a stupid harem at the end of the day, and it just had to introduce another girl.  If this show just focused on bunny b!tch, it could of been a pretty decent romance.  Keep the first three episodes pretty much how they are, except cut out all the pretentious fat, and fill it with fleshing out the established characters. Then make the rest of the show a real talk romance with trippy Tatami Galaxy style scarios happen to spice things up.  But harem girl #2 was so bad I had to drop this show.  She was introduced by kicking Mr. Protagonist in the butt: then proceed to feel bad, hunch over, and expect him to kick her back?  Am I the only one that thinks that is the dumbings thing I’ve ever seen?  Doesn’t these show’s have script editors?  How is it possible such a stupid, unfunny scene could get past so many incompetent people?  I’d be ashamed to have my name in the credits.


   Other than that asininity, the episode had some good elements to it.  And by good elements to it, I mean the scenes that just focus on bunny B!tch and Sakuta.  When it is just these two chatting, it is actually pretty cute.  This episode also utilized the syndrome in the way it should be used, which I greatly appreciated.  I loved how existential the show made bunny b!tch’s disappearance.  However, there are still thinks in this episode I think need to be cleaned up.  For one, just give me more scenes of them just talking.  I personally really like episodes that feel like 24 hour day in the life videos.  One of my favorite episodes of anime was the Panty & stocking episode where they just sat on the couch and complained for the whole episode.  And I think bunny b!tch could use more of that.  Also, I would like to see them not talking about the adolescent syndrome and bunny b!tch’s disappearance so literally.  If there was a spectrum of presentation of metaphoric storytelling with literality on one end and the abstractness on the other, Homunculus would be far into the abstract while Bunny B!tch is quite literal in how the characters talk about the syndrome and its implications on the characters life.  The show would do much better if the show was tastefully more on the abstract side of things.  How it stands now, the literal implications of bunny b!tch’s syndrom take up too much of her precious dialogue with Sakuta.  It would be of much benefit if the dialogue cut back; how it is now makes the characters struggles feel jaded to reality despite the concepts being real.  Overall, focus more on concepts rather than the literal. 


   I won’t talk much on episode three because I don’t feel like it, and I kinda liked it.  The over the top the confession seen actually made for some really good catharsis--even I found it touching :,).  And there was no #2 to be seen, so that automatically makes the episode better.  That is about all the positives though.  Granite, those are some pretty good positives to have.


   However, episode four was an insult to my intelligence.  I was bullied in elementary school but somehow this show managed to insult me more than my childhood bullies.  This is where #2 becomes a playable character in this grand harem.  Like with girl #1, girl #2 has the syndrome too and only the white knight can help her!  My biggest gripe with her character is that her problem that makes her seek out the MC is such a universal problem. Pretty much every high schooler doesn’t want to be alone and is embarrassed to go to school, so why is this girls so special that she gets a white knight to pretend to be her boyfriend for her?  If Mr. white knight is willing to help this girl because her anxiety reminds him of her little sister, then why doesn’t he just date every girl with anxiety? Because his harem would end up being a million freshman school girls too big.  Surprisingly, I actually think the anxieties and struggles of school girls could be made into a pretty good show.  Make a whole new show with new characters and present a similar scenario, and it could be good.  But as it stands, these ideas have no place in this show, and it just takes away from the already established story.


   To make matters worse, in the same episode, Bunny B!tch and Mr. knight started officially dating.  Basically, white night agrees to help #2 while he is already date Bunny girl.  This man, who literally yelled to the enter school how he felt, now thinks it is okay to pseudo see someone else.  What was even more insulting was that, bunny b!tch even saw them together and was aware off this. If this was reality, after Mr. Knight got off from work, he should of went straight to bunny b!tch’s house and cleared things up.  But no, his white knight and loli little sister got in the way and ruined the show.  


   I won’t go too in depth on episode five since I didn’t even finish it.  Me and the friend I was watching this with couldn’t take any more and dropped it midway through.  That and this show was drop worth from the CGI crowds in episode one--this is all just extra credit.  But the nail in the coffin for this episode was the fact that bunny girl went to MC’s house.  The guy who apparently love’s here didn’t even go to see her when he knows she thinks he’s cheating.  Not only that, the episode starts with MC just having explained everything off screen and with Bunny B!tch saying: “I understand the current circumstances now. It’s tough being a highschool girl.” Am I the crazy one? Because I think nobody would ever be okay with this arrangement on the day you started dating. I know people will just say something like “But she can empathize with #2.”  When, as I started earlier, ever high school has these problems; she isn’t special.  A much more realistic response from bunny girl would be her saying that #2 needs to get over herself, and that she got over herself and #2 can too.  Or an even better fix: take out #2 and just have a romance between Bunny B!tch and Sakuta.


   So basically, this show is bad, insulting even.  But it has stuff going for it, but it is plagued by an incompetent staff of writers and animators that will likely never achieve anything good in their careers if they don’t fix their jawn.  And by fix their jawn I mean stop adapting bad light novel harems, that’d be a good place to start.  So Rascal does not Dreams of Bunny B!tch Senpai… it’s not good.


If you disagree with anything I have to say, then catch me live on twitch (https://www.twitch.tv/infinite_fiend) and insult me personally.  I stream live anime discussions and analysis.  So if you feel inclined, give me a follow, and bring forth your best arguments. I'd love to hear them. Peace, and have a nice night.

What a disappointment, of the same author of Sakurasou in Pet na Kanojo that is a very good work, well developed and brings great messages of life, I thought that would see something similar in Bunny girl, but was totally mistaken.
(Story = 5/10)
The teenage syndrome is the theme that they address throughout the plot, it is quite interesting, the problem is that it is very predictable, besides holes in the script of some parts. The rhythm of the plot is well rushed, especially from the part 1, I feel that the relationship between the protagonist between Mai could bemore worked out to be more realistic their relationship, especially with the last episode of the part 1, it was something totally unexpected coming of the protagonist so soon. Now the other arcs followed the same thing of part 1, the protagonist asks things to Futaba to know what to do in the problems of each character, so getting predictable, is a hole of script this character, besides the anime does not detail the right issues being very superficial the plot.


(Characters = 5/10)


The characters are all very superficial, I feel they had a good background, but they were not well used, one of the main problems is that they do not seem real, the dubbing affected a lot of what I'm going to talk about, besides they did not have a good time of being well developed for us to care about these characters, one of the characters who suffered most from this was Kaede, even if she was the most superficial character could explore very well the issue of bullyng she suffered. Now the protagonist, I will confess the comedy has worked a few times because of him, is the kind of shameless character, who has good answers certain times, but greatly abused these jokes with the protagonist, getting very dull and losing grace very fast. His actions were very dubious at times, for through his reaction he did not seem to mind much, it was even odd at certain times.


(Art,Animation = 6/10)


The trace is pretty mediocre, sometimes even inconsistent, the character design is pretty bad, there are times when the characters are very identical. The scenery felt good, but nothing much, as well as its animation.


(Sound = 3/10)

The worst thing about Bunny Girl, the ost they play are pretty weak with repetitive piano taps with no impact at all, except that the silence often used in anime was the worst choice. The dubbing was terrible, I feel that the voice actors did not feel like dubbing this anime, I never felt such an empty and superficial character contributing so much to the dubbing badly done, it affected the protagonist very much, his actions, both dramatic ones, as in the jokes that he did, it did not seem real, they were completely empty, some times his voice was sleepy, and without ost, it was almost an invitation for me to sleep.


(Overall = 5/10)

Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai is an arc based supernatural drama series that focuses on a harem lead solving the mysterious goings on of his eccentric female classmates. If that sounds familiar, that's probably because it should. I'm not going to be the first or the only one to tell you this, but Bunny Girl Senpai clearly rides heavily on the coattails of other, more famous Light Novel Intellectual Property. I won't go as far as to call it plagiarism, but the parallels between this series and those like Monogatari or Haruhi Suzumiya are glaring enough that you start to question whereyou draw the line between wearing your influences on your sleeve and just trying to be them.


On some level, I understand why people are enamored with the show, because not everything about it is terrible. The formula it's drawing on clearly works (otherwise why do it, right?). Unfortunately, I feel like most of the time the writer didn't understand explicitly what made those older series stand out to begin with and just pulled structural elements from them hoping that would replicate their success.


One of the big talking points I see brought up about the series is that it's got that snappy back-and-forth dialogue that a lot of people enjoy. If the protagonist is engaging with someone, you can be sure he'll have something dry and witty to say to them, and his dance partner will be more than happy to reciprocate. That's how the scenario is supposed to play out ideally in most encounters of most episodes. It'll be played for laughs and will be used to endear us to the characters; they're like us, they're young, hip, and have that cynical internet humor going for them. This really only works, though, if the characters are being genuine about it. In most exchanges, the conversations come off as a some type of low energy defense mechanism (if that's the right way to phrase it) for the protagonist to continually reassure us that he is in fact as cool and smart as he plays himself off to be, and no person or event can shake him from that. His lack of vulnerability and the need for him to come out on top of all the verbal tussles leaves him feeling less like an actual person and more like a self-insert character prop. Even in situations where he feigns defeat, it's a win, because his concession is usually to something like being very attracted to a genuinely attractive girl, so that he can catch them off guard with how blunt he's being and regain control of the situation. In similar IP, side characters would be able to take advantage of this, but because Sakuta is consistently portrayed as the most intelligent character in the show, none of them are able to do anything with it. There's no chemistry or authenticity involved in an interaction (at least when it's the only type of interaction) that's primary narrative purpose is to remind us how cool and untouchable we should think the main character is. Imagine the most lopsided game of cat and mouse you've ever seen, but the mouse keeps coming back to play in spite of the knowledge that it has no hopes of ever winning, and is just there to make the cat look cool in front of his friends.


And really, when you get down to it, how knowledgeable Sakuta is framed to be is the show's biggest Achilles Heel. In a narrative sense, there's very little dramatic tension involved in the specific supernatural trouble each arc centers around, because once we know who it's about and what their symptoms are, Sakuta is able to tell them roughly how they could go about fixing it during their first interaction to immediately follow. The arc only continues because the person being given the advice doesn't take it right away. Once they've come to grasp that exact same piece of social understanding that we've known since the outset, the arc comes to a close. This happens in 3-4 of the 5 central stories presented, depending on how you argue the Mai segment (the Kaede arc being the sole exception). You would expect, then, if there isn't a lot of tension surrounding that portion of the conflict, the vast majority of the substance would be related to the show's thematic core and the surrounding character drama.


The quality of that thematic cohesion in relation to the emotional payoff of each arc is pretty variable. Sometimes, the show will surprise us with segments like the Kaede arc, where she struggles for self betterment largely as an individual, and in a way that seems emotionally honest, providing us with what is probably the best character the show has.
