Her motivation and want to improve seems largely good natured, and she's willing to put in her own work with the help of those surrounding her without taking their instructions verbatim on how to get to the destination. Weird, I know, but the show is most successful when it lets the characters explore their problems to their logical conclusion in a way that doesn't feel like their hand is being held (which is especially ironic, given that Kaeda is the one that requires the most literal physical assistance of any of the cast). For every moment like this, though, we have things like the Nodoka arc or the Futaba arc. The former of which largely ignores what could have been it's most interesting narrative conceit in the exploration of Toyohama's relationship with her mother, and the latter, which undercuts any emotional payoff the viewer might have by letting Sakuta fix all of Rio's problems for her.


At it's core, Bunny Girl wants to be a show that has something to say about the subtle ways people interact with each other. It wants to say that you should try to strike a healthy balance between being honest with yourself about your feelings, playing an active role in how other people perceive you, and that remembering to temper those concerns with some degree of care, hoping not to get too swept up in the fleeting emotions of your peers doesn't make you a bad person. Because these things are told to us through the lens of Sakuta, though, the way they're discussed isn't especially nuanced. Often times his solutions to problems feel incredibly reductive and leave almost no wiggle room for the complexity of the emotions of the other involved party. A lot of it boils down to "just kind of be honest and get over it". Even late in the series, when we finally see Sakuta's armor crack a little, the tone of the scene featuring it soured the scenario for me a bit, as if to say that he can't feel those terrible sad emotions because it made him less cool, and stoic cool dudes don't feel those emotions, bro.


A level of that attitude is to be expected, though, since characters like Sakuta are likely made to appeal to a common type of person in the anime community. High school aged guys who are kind of jaded and can't identify with the normal harem protagonist due to those characters' social ineptitude, but haven't matured enough yet to realize they aren't always the smartest or funniest person in the room. I tried to make that sound less insulting, but what are you gonna do, I guess.


At the end of the day, that's basically what this show is. It's average looking. It's music is mundane. It's character arcs are more miss than hit. And It's all told to you from the perspective of a guy you probably wouldn't want to be friends with because of how high he is on himself, even if he insists that he isn't. There was a lot worse you could have chosen to watch in 2018, but there was a lot better, too.

Didn't really know what to expect of this anime, but long story short I generally didn't like this. I mean it was decent, and the beginning of this anime made me watch more of the show. Although I did like it at the very start, there was one pattern I hated throughout the show, a problem occurs, the MC has to solve it and it's left with a few minutes without any issues before it goes on to a new problem. Well that's the biggest flaw in my opinion, although I can very much see why someone would enjoy this kind of anime.
Story: Got littleto say about the story, already talked about what I did- and didn't like..


Art: The art was decent, however not great. Much like many others I believe.


Sound: I mean, the music was great and all, on the other hand the opening didn't sound that good to me which also weighed down the score of this.


Character: I mean they have their own tastes which I kind of enjoyed, but the irony wasn't all that funny to me. I mean they're special and unique in its own way. I just wish that there were more going on with their lives other than their psychological illnesses..


I would believe that this anime has potential and that I can see why the reason behind the enjoyment rate, but it didn't affect me as much :/


Overall: [ 4/10 ]

Bunny Girl Senpai did not deserve the hype it got. I wasn't even to finish the anime, as every time I watched it, I would just get so overly bored. I would not be able to finish a single episode without looking away, checking my phone, or just plain ignoring everything in it. The first 3 episodes were alright, and captured my attention. But after that it all went downhill. The only good part about this anime was Koga, as she is a very well made character who I think deserved to be the main girl. 
As for Mai, she was alright in the beginning.After a while though she grew dull. I never really liked her tsundere act she tries to pull off, and I hate how she treats Sakuta with so much disrespect. Now, I think if Koga or one of the other girls had been more in the spotlight, the anime would have been so so so much better. For instance, Koga (despite her basically being a highly disliked character) was truly in love with Sakuta, and was willing to relive the same day over and over, no matter how boring it got, just so she could be with him longer. She cherished him, and didn't take him for granted. She also treated him well, and gave him lots of love. While Mai ended up leaving him for her work (yes, I know puberty syndrome blah blah, she needed to be famous or else she was invisible), Koga stayed there, as did all the other girls with arcs. It highly bothers me how Mai treats him as well. She blows him off all the time, gets mad at him a lot, and basically makes him chase her cause she is oh so special..


Now, the one thing I loovveedd about this anime was the art style. I thought the art was very pastel colored, which happens to be something I adore in anime (like Your lie in April, or Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid..). The art was actually what made me want to watch this, other than the fact that omg there is a bunny girl so hot wowowowow. 


A quick thought, I think this anime is similar to Charlotte. But wayyy worse. Charlotte was actually a great anime, and I loved it. It wasn't much about puberty syndrome, but it was about gaining shitty super powers while you're going through puberty. Yet, the characters in Charlotte are soo much better, and the story line there was fantastic! In Bunny Girl Senpai it was dull, and seemed to be the same thing over and over. 


This may just be personal preference, as I have friends who just adore this anime and think so highly fo Mai..but I just never was able to enjoy it.

I'm not one who normally writes reviews but Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is so good I just had to write one. Not very refined since it's my first review but it's spoiler-free and briefly covers the aspects that I really liked. 
Story: 10, Art: 9, Sound: 10, Character: 10, Enjoyment: 10, Overall: 10
Right from the very first episode, this anime had me hooked and I knew I was in for good. We are presented with Sakuta, the male main character, and 6 beautiful girls. Sounds like a generic harem anime? For starters, there are some mild sexual jokesand a bit of fan service, but after finishing the 13 episodes I can tell you that it's not, but rather, these elements merely serve as light refreshment. This anime has so much more as their strong points and has earned its spot as my top 3 anime ever. 


The 6 girls have their own arcs to describe their respective problems, caused by the so-called "puberty syndrome" and they overcome the problems with the help of Sakuta. I truly enjoyed the character-driven story, the pacing, and how the characters manage to cope with their problems. Their actions are realistic and felt natural. I'm fond of the dynamics and casualness of the relationship between the characters, particularly the boyfriend-girlfriend relationship of Sakuta and Mai and the brother-sister relationship of Sakuta and Kaede. 


I must praise the writers for the in-depth dialogues that are very well written and smoothly presented. Kudos to the voice actors as well as they successfully delivered the emotions of joy, excitement, anger, fear, frustration, sadness, sorrow, depression not in the over-the-top way; a reason why it's a fresh breath of air. In the end, they're very engaging and managed to captivate my attention. 


The art is good, but not the best one out there. CloverWorks managed to portray the gestures and emotions very well. But another strong point here is the sound. The music themes fit really well to the respective scenes, they boost the melodramatic atmosphere and give more immersion to said scenes. 


Overall, I think this anime is worth watching if you're interested in 1) stories that revolve around psychological stress, how they impact someone, the coping mechanism, and how the affected one resolves them and finds solace in others 2) excellent dynamics between the characters and good character development supported with well-written dialogues, great voice acting, and soundtrack that really fit the emotions, and 3) tearjerker anime.


As a side note, the creators use a lot of metaphors and symbolism, which I think are beautiful, and again, add deeper meaning to some scenes. Some are subtle; easy to miss, but once you come to the realization, they hit you hard.

Seishun Buta Yarou Wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai has to be the most overrated anime of the season. Opinions are divided, there are people who think this is a masterpiece, and others think this is shit. I am kinda between the middle but towards the latter. The main issue here is whether the main protagonist Sakuta is a cool guy or just a pure asshole. Although I hate Sakuta, I can get why people at first glimpse think he is the protagonist-of-the-season, on the surface, his dialogues are pretty badass and seems cool, but when you use your critical faculty to analyse,you realize that Sakuta is a completely ridiculous character that absolutely makes no sense at all. This review will explain to you why Sakuta is not a good character and why Bunny girl is an overrated anime. 


Character:1

I'll begin the review with the most pathetic aspect of the show, its characters. I will mainly about Sakuta, he is the root of all problems with the show, the embodiment of the unrealistic nature of the show. 

Now Sakuta is a high-school student that is not smart, not particularly handsome, there are rumours about him using violence (tho later on it is explained it is not the case) and he doesn't care about many things, including how other people view him and he did not really have a serious in-depth relationship before. Keep in mind these traits, because I will use them to show just how contradictory Sakuta is. First of all, I also don't give a shit about many things, but his "doesn't-give-a-shit" is on a different level. I don't know if you have ever had a relationship before at highschool, but if you do, then  you realize how ridiculous Sakuta is, he can say stuff like "I want to go to bed with you" without even blushing, in fact he never feels nervous or any emotion at any point at all, remember, he is not dating just any ordinary girl, not even just any beautiful girl, but the superstar of his age. Now Sakuta is an ordinary person, not only is he ordinary in terms of appearance and his academics, there are bad rumors about him, which make it worse. This fact makes it completely unrealistic for him to act as if nothing is happening when dating the Bunny Senpei. There is no way, really, how he can feel no pressure at all, remember his no expert at dating, he had only one relationship according to the show before and is not explained in the show at all, but even if he is an expert, this whole thing feels fake and there is no way to relate to and emotionally invest in this show. But, why, do so many people actually enjoy the show and think Sakuta is so cool? Let's talk about his lines, all his interactions with girls are vulgar and bold. He would shout out that he is virgin and teased about other girls being on period, he would kick a girl's butt and etc, etc. I can not take this seriously, this is really bullshit, there is no way how anyone at anytime would behave like Sakuta. But if you think about his dialogues, those are words that kids would think: "oh I should have said that on that date to make me look more confident and cool." Yes, it looks cool from a third person perspective, but the truth, his lines are absurdly unrealistic for anyone to say. If you disagree, try them on your female classmates and they will be in love with you? no way. Everything about Sakuta is artificial. Now can you have unrealistic characters in a show then? the answer is yes if it is some sci-fi shows that is set in an alternative world, but in this case, the show is about romance that is set in modern world. if a romance show like Bunny Girl has incredibly unreal characters, I don't understand how it can be pleasing to view; not only that, romance shows' conversations are important in order to make audiences feel emotionally invested, but Bunny Girl's conversations are awful, Sakuta's monotonous vulgar lines really make me sick, and people think this is cool. Sakuta looks like a corpse to me most of the time, he doesn't give a shit about anything and don't want to explain about rumors about him and just let it happen. I wonder if he even cares about how people would view his girlfriend. Let me tell you something, in reality, people start to think:" why does Mai date with such a unfunny and boring guy? Does Mai really have that low standard?" but apparently Sakuta can't be bothered to explain and he continues to be this boring, offensive asshole through the entire show with zero character development, as ridiculous as Sakuta is, girls fall in love with him one after another. People who enjoyed the show aren't really enjoying the romance aspect of the show, they are enjoying imagining themselves being a guy that speaks in the most bold and coarse way possible while girls keep falling in love with him. 

Why isn't sakuta punished for his offensive lines then? the show greets you with Mai, the most unrealistic heroine I've ever seen, A teen star who exhibits little anxiety, she is sick of attention but that never manifests in her personality at all. Is comfortable with all the dirty lines from sakuta, has very little self-aware being a teen star, dresses like a bunny girl with no other intention then to provide a huge clickbait (which by the way, was completely forgotten once the story moves forward). She is okay with his boyfriend pretending to be the boyfriend of another girl, and okay when asshole sakuta can't be bothered to explain his intimacy with the said girl. god, kill me plz, i've never seen a character so absurd other than sakuta.

Okay, let me say this, she is a perfect waifu, yes, we know that, but do you really think she is a good character? a realised character? 

this show is a fantasy, and all characters are served for that purpose. Not to mention the abysmal character development of all other characters:  a girl who developed a crush on sakuta and appeared five seconds after her arc just so we know she isn't dead. Futaba who showed up whenever necessary to explain her stupid quantum mechanics, please, do yourself a favor and go back to look at the way she speaks before her arc and after, do you see any character development? 


Art: 7

Animation is not really consistent through out, like the beginning of ep 12 has some facial distortion, it happens here and there. So it is worth a 7. 


Sound: 

I do enjoy the op and ed, however, Sakuta's monotonous speaking is really vomit-inducing, he never changes the way he speaks, again, can you imagine such a guy with no emotions expressed entire time be the same guy that flirt masterfully with girls? if you can, then you need a reality check. 


Story: 5

You have the synopsis anyway so I wouldn't write a summary on this. Instead I'll talk about the positive and negative aspects of the story:

For the bad parts:

1. The show spends more than ten minutes every two or three episodes explaining pesudo-science to account for the puberty syndrome in the same setting, that is, futaba's lab. This is really boring and unnecessary, you know not any of these explanations are valid anyway. The show tempts to explain something fictional using actually science theory, this is ridiculous, it could be handled much better by just coming up with some fictional explanation. 

2. Characters are either stereotypical or unrealistic, we have younger sister with a brother complex, a girl that looks chill but has a soft side, a cute type of girl. I don't find these character designs exciting. 

The good thing is:

1. This show has a generally good theme by solving puberty problems are atleast teens would have in reality. This show would be much better if characters are more realistic. 


Enjoyment: 5

The first few episodes can be enjoyable but the more I watch, the more I feel it is painful to watch more. This is because the more arcs it introduces, the more cliche I feel Sakuta's way of handling issues are. Also again, Sakuta's conversation and tones can be exciting at first glimpse, but as the show proceeds, there is a point at around ep 8 where I feel I can't tolerate his way of speaking any more. 


Overall:4

I don't hate this show, this show is definitely not trash tier anime like SAO is, It could be enjoyable but don't take this seriously, withhold your suspense in order to enjoy the show, so basically, turn down your brain in order to enjoy the show.

Racal Does Not Dream Of Bunny Girl Senpai is nothing like its name would indicate similarly it’s cover art making it appear as nothing more than a lazy excuse for a harem though in actuality it’s quite the contrary, as instead it has a great heart and tells a touching story from beginning to end exploring the lives and complications of a wide variety of character types. 
Plot- The narrative is extremely effective; The plot surrounds a group of characters simultaneously experiencing a phenomenon called adolescence syndrome which imposes supernatural effects on the ensemble in a very similar manner to Kimi no nawa in implementationand exploration which similarly allows the anime to have a heavy heart throughout the journey which it’s not afraid to show having strong emotion and eventful moments by episode 3 and a climax which had many in the anime community holding back tears. The story does its job perfectly not recreating the wheel instead being an engaging string for the audience to follow tugging them back each Thursday anticipating the new episode while also facilitating scenarios for the characters which are debatably the main focus of the anime, the narrative giving reason for different characters of old and new in relation to Sakuta to interact and develop relationships along with the wide variety of other impactful character moments. The narratives other effective factors are the previously stated supernatural storyline which gives flair and originality to the slice of life elements of the anime not only creating intrigue but also allowing for more in depth development of each character represented by their symptom while also the journey to overcome it. Overall due to the narrative not being anything drastically new and original though perfecting and building upon previous attempts of this narrative type creating a masterfully executed take on the genre it receives an 8/10. 


Character- The characters in the anime were extremely close to being masterful feeling genuine and detailed throughout the anime’s seasonal run. The main character Sakuta is developed perfectly being a comprehensive and relatable figure, from strangers he’s seen as emotionless and cold but the close friendship circle around him gained throughout the duration of the season view him as emotional and caring effectively doing anything and everything to help his friends and family as seen throughout each episode. The other main character Mai is similarly complex having to deal with the struggles of her career and its effects on her high school experience further added upon by her dysfunctional family and also struggles through adolescence syndrome, this allowing for in detail development of her character in relation to her history and also relationship with Sakuta featuring a beautiful romance arc over the season. The supporting cast is brilliant and similarly well developed from Kaede his anxious younger sister and her past and present struggle through adolescence syndrome to Nodoka who is insecure of her own abilities as an effect of always being compared to her older sister Mai. Due to the lovably ensemble of characters featured throughout the series and comprehensive development displayed overall the characters are a high 9/10.


The music which accompanies the anime is one of my favourites in recent memory with a distinct op clearly representing and reflecting the themes and mood of the show with accompanying visuals only adding to the experience. This can be similarly said with the ed having so much care and attention put into it such as the changing vocals depending on the arc from the episode similarly with the visuals. The Soundtrack which accompanies each episode is also noteworthy having a wide variety of pieces that capture the mood and add to the experience leaving me with an extremely tough choice for the music to use in this review. Overall due to this it receives a tremendously deserved 9/10.


Overall the anime is absolutely masterful in every single element it portrays throughout the season and is well deserving of a 9/10 leaving the anime community in anticipation of the upcoming movie.

In short, the reason i dropped this is that the only thing I actually liked about the show is Sakuta's banter with Mai but, that wasn't a good enough for me to continue watching. 
Firstly, there is the entire reason I'm an anime fan in the first place. Animation is capable of conveying emotions in a way that live action doesn't. BGS however, uses the medium for one visually interesting scene in the first 5 episodes. Apart from this, there were no shots that i find even remotely interesting to look at, with directing that feels flat to me and character animation that fails toconvince me of genuine feelings.


Good visuals aren't everything though and good stories don't necessitate impressive visuals to keep me engaged. Unfortunately, there are several aspects of Bunny Girl's plot and execution that didn't gel well with me. Most importantly, the solutions of Bunny Girl's supernatural problems aren't very compelling. Both Mai and Koga get saved from their problems by Sakuta and I don't like that. I find stories of how they overcome their problems much more engaging than a love confession and Sakuta beating a guy up (I know that's not the actual conclusion but, from what i heard the conclusion is even worse). At the end of the first arc, I asked myself: what have the characters learnt from this, how have they changed, what is the lesson? None of the answers I or people I've talked to satisfy me.


The pacing of the story also seems fairly rushed, as if it's jumping from plot point to plot point with no time for anything to impact me, particularly when Sakuta talks about his sister's syndrome it shows the only visually interesting scene in the anime and then goes back to what they were talking about earlier which was fairly jarring. I felt a slower pace to allow for more characterisation would have benefited the anime.


Another problem I have with the anime is with the pseudo-science. This often gets brushed off as one of Futaba's character traits even but, there is no indication that Futaba is the person who doesn't know what she's talking about and not the author. If I knew nothing about quantum physics then there is no clue that Futaba is misapplying the theories - there should be a better clue than Futaba just being wrong. It also doesn't help that her characterisation up to the point i dropped it is 'science girl', so it's a fair assumption that she's the author's tool for exposition.


This leads me on to my next issue: the characters. 


Futaba is an extremely boring character with seemingly no depth (I've read about her later development and it's very much a case of "why would i care about the problems of a drawing that I didn't like in the first place"). She has a crush on a guy we know hardly anything about (that's already an overdone cliche) and that's everything.


Kuninimi (I think?) Is a bro, a one-dimensional bro that doesn't even have his name on Bunny Girl's MAL page or any real screen time but he's cool.


His girlfriend is annoying for the sake of it.


Similarly annoying is Koga who happens to be the kind of person I really don't like, so it was always going to be a task to get me to like her anyway.


Kaede is Sakuta's little sister.


Sakura himself is relatively smart, charismatic, witty, a nice guy, apparently good in a fight, gives great life advice, is smooth with the ladies, works part-time to help support himself and his sister, is the sole caretaker for his sister and lacks any convincing flaws that make him seem human to me. The story seems to be afraid to question his views and expose any insecurities or weaknesses he has. I've been told that he later gets called out on his behaviour but, the story hasn't given any consequences for this.  


A good writer, in my opinion, should put a character in a situation where we can see these parts of their personalities.


Mai is an Ok character. She's a tsundere pretending to be a kuudere but, there really isn't enough to sell me on her character. For instance, how did she feel when her mother forgot she exists? How does she feel about it now? 


There are also two other aspects that fail to move me in this show. The OST exists, probably, I can't remember any of the music. Then there's the voice acting. I just don't like how monotone it is. It makes any lines that aren't best suited to monotone like sarcastic comebacks either sound boring or lacking in emotion.

Another 2018's fall anime series which i watched based on its popularity and.....it was good..not perfect tho...this anime is made for teenage boys to be honest :D teenagers will love this anime for sure :)))
STORY 8/10 :so story is about a guy who saw his senpai one day running around with bunny outfit running around without anybody noticing her...he is a curious teenage boy so he had to ask about her situation and after that day they hang out together everyday and...falling in love :D there are a lot dramas and jokes tho :))))
ART 7/10 :so art is fine but it doesn't match 2018's visuals...artseems a little old like in 2007 or smth but still...its good


SOUND 6/10 :as for the sound i only loved the ending and there is nothing special about soundtracks tbh...


CHARACTER 7/10 :we have two main characters Azusagawa Sakuta and Sakurajima Mai...


Sakuta : a teenage boy interested in girls like other teenage boys(mostly)...he is the very honest yet stupid one here...he says whatever comes to his mind freely like he doesn't care about what others might think about him...he is obviously in love with Mai(his bunny senpai)and does whatever she tells him X)))


Mai: Sakuta 's senpai who was a famous actress but suddenly she stopped working and went to a regular school but one day she noticed that no one recognizes her  and then Sakuta suddenly shows up in her life and saves her from this syndrome(they call it a syndrome)


Sakuta has two friends a smart girl and a regular boy...and a younger sister who suffered from this kinda syndrome :D


ENJOYMENT 6/10 :at first i found this anime a little boring but it got interesting after episode 4 or so :)


OVERALL 6/10 :so this bunny girl senpai is actually a GOOD ENOUGH anime...the only warning is that this is not your pure high school story of two people falling for each other...its reality :D it has all kinds of words and expressions...you will see all kinds of teenagers behaviors :D


so if you like watching a cute bunny girl senpai messing around and falling in love...and also a teenage boy doing what he does with a quite interesting story behind them then give this a try :D

So Far in just 3 episodes, this anime has done an outstanding work. Probably going to be added to my favorites list soon after it ends. 
Story/Plot: 10
very amazing and intriguing. The plot is way deeper than I thought. the theme of the series that it portrays is that us teens and basically the whole society lives and believe things by with rumors and the so called "everyone" thinks, without trying to look for a different outcome/answer. and how easily everyone goes with the flow and switch their mindsets/thoughts on specific subjects by the mood of the atmosphere. And how the illusions shown by unstablepsyches or strong preconception that come from adolescence is basically our society today. But at the same time the way to alter any given atmosphere is to break norms, and present an independent perspective while also making a statement big enough for people to recognise, validate and internalise. So the only way to alter the atmosphere is a big show of social unconventional but relatable perspective, so its a huge power of love and friendship cop out, their their going to have to keep repeating

Interesting... very interesting.... the author is a genius


Art: 8

The art is nothing bad and nothing too special. I guess you can call it your average anime art. good thing there are no Bad CGI in this one tho. But you can say that the art is wonderful especially the sunset part, that was pretty. 


Sound: 7

I have to say, the studio did a great job on the OSTs and it was really great listening to it while watching the anime. It really created mood and how the author intended the scene to be like. 

But to be honest, The Opening Theme Song (OTS) is just Horrendous. That why I graded this sound part as a 7 and not a 8. But the Ending Theme Song (ETS) is fairy Good.


Character: 9

I think the way the characters were set up as were really nice, and they got to preserve the character traits without breaking it. The author even made sure that the characters stick to their intended traits - this was shown when Mai slapped poor Sakuta. Instead of acting in the spur of the moment (she's still human, she did tear up but quickly composed herself), she came up with a rationale decision instead of going all tsun on him (thankfully) as we commonly see in many other animes.


Enjoyment: 9

I really enjoyed watching the first 3 episodes of this anime. the first episode really got me into the story and couldn't wait to watch the next episode. After watching the first 3 episodes, it really made me think over our society today and how we are not seeing things that are pretty obvious and how easily people forget things because of one twitch to the atmosphere. 


Overall: 10

To wrap it up, I really enjoyed watching this and recommend this anime to all.

Butayarou: It's Bakemonogatari, but instead of mental illness being represented by folklore or magical entities, mental illnesses here manifest themselves as sci-fi weirdness known as "Adolescent Syndrome." This includes things like time loops, retroactive erasure from reality, characters splitting into two... Some really interesting concepts that can work really well to explore the concepts of identity and self.
Unfortunately, it sucks. 
This is what happens when you rip off a successful work, but fail to capture the essence of what actually succeeded the first time around. It results in some of the most banal, hackneyed trash I've seen in an anime in a long time, allglossed up like it's destined to be the next big hit when in reality it's got about zero appealing factors.


First off, we gotta address the cast. By that I mean, they just don't exist beyond two-sentence stock summaries, most of them lifted directly from Bakemonogatari. The protagonist is sardonic and cynical, but also goes out of his way to protect everyone. Check. The main girl is a tortured and reserved tsundere who opens up quickly after her initial problem is fixed. Check. There's the nerdy glasses girl who seems to know literally everything, but has a secret romance-driven pain deep in her heart that manifests by splitting her personality in two. Check. There's the cute kouhai who is driven to great jealousy by the protagonist's relationship. The only "new" characters is the little sister, who is a stock personality herself, but not one stolen from a Nisioisin book, and an idol who really doesn't have much presence.


Each of these main characters has their own character arc problems that need to be solved, and of course they always involve some supernatural occurrences (except for the sister's, but I won't go into that one because it's just too poorly done). BIG PROBLEM THOUGH: the arcs aren't interesting! The characters aren't interesting! It's all paint-by-numbers high school life!


We have such good sci-fi elements that get only the most cursory use, never delving anywhere past the surface level. There's a body swap story arc where two characters are forced to assume each other's lives, but it leads to one emotional outburst and mainly some hijinks. There's characters stuck in a time loop, but to only one end, and that is some wacky dating hijinks. A character accidentally creates a copy of herself, and so now two of herself are wandering around the world living as independent beings. But rather than exploring that concept of identity, it's just treated like a hurdle for the writers to get past; they don't want to deal with the sci-fi parts, they just want to get back to the kissing (of which there is none, spoiler alert). 


It took me a while to realize what makes Butayarou a failure while ripping off from only the most successful anime of the past decade-- the characters aren't given enough depth beyond their stereotypes, but why? I know why. The protagonist, the main dude, takes away all the spotlight. The female characters have zero agency in their own story arcs, because the protagonist solves all their problems for them. In Bakemonogatari and its sequels, Araragi does his best to help his friends, but in the end, the characters only fix their problems of their own accord; the only character who was saved entirely by Araragi turned out much worse later down the line as a result. 


Here, the protagonist does all the work. The first girl is saved because the main guy learns to overcome his own feelings of awkwardness and put himself out there. The second girl is saved after the protagonist forces her to confess her inadequacies. The third girl is saved by the protagonist arranging everything to force her to see herself clearly. And so on. No agency means it's not interesting, and we can't actually explore a character's identity if their arcs have been snuffed out by a poor narrator. 


The very last story arc is so bad that the big giant emotional plot twist was so obvious, so hackneyed, that I didn't see it coming. This was not an uncommon occurence in Butayarou. Every single time that there was something interesting the story could do, it instead resolved itself to have some sort of ridiculous plot twist to push itself back towards the normal Light Novel Quasi-Harem High School Drama status quo, and nothing ever actually changed but some of the characters seem to like each other a bit better now. 


Stay away. Just rewatch Bakemonogatari and be done with it.

A couple of days ago I binged through "Bunny Girl Senpai" and thoroughly enjoyed it. It wasn't until I came to this page that I saw the discussions about it being similar to "Bakemonogatari", up to and including accusations of blatant plagiarism. As luck would have it, "Bakemonogatari" was near the top of my PTW list, so I decided to watch it and see for myself how similar they were.
The two series have some notable similarities. Both have a male lead who thorough a series of 2 to 3 episode story arcs aids a series of female characters who have been experiencing a variety ofsupernatural/paranormal phenomena that are messing up their lives. In both cases, the male is something of an outcast who has been through something similar himself who can't help wanting to aid these girls with their struggles. Also in both, he gets into a romantic relationship with the first girl, who then proves to be understanding and supportive when he comes to the aid of other girls.


Beyond that, however, there are huge differences between the two. The art style and atmosphere is the most glaring difference; "Bunny Girl Senpai" is set in a realistic (albeit animated) world, whereas "Bakemonogatari" has a much more arthouse/impressionistic feel to it, often dark but at times whimsical and farcical. "Bunny Girl Senpai" stays pretty much in the realm of emotional drama whereas "Bakemonogatari" ventures much closer to horror territory, with some scenes portraying blood and graphic violence. The nature of the supernatural/paranormal phenomena differs between the two. "Bakemonogatari" has themes of vampirism, and the phenomena are portrayed as demonic curses of some sort, whereas there's nothing of the sort in "Bunny Girl Senpai", where some are tied to concepts of a more scientific nature, such as Schrödinger's Cat or Laplace's Demon. It also bears mentioning that the use of supernatural/paranormal phenomena as story elements are not unique to these two series. They are also central themes in other series such as "Kokoro Connect" and "The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya", and feature less prominently in other stories such as the series "Clannad" or the film "Your Name".


In summary, while "Bunny Girl Senpai" and "Bakemonogatari" have some notable similarities, they have enough differences to preclude any claims of copying. To say they are alike would be like claiming that chefs on the Food Network show "Chopped" made the same dish just because their dishes included the same four mystery basket ingredients.


Since this is supposed to be a review of "Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai", I suppose it behooves me to actually review it. I came into the series thinking it was a quirky romantic comedy, which isn't very accurate, but I soon found the show enjoyable enough for what it was. The characters introduced in the first story arc were engaging and likable, making me want to see how that situation played out. There were a couple of moments, especially one in episode 3, that were so over the top that I briefly toyed with dropping the series, but I'm glad I didn't, as the characters and situations explored in later episodes proved to be just as engaging as those we meet early on. The art and visuals were well done, as was the audio and the musical score. All in all, it's a well done and highly enjoyable series. It covers the first five volumes of the associated light novels; I shall be looking forward to the forthcoming film that covers the next two volumes of the series.


By the way, I also recommend "Bakemonogatari".

Let me start off by saying that i did enjoy the series  before i start jabbing at it. just because i jab at it doesn't mean i don't like it. and most of you don't seem to know what a review is but boy do you know how to rant. Am i good at it? No, (at least i'm probably not) but you can at least try to not cry about it, write the damn "review" and move on!
anyway.
 Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai AKA Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai 
AAKA Bunny Girl Senpai (becauseshorter titles are just easier for for our wee little brains to comprehend) 

is your stereotypical mushy love story interjected with dry and sometimes sarcastic  comedy that  may go  unnoticed or unappreciated and honestly a lot of the time i found this to be true. Yeah it got a good chuckle out of me a time or two but it wasn't the typical japanese slapstick that i'm used to when i see an anime with the "comedy" tag but it felt like that was just there for show, to see how long we'd watch before realizing that it's not your run of the mill comedy that most of us are probably use to by this point, though i applaud it for trying. *insert sarcastic single clap here*


 The story seemed a bit repetitive to say the least, puberty syndrome (aka middle school syndrome and about a hundred other names for this) problem is presented, our main hero boy questions what's going on, comes to a conclusion with his little science friend and *insert witty, mildly philosophical speech here* and YAY! problem solved! rinse  and repeat until about episode 10 or 11 and you got yourself a show! All that being said the art, and animation was pretty good over all, i mean it didn't wow me or anything, it was the typical big eye, small mouths and rosy cheeks that artists have  been using for years now, nothing really stood out as particularity eye catching. same for the sound design , i mean yeah there was a pop song in the middle of the series and that spiced things up for a moment but, again, not something i was super impressed by. The characters on the other hand! ... weren't impressive either they all kinda of stayed the same in the end, yeah they had their moments but at the end of the day they go back to their average life in high school, not being all that changed the next time around, yeah,  i assume they learned their lesson(s) but they go back to acting almost the same afterwords more or less. Sakutais is your favorite stoic, witty, slightly philosophical, mild douche bag with a dry sense of humor(which is why he's my favorite character) Mai is your stereotypical cold and distant "hot girl" that turns out to be (not so) surprisingly warm hearted when you take the time to get to know her  with a slightly sensible head on her shoulders,  then you you have the seemingly stoic no nonsense cute brainy girl that'll throw a joke in the mix that'll probably zip past if you aren't paying attention. not to mention the "best friend" that is hardly there and the little sister that that just wants to bed her brother but he ain't having any of it.


 Even after of that being said, i did find myself enjoying it in the end. "but why!" you may be wondering after typing up the worlds longest paragraph throwing jabs at it. Well you see the answer is fairly simple, it had an odd charm about it that i found amusing that compiled me to keep watch it even after noticing that it was a "rinse and repeat" kind of anime. "oh no! i soled the sheets! oh that's fine, we'll just plop this in the wash and they'll be good as new!" seemed to be the general idea of the show, even so, i kept coming back to see how papa Sakuta was going to clean up the mess this time. I found it somewhat enjoyable waiting to see how everything played out knowing in the end it would end with some life advise and hugging it out. Though i wish that it didn't pull as many punches in the feels department but then again maybe i'm just  a masochist. 


 Long story short , not knowing what "puberty syndrome" shenanigans was going to happen next and how they were gong to fix it kept me coming back. That and maybe the fact that i'm a hopeless romantic and loved seeing how that mushy shit played out is why i liked it in the end. 


TL;DR Bunny Girl Senpai is a mushy romance story with a dry sense of humor that may or may not give you diabetes depending on how sweet you like your anime.So if this sounds like your cup of tea then enjoy, if not then sod off, if you're not sure then the first couple of episodes sets the tone pretty well for the rest of the show.


I give it a solid BUNNY/GIRL. now if you'll excuse me, i have a bottle of lotion to help me "review" some other bunny girl material.

Disclaimer: Ignore the negative reviews that include "the girls have no character", "the protagonist cares about nothing", and "it's a Monogatari rip-off." What they anticipated was a confirmation bias and refused to give it any sort of room to do its own thing. 
Now, onto the review...
If I said "toothbrush scene", most people would be able to respond with "oh, that scene in Monogatari that, even in-context, makes zero sense?". Now, if I said "Monogatari is good, but dialogue-heavy and full of PLOT", most people would be turned-off from the series. I could understand that, too, since it's hard to marathon that series on itsown. The dialogue-heavy aspect is a bit of a "pleb filter" to weed out the people who have severe attention issues, and those that enjoy good characterization and easily some of the most enjoyable dialogue. 


Unfortunately, "enjoyable" doesn't always translate into "Believable". 


Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is (hereon referred to as "Bunny-girl Senpai") has some of the most believable dialogue in the genre to date. Its characters feel fresh, yet predictable in how they emulate real-world behaviours. Granted, the phrase "fiction is not reality" is still applicable, but that means so little when the cast is so endearing. The main character, Sakuta, has a "go against the grain" personality that you could believe someone would possess as a result of a trauma from earlier in his life. His eagerness to help others after a mysterious girl inspired him to do so is perhaps the most uninspired, yet believable motivation coming out of a series like this. 


Bunny-girl Senpai also rejects the standard tropes of the genre. In an arc where a "beach episode" is inevitable and the standard PLOT trope is almost expected, the series does its best to subvert by giving the obviously underage character a more modest bathing suit. The "tsundere love interest" doesn't have a one-day crush, but her feelings legitimately develop over an extended period of time. When the protagonist is inclined to ruin himself for her, it's played straight and as further legitimization of both their feelings. 


That's the gist of the series, as well. Protagonist encounters strange occurrence with a "member" of his "harem", has to resolve it, and they're thankful, but don't fall in love as if he's the first male to ever do anything for them ever. Heck, only two characters actively fall for him, one of which resolves to simply be his friend because it's better than the alternative of either never seeing him again, or testing his tolerance. 


I will admit the series opening and ending themes are perhaps some of the most catchy tunes you'll hear this season, but the rest of the show doesn't have tons in terms of ambient music that you'll recall, which is fine. A series ought to stand on its own merits in terms of writing and characterization rather than factoring in ost's. As well, the absence of "fun chibi" animation is refreshing, though some might also feel a bit disappointed as a result. I will say the art and animation are well-done and the models are really good. 


Ultimately, even if it never gets a second season or the author is content with what he's written, I would still highly recommend it. Whether as a "jumping off" point for Monogatari or on its own merits, I would honestly suggest you go watch this and judge for yourself!

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai
Wow, that is quite a mouthful, but Bunny Girl Senpai works fine too as an abbreviation. This anime is great, but I`ll firstly address its shortcomings. It is Monogatari/Oregairu knockoff, but not really. Less of a knockoff of Oregairu and more of a similarity in characters, but practically a script out of the Monogatari series- Guy helps out girls that have supernatural problems. I am a big fan of the Monogatari series, but I will defend Bunny Girl Senpai because of the maturity of the themes incorporated into its arcs. A lot of people lovethe MC, Sakuta Azusagawa, but just as many people dislike his qualities as the main character. I can understand the hate, but I like him as a character. The girls are unrealistic. Oh, get over it. It’s an anime, the whole premise of anime is to subvert reality. However, this show does it well, and I`ll explain why that is the case. Okay, now it's time to go over the anime itself.


PLOT: Puberty Syndrome is real, and it is an effect of adolescence that occurs due to specific social circumstances. They mostly have to do with an abrupt change in one’s daily life, such as switching bodies or getting stuck in a time loop. Our main character, Sakuta has an encounter with adolescence syndrome when he notices a third year senpai from his school walk around dressed in a revealing bunny girl outfit, with no one paying attention to her. Her name is Mai, and she is a popular and rising actress, which further contradicts the fact that she’s being completely ignored by others. Sakuta confronts her, and after talking to her for a few days, they come to the realization that she is slowly fading out of human perception, because she had wished to “go to a world where no one could see her.” The reason for this was because her mother had attempted to exploit her as an actress in order to make money. It is revealed that Sakuta has had a previous encounter with adolescence syndrome, when unexplained physical wounds plagued him and his sister after his sister was bullied online, which is why he acknowledges the existence and validity of this phenomenon. It’s concluded that certain social circumstances or a certain mindset must be present to cause this adolescence syndrome. Back to the main story. Sakuta’s friend, Futaba Rio, diagnoses her with “Schrodinger’s Cat”, a quantum physics experiment that explains her situation: Mai is fading out of existence because she isn’t being observed. Eventually, Sakuta brings Mai back into existence by confessing his love to her in front of the school, and having the entire school observe her existence at once. As the school year progresses, Sakuta deals with case after case of adolescence syndrome, each girl bringing a new problem to solve. I’m missing a bunch of romantic details here with this summary, but this is the gist of it.


Writing and Characters: 9/10

The writing is fantastic. It has this whimsical and mysterious feel that balances lighthearted romance and comedy elements with serious social problems, with a touch of the supernatural. Sakuta and the gang make excellent banter, with conversations that feel natural and funny, and not forced. While there is a decent list of relevant characters, I’ve chosen to write about the three most important ones. 

Sakuta Azusagawa has a habit of sexual harassment that is enough to turn a conversation into an amusing one, but not enough to make him a hateable pervert character like Mineta from Hero Academia. He has that antisocial persona that most MCs do, but is deep down a really good person who will come through for you, especially if you happen to be a girl with adolescence syndrome. His conversations with Mai are cute and romantic, not enough to make you disgusted at them being lovey dovey, but just the right amount you can enjoy. 

Mai Sakurajima is another solid character, being the top love interest and the “main heroine” of the anime. She’s an adorable tsundere that doesn’t go as over the top as they all do in other anime, and she’s a perfect match for our cynical but likeable  Sakuta. She’s understanding, reliable, and kind, with kind of a big sister aura surrounding her, and she grows a lot as a person when her problem is resolved, because of her relationship with Sakuta. 

Kaede Azusagawa. At first glance she seems like the normal brocon little sister, but she definitely is an interesting and unique character. (Spoiler ahead.) Before she was an adorable Onii Chan loving girl, she was a normal middle schooler, but since the bullying incident and physical scarring that followed, she lost all of her memories and became a shut in, only relying on her older brother. This makes a great deal of sense, given that she has no experiences with anyone else after the incident, and it would be difficult to re assimilate her into society. She also makes an attempt at doing so by going to school independently, which is a fantastic display of character development on her part.

Character development is the name of the game in this anime. Same as Monogatari but this time, there is a specific focus of social circumstances like bullying, which is rather mature, with no offense to the Monogatari series. It is pretty rare that realistic themes like this appear in anime, but when done right make for a fantastic show. And it has done right. One of the ideas that makes anime good is its blend between reality and fiction. This is what really props up the genre of isekai, the idea that a guy grounded in reality suddenly is thrust into a fantasy world. 

In Bunny Girl Senpai, the balance of reality and fiction is done extremely well, with enough fiction to explain puberty syndrome but enough realistic drama to cause puberty syndrome. The idea of adolescence syndrome is handled creatively, mixing in real life ideas such as Schrodinger's cat and Laplace’s Demon as the cases of adolescence. The drama is handled quite in a believable way, such as Kaede’s unique symptoms tearing Sakuta’s family apart, and Mai and her little sister being jealous and angry at each other growing up because they were compared to each other by their mothers. The dialogue is done right as well, with a good mix of natural everyday conversation and serious and dramatic matters. There’s a running gag or two, but it doesn’t get in the way of the flow of the anime, which is really good, because any dialogue that gets in the way of an anime’s flow is bad dialogue. 


Art and Animation: 7.5/10 

Mediocre, nothing that stands head and shoulders over other anime like Violet Evergarden does, and nothing too bad like a certain airing little sister show I`m not gonna mention. The animation in certain scenes is nice and fluid, such as the running animation of the opening, and the beach walking scenes of the ending. The character visuals are okay, no gorgeous, over the topic character designs to gush over for a long time, but memorable enough to recall in discussion. If the really emotional scenes of this anime were animated with extreme care for quality, it would really bring out the beauty of this anime more, but even that not being the case, it stands alone as a great anime. 



Music (Soundtracks and Opening/Ending): 9/10

Unexpectedly, this is where the show really takes the cake. Music, like art, is subjective to opinions, but for the sake of review I`ll talk about it anyway. 

Kimi no Sei (It’s Your Fault) by the Peggies is an upbeat song that introduces every character in a quirky, slideshow like manner, which is the complete opposite of its accompanying ending song, Fukashigi No Carte (An Incomprehensible Record). The effects of the opening are reminiscent of screensavers of Macintosh computers which may seem lazy, but do not take away from the presentation of every girl, for example: the mysterious character of Shoko Makinohara, which is a very good addition, given her equally mysterious nature in the actual anime, as well as the increased screen time in the sequence of Mai Sakurajima, the Bunny Girl of the anime. Fukashigi No Carte, sung by the individual voice actresses of the main heroines, is an unique and extremely methodical ending sequence. The song itself is whimsical and gives off a mysterious and supernatural feel, and each arc has a different girl singing the song and walking towards something different. In Mai’s bunny girl arc, she is seen walking towards Sakuta, her lover, and in Futaba’s arc, Futaba is walking towards her friends, Sakuta and Kunimi. In Kaede’s arc, rather than wearing her usual panda pajamas, she is wearing her school outfit, which she has never put on after being bullied. There is a great deal of symbolism packed into the endings, which is easily overlooked. A lot of people may not care almost at all about anime openings and especially anime endings, but Bunny Girl Senpai has some extremely well thought out and symbolic sequences for both, with fitting song choices to boot. 

In terms of soundtrack, the original compositions are really good. Three emotionally impactful scenes really come to mind when I think about this anime’s original soundtrack. The first one is when (BIG SPOILERS AHEAD) Toga stops lying and gathers the courage to confess to Sakuta, the second one is when Mai and her little sister are arguing because each sister thought she had it worse in her home growing up, and the third, arguably the most impactful scene in the anime, is when Kaede tries to grow up from being a shut in. This particular scene really steals my heart because of the music that plays when Kaede says that she wants to go to school, a place that she has no good memories of, because she no longer wants to be a burden. The emotional impact of this particular scene had me in tears, due in no small part to the accompanying soundtrack. 


Conclusion: 8.8/10

This anime is great. I honestly cannot understand or justify why people decide that the writing is bad or that the dialogue is unnecessary, or develop a firm hatred of its characters. The fact of the matter is that this is an extremely well thought out anime, from the elements of puberty syndrome to the well crafted design and role of each heroine, to the cinematography of the opening and ending songs. This is as well written as it gets when it comes to interesting anime. 

It isn’t quite a masterpiece because it isn’t a god tier piece of animation, but it is undoubtedly a good anime. The only real shortcoming is that it looks like some strange fetish anime on the cover (Mai’s revealing bunny girl outfit) as well as the title. This anime stands out among the otherwise mediocre anime season, and is my clear and justified pick for anime of the season.

Not many shows come close to this one, despite its looks, this show is a masterpiece complete with memorable characters, a wonderful story, great attention to detail, and some of the best and most heartfelt voice acting and writing i've ever seen in anime. I hope it gets as much attention and credit as it deserves. In one season, the amount of character development and love i have for the story as whole is insane. I never expected to find a show that left me feeling as empty as i did after watching Angel Beats but here it is. Do yourself a favor and watchit.

This show has so much going on, and it's all good. Its hard to put in words the feeling that I got when watching it, and how weird it feels now that it's over. I don't really think I'm gonna feel it again. Everything just resonated with me: the very calm way everyone delivers dialogue, the music, the character design (best girl Mai), and the overall story. There's just something about the way that Mai and Sakuta speak to each other that is so great, and funny in almost every line. 
On top of all the great comedy writing, Bunny Girl Senpai really knows howto make me feel for the characters. I'm not going to say any spoilers but there are many moments, you know if you've seen the anime, that are preeeetty emotional.


Everyone that likes romance anime should most definitely watch this because it feels different from others I've watched in a lot of good ways.


In summary, watch Bunny Girl Senpai.

Now, I have been seeing a lot of flak coming from the self-entitled "elitist" in the MAL community Dissing on this show for invalid reasons, but this is my letter to them, please stop hating a show just because it is popular.
It has been a while since I have seen such a refreshing take on the Romance/harem genre in anime, where most shows use very cheap "plot gimmicks" to attract its audience. Development is usually few and far between characters relationships as shows only tend to make the couple "get together" at the very last few episodes or when the plot calls for it, butI am glad Bunny Girl Senpai tries something different. Instead of trying to focus on the "grand world narrative", it is nice to see a show being heavily character centric, we see the world according to the eyes of our protagonist, and we see how the characters grow alongside our protagonist, in this case, it is Sakuta.\n\n
Just some short thoughts for this show as i doubt many people will read this anyways. Most people are probably on the love it camp. but if you don't like it, at least give it a fair rating instead of creating 20 spam accounts to give it the score of 1 and upscore JoJo's to 10. Thanks

Warning: Mild spoilers ahead.
INTERESTING! That is the word I would describe this anime. From the start to the end of the first episode my interest was piqued, there was not a dull moment in the first episode. This is one of the most interesting animes this season.
So we all have seen your typical romance genre anime, most romance nowadays try to spice things up by adding a supernatural factor in their romance and some have succeeded but most just fall flat. But this anime did it right, the air of mystery is present all through out the first few episodes and after the end ofeach episode I had more question than answers. Yet I want more of it. The romance factor is also really good a really good blend of romance, supernatural and comedy.


The characters in the anime are, well you guessed it, Interesting each character has their own backstory slowly being set up for later parts in the anime. Another factor that I cannot ignore is how many times I have grinned on how good the chemistry between the MCs. Their romance is something fresh and something that I haven't seen in a while in recent romance animes. 


One of the things this anime gets right is the pacing if there was a rating for pacing it would easily score a 10. Each part of the episode added more story but also added more questions. The soundtrack was beautiful and voice acting was on point. I also have to point out that they change the ending song for every character arc they are on and it makes it watching all the more worth while. Also these ending songs are sung by the voice actress of the current character in the arc.


With an interesting title and premise this anime has a lot to offer. And I cant wait for the next episode!

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wa Minai went under the radar for many anime watchers due to the hype for shows such as Goblin Slayer and Sword Art Online: Alicization, but it is undoubtedly one of the best shows currently airing.
Romantic comedies are rarely known for having good plots or characters, especially in anime where we are commonly given a dense main protagonist and a harem to back him up. Development is almost non-existence  and the only thing that is possibly keeping the watcher going is the cute character designs.
So what makes this show different from the rest? Granted thisshow is not exactly unique in any way but it definitely is very different, and I’ll explain why.


Story: In this show we are given a main protagonist, Sakuta Azusagawa, who helps people that are suffering from what’s known as “Adolescence Syndrome”. Adolescence Syndrome, as stated by the name, occurs in those in their adolescent stage of life and are inflicted when they experience great stress, instability, and turmoil. The show uses the Adolescence Syndrome as a way to address common problems faced by many high school students, many that you may consider relatable. But in reality, many choose to hide their problems rather than express them to others in order to solve them. In this show, those who suffer from great stress are inflicted with physical damage, in which the character is in a way forced to understand how they must solve their problems, otherwise they are unable to face society again. 

This sort of plot is definitely a leg up from many other cliche stories. Although only 4 episodes have released, it can be predicted Sakuta will be helping out different characters overtime, curing them of Adolescence Syndrome while developing himself as he learns about the problems many of his peers face. This is a very similar style of plot to Oregairu, TWOGK, and Kokoro Connect. But just like those shows, this show may become a repetitive repeat in which Sakuta finds someone with Adolescence Syndrome and cures them of it, unless it tries to gradually increase the severity of this disease.


Characters: Unarguably this show is highly focused on the characters that are being introduced. These characters are unique, as each one depicts a specific problem commonly faced throughout high school. Sakuta will learn of each problem and help each character out, while slowly developing himself. This is very similar to the characters of the shows aforementioned. But although the first 4 episodes of this show were quite good as well as the development of the characters, this show can easily fall and never be able to rise back to the top. As a show that is highly focused on the character, each time an arc ends, Sakuta and every new character introduced as well as the old ones must have a proper development. If only Sakuta gains development throughout the series, the other characters will become completely useless and we will be forced into an infinite story loop that will eventually cause the audience to lose interest. If, however, this loop does not occur, then get ready for one of the best romantic comedies to ever release in the anime universe.


Art and Sound: If you have seen my previous reviews, I do not take art as an important factor that determines how good a show is. Rather, I focus on the plot and characters, as I see art as a benefit rather than a requirement. However, this show’s art is still great. The designs of the characters are quite simple, and you can feel as if you yourself are in the high school experience. 

When it comes to Romantic Comedies, music isn’t exactly a popular factor. The music is quite good though, especially the ending in my opinion.


Enjoyment and Overall Rating: Overall this show has some of the greatest potential in this season. It is nice to see something different for a change, a drama that is well executed and a romantic comedy that does not focus on a dense main character, harem cast, and a selective comedic stance as well as large amounts of ecchi. However, this plot is nothing new, as we have commonly seen it in the past, especially from Oregairu, which has similar characters and a similar style of plot. If the next episodes are done well, we can have a great anime that addresses multiple and common challenges faced by high schoolers in reality, relatable and entertaining characters, and an almost unforgettable story. But if the character development fails, then this show will end up as a repetitive collection if predictable stories that is only entertaining at the beginning and progressively bores the audience into dropping the show. I have high hopes for this show’s success. 

Story:8 Art:8 Sound:8 Characters:8 Enjoyment:9 Overall:8

I'll be honest, I went into this anime with low expectations. I didn't think the show would take itself seriously, but my mind was immediately changed with one of the most engaging first episodes I have ever seen. The characters are developed quickly and surprisingly appear realistic. In case you live under a rock, there is an ongoing debate about who is the "best girl" but it's impossible to decide because there are so many! 
If you enjoy moments that cut to the heart, this anime is for you. Each and every second of every scene has a purpose and it warms you more thanit probably should. The show burns through arcs at a steady pace, constantly keeping you on the edge of your seat, but somehow manages to tie everything together. There is just the right amount of tension to keep it interesting without becoming unsettling. My only critique is the so-called "pseudoscience" that it likes to play around with but, unless you are a psychology major, I wouldn't worry too much about it. Even with that minor flaw, the show is truly intelligent.


What really made Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai wonderful, however, is the wit. The entire cast is filled with a clever vocabulary and is just waiting to use it. Every conversation makes you laugh, groan, or shed a tear, and in the end, there's nothing more I could ask for. 


~Jackun

Bunny Girl Senpai had a pretty interesting start in terms of reception. It feels like many people dismissed it as yet another trashy ecchi/harem LN adaptation thanks to the name and rather erotic cover art. Yet, as more people got to see it, many were quick to point out how the poor Bunny Girl was misrepresented and how it’s not a generic ecchi show but actually a very thoughtful anime about problems people face during adolescence.
At first I bought that myself but after actually watching the show I have to disagree. BGS is hardly different from a run of the mill romcom. We follow Sakuta,a character that’s supposed to be your normal relatable outcast with nothing special about him but shows his “amazing” qualities when he turns out to be the only one capable of saving the girl in every new arc. 


This is where the only real gimmick of BGS comes in, the Puberty Syndrome. That’s what this anime calls a mental illness brought about by unstable and stressful life of a teenager but in reality is so vague there’s no point to see it as anything more than “dumb thing that tried to justify more dumb shit happening”. Think of it as oddities in Monogatari but if they were done extremely poorly, more on that later. 


Whole show can be broken down into arcs, each revolving around a particular girl with their own problem. Not a lot of stuff carries over though and when one girl is “solved” they become more or less irrelevant and stop playing a meaningful role in the story. Even the titular Bunny Girl, Mai Sakurajima, eventually starts feeling like a background decoration that only serves as an excuse to shove in more perverted jokes or romance so basic and plain it makes Naruto seem like Anna Karenina.


With that out of the way, let’s get into more detail. I think for this show to be at the very least more than passable it needs to have either of two things: interesting characters that get fleshed out or developed over the course of the story or a strong gimmick with interesting mechanics that would serve as an excuse for some high concept scenarios that combine psychology and physics. 


BGS has neither of those. Main characters alone are a good example, especially considering that they’re supposed to get the most attention. 


Sakuta, our protagonist, is less interesting than a box with “don’t put fingers inside” written on it. At least with that box I wonder what’s inside and with Sakuta the answer is obvious from the start, nothing. He feels more like a self-insert for chuunis and other nerds rather than a real person. A lot, if not most of his dialogue revolves around perverted, low brow jokes that also make up 90% of comedy in the show. Telling a girl how his imagination is much more perverted than she thinks he is, how he’s gonna enjoy the sound of a showering girl or how he’s delighted to have a cute girl step on him. These remarks never lead to anything and girls just brush them off after providing some cliche “moooou yada ;///;” tier response cause he’s just such a charmer. There’s even an older lady reporter that just seems to want to fuck him for some reason, it’s less egregious in the anime but very heavy handed in LN. 

When Sakuta is not a braindead pervert he’s somehow a warrior or justice. Telling off someone taking a photo of Mai without her knowing, beating up an athlete for spreading lewd rumors about Koga, threatening to call the cops on random pervert messaging Rio’s twitter account and in general going above an beyond to help out any woman he sees. This is all explained by him having empathy for people who are put in a situation where others can’t empathize with them, which just so happened to apply to every damsel he saves. 

In the end, I think his characterization as both some selfless messiah going against flow and a horny worthless teenagers is a very incoherent combination, which is part of makes him feel like a self-insert. Characters like that are often flawed but those flaws are never acknowledged and more often made to seem as something charming. It’s a fantasy of being special without actually being special in any way, that’s Sakuta.


His girlfriend, Mai, will take much less words to describe because despite being the second most important character she has fucking nothing. Her whole issue was that she’s a super popular mega star and she wants to get away from that, wishing that nobody knew her. Because of this, people start forgetting her and become unable to see her. Some pseudo-science bullshit later she’s completely fine again and we get to know her for who she really is, a mild tsundere. She fires off your typical “I don’t like this but I actually like this” trite and constantly teases Sakuta. Maybe two or three times she shows some other emotions, hinting at some drama spicing up their relationship but every time it either doesn’t actually matter, or in case of the ending stops mattering after Sakuta accomplishes an amazing feat of going from point A to point B using public transportation, truly nothing is impossible when you’re in love.


Going over side characters makes things seem a lot more sad. Kunimi, Sakuta biggest friend is just there, he’s a nice guy who shows up a few times to do nothing. 

At least his other friend, Rio, gets a few episodes but there’s the same problem of bad execution. We get a few scenes showing she’s loves Kunimi even though he already has a girlfriend and that causes her frustration and then show fucking jumps to “I took lewd pics of myself cause I wanted attention” which gets solved by Sakuta just hanging out with her and Kunimi riding a bicycle to her place after Sakuta calls him in the middle of the night. 

Koga appears about as suddenly as she vanishes, she’s a village girl who changed herself to fit in with the city crowds and worries about doing something that would hurt her reputation, that’s it.

Nodoka admires her sister, Mai, but at the same time suffers from her mother expecting her to achieve the same success.

Makinohara Shouko is not really a character. Apparently LNs do something with her later on but as far as anime goes she’s just some entity that shows up to motivate Sakuta.

Kaede, Sakuta’s sister is terrible too but there’s also another problem associated with her and a few spoilers so that’s for later.



Now, onto the second issue. The pseudo-science or bullshit known as Puberty Syndrome. 


As dumb as it is  I don’t think it’s completely without merit. If this part was actually developed I think the show would at least be able to invoke some curiosity simply by making you wonder what it will do next.


BSG as is fails to do that cause of all the supernatural things that happen, none of them get any clever use. I won’t even mention the mechanics of Puberty Syndrome in general cause those aren’t a thing. There’s no consistency to how it works or how effects manifest outside of all victims being teenagers with some frustrations or insecurities. Not like the show sticks to its own premise of Puberty Syndrome being a psychological issue because they try to explain everything with some of the dumbest faux-physics I’ve seen in a while. 

People can’t see you? That’s because Observer effect, you know? It’s like with Schroedinger’s Cat you know? None of those things fucking fit the situation but author will throw out those concepts regardless, seemingly just to make it seem like the work is way more complex than it actually is cause he sure as hell doesn’t demonstrate any sort of understanding of the concepts he mentions. That is further cemented by the show usually forgetting it said anything about physics after initial explanation and going for a more supernatural take on things. With Sakurajima for example, this went from Schroedinger’s Cat and Observer theory to “she ignored everyone at school, not wanting to avoid the attention and that made other students become unable to see her and forget memories they had of her”. Sakuta at one points asks a fair question, if this is a problem with how she acts a school, why did it spread over seemingly entire country? To which the reply is something among the lines of people unconsciously carrying this “atmosphere” with them similarly to how there’s some social standards and norms that people might adhere to without realizing. A terrible explanation but at least it’s not as pretentious as trying to explain it with science.


After Mai fading out of existence, next story concerns what is by all means a time loop but wait, that’s too simple for BGS. This ain’t a time loop dude, it’s LAPLACE’S DEMON. Time isn’t actually looping, you’re just living in a simulation launched by a school girl who wants to reject a boy without making it seem like he’s trash, cause her friend likes the guy. Why does a simulation loop by the day instead of only repeating relevant window of time? Why is Sakuta in it? We actually get an attempt at answering the second question, apparently it’s because of quantum entanglement, just smash my head in this is dumb. 


Other cases of PS aren’t nearly as severe. We get a body swap caused by jealousy/adoration, doppelganger cause by dissociating. This all feeds into the problem of these problems not only of the gimmick being rather tame but also them not being used well.


When people stop to see Mai the most she tries is wearing a bunny girl outfit to make sure someone will notice her but not only does she drop that after the first time you see it but she also seems to stop any real attempts to make people notice her until convinced to do so by Sakuta. Despite people not seeing or remembering her, they can still feel her physically. While it’s not a surefire way to make people remember her, it’s weird how they never even tried to convince people that she exists by having her move objects in front of them, pushing and pulling people or imprinting her palm or face on something. In the end it feels like author didn’t know what to do with it himself cause this is all literally solved through the power of love, somehow, Sakuta yelling about how he loves Mai gives people a reason why she would exist. 


The apex of missed opportunities are the time loop episodes. Time loops are an excellent way to explore characters and everything resetting the next day is a really good excuse to mess with things. Look no further than Groundhog’s Day for an example of how much potential this premise has. So what does BGS do with time loops? Pretty much nothing. First episode only has things repeat a few times with Sakuta at most using it to change a few conversations and not by experimenting what response his words would get but using the conclusion of the original conversation to reach it faster. Then a classic misunderstanding happens and a guy Koga was trying to avoid thinks she’s dating Sakuta so the time loop breaks. After an episode of fake dating to keep the pretenses she falls in love for real and time loops again in hopes he will respond to her feelings. How does it go? Well, he just goes along with it and keeps doing the same shit until telling her “stop, I won’t change my mind” and tells her to be herself.
