Doppelganger due to dissociating? Just be yourself. Don’t feel like going back to making movies? Just be yourself. Scared to do something wrong? Just be yourself. Jealous of your successful sister you can’t live up to? Just be yourself. 


No experimentation, no depth, no creativity. If not for the two elements I talked about already, maybe in its intention to solve common insecurities of teenagers, BGS would get some points for a sincere attempt to explore these issues, but no. Psychological element of BGS is an anime equivalent of a facebook motivational pictures that recite shallow quotes of unknown, kitchen philosophers in fancy font on top of a pretty background or twitter posts that tell people that drinking water and working out will cure their depression so depressed people have no reason to whine about it. None of the issues present are shown with any sort of nuance. It’s almost insulting how casually author used real things that can actually fuck people up for cheap tearjerkers while pretending that there’s something more to it.


This peaks in final episodes relating to Sakuta’s sister and I’d consider what follows a spoiler if it had any impact behind it. Kaede was bullied online for not leaving a reply from her group of friends on “read” and not replying. I know, sounds dumb but we’re talking about dumb teenagers so it wasn’t too hard to accept that something like this was traumatic for her. Either way, the trauma of it makes her faint and lose all prior memories which takes a toll on her mother who straight up goes insane. Don’t worry, BGS doesn’t actually show the parents perspective or explain why daughter’s amnesia made her mother spill her marbles, it’s just there for you to feel bad about the whole thing. Sakuta keeps his cool though and comforts Kaede, telling her not to worry about who she was and thinking only about her current self. He encourages her to keep a diary and write down her thoughts, limits her from interacting with outside to avoid trauma and brings her some books and movies to keep her entertained. Until the end of the show he does pretty much nothing to fix her problem with going outside or interacting with people which lasted for TWO years until she herself wants to fix the issue due to… Sakuta bringing a bunch of girls to their apartment. Little by little she starts to push herself. Answering the phone, going a few steps outside and gradually taking it further. This actually proves effective and after fainting again she wakes up with her old memories intact but without memories of her last two years of being a shut-in. How does Sakuta react? He tells her he needs to go take a piss and books it the hell out of the hospital, crying and yelling, acting like she literally died. Not even a trace of being happy for his sister can be seen even after he more or less gets over it. What the actual fuck is this? How is your sister remembering her formative years and all the other important memories such a gigantic tragedy? I get being somewhat sad that last two years were erased but this is too much. Go and see videos and interviews of people who lost memory at older age. They don’t know who they are, who people around them are. They don’t know where they live or really anything around them. They look at their own photos without a shred of nostalgia simply because they have absolutely no context for them. Imaging that all the memories you hold dear and everything that formed your identity just disappearing. That’s a very tragic and traumatic thing in and of itself and Sakuta acts like his sister fucking died when she gets those memories back and then we even get a montage of his sister talking as if she died too and framing her path towards recovery as some form of suicide. It’s incredibly distasteful. What makes it even worse is that in the post credits sequence all of this supposedly dramatic shit is gone cause when she reads the diary she gets the knowledge of what happens and her slightly different personality is implied to have gone back to the way she was shown before. There was nothing to stop the author from setting up her past as being something she might be best off forgetting in which case a switch from positive improvement and being happy back to painful memories would be easier to see as something troubling. Why even pull this whole “I cry every tiem” tier shit when you’re gonna act like everything’s cool the next day? That’s not even me decrying morals of the show but a glaring inconsistency for the sake of having manipulative melodrama.


Now, it’s not wholly bad. I’ll admit it’s somewhat easy on the eyes. Not too pretty and character designs are very forgettable but there’s some nice scenery here and there and a few cases of good animation. In general it’s very average but at least that means it doesn’t get add to the garbage fire. Voice actors deserve some praise for the work on this series. If not for their heartfelt voice acting it would be impossible for me to even remotely sympathize with these poorly written characters. 


While show is chock full of holes it at the very least is not another case of a terrible adaptation. I’ve read the first volume before watching to make sure that it’s not fault of the show of not being faithful to the source material. If anything it makes it better by cutting enough excess to fill in a few extra episodes that added nothing to the narrative. At times it becomes a bit too fast in places but that’s a minor flaw in the big picture. My biggest problem with the pacing was that it often didn’t give any breathing room for characters to get along and make progression of their relationship more gradual but to some extent this still applies to the light novel.


Hard to say to what extent Bunny Girl Senpai nailed what it was going for considering how many people enjoyed it for it’s melodrama and bargain bin Monogatari elements but I think it failed on pretty much every front. It doesn’t have a single well written character, supernatural or paranormal parts of it are tame and left unexplored, melodrama constantly shits on common sense and even comedy is gets stale. That’s a hard pass.

WARNING: This review assumes you have already viewed the series in full.
WARNING 2: This review most certainly WILL BE personally insulting to those who rate this series highly.
You have been warned.
Ah, so I return to viewing and reviewing anime after 2 years or so.
And this series was clearly at the top of my list, based on hype and comparisons to the Monogatari series.
Where to begin..
This anime made complete sense once I stepped back into the shoes of a teenager.
And I don't mean that I was only able to appreciate this show's profound themes of personal growth by turning back the clock to when I, too,experienced the same struggles as the show's relatable cast.


No, that's something I would say about actually good shows about growing up like FLCL.


What I mean is that, once I dumbed myself back down, it became clear to me what the source was for all of the unequivocal failings of this series, especially in comparison to many shows it is frequently compared to, if not outright draws from.  It also explained the hype and controversy over this shallow husk of a series.


If you look at raving reviews of this series, you will find a common thread:

"Based on the title and poster, you may think show seems like a shallow ecchi harem series, but you would be mistaken if that is what you came in for."


Let's run that through the "self-important teenager speak" translator:

"I am able to enjoy shows like this thanks to my superior intellect and taste, unlike you commoners who only watch anime for mecha battles and oppai.  You just lack the superior intellect and taste to appreciate a show like this, as I."


Cringe Central.


Let's talk about the various "offerings" of this anime to analyze how shallow and empty it is, and how it sets the trap of appearing as an intelligent, counterculture anime.


First of all, the elephant in the room. The titular Bunny Girl Senpai, and no doubt the main selling point of this show, despite its fans insisting they like it for the deep dialogue about Schroedinger's Cats (we'll get there).

She is basically the ideal girlfriend in the mind of someone who apparently hasn't interacted with real girls much, and bases his expectations of romance based on watching anime romance.

Bunny Girl Senpai comes from a long and prestigious line of popular waifus, including the likes of Kasumigaoka Utaha, Yukino Yukinoshita, and of course, Senjougahara Hitagi herself.  Dark hair, darker wit.  An actual senpai or has that dynamic.  Sardonic and witty.  Brain and Beauty. S to the male lead's M. Skyward tsurime eyes. The disproving gaze. The potential for GAP. Ara ara ufufu

Despite the fans' insistence that this show is not about moe girls, the series pushes you to fall in love with Mai-senpai at every turn.  "Check out our flagship waifu," the show nags, "she is basically a moe version of Senjougahara!"  "And, in case you get bored of her, you might be interested in our selection of: the Science Chick, the Genki Dojikko, the Childhood Friend, the LOLi Imouto, the..."  I could go on.


As an undying fan of Monogatari, and as someone who firmly believes that Senjougahara Hitagi is the most genius and game-changing anime character so far in the 21st century, Bunny Girl is really not a Senjougahara clone she was clearly attempted to be.  Not even close.

She's actually more comparable to Spice and Wolf's Horo, in that she is the breakout waifu who carries the show's popularity, despite fans' vehement insistence on liking the show for being "deep."  And, most notably, the show's creators freely lean on their waifu status to divert attention from poor writing.

She is sharp-tongued and sharp-witted (at least to teenagers) when she needs to be in order to fulfill her duty as a Senjougahara clone and cater to that aspect of the author's fantasy.

This is strategically interspersed with her being inexplicably ingenue and flustered when she needs to be that way in order to pander to her status as a waifu material in the author's fantasies.  This is a downright failure on the part of the author to realize that part of what made Senjougahara so appealing to himself and everyone was the very fact that she would never do this.  Because no well-written character does this.


There are certain character archetypes, especially so in female anime characters.  That is an undeniable, indeed unavoidable, fact, and not necessarily a negative thing either.

What does matter is how well and how sincerely that character is written.

Look at the real big ones, like Rei from NGE and Faye V. from Bebop.  They are not at all free of typical anime girl tropes, including blatant fanservice.  However, this does not at all lessen the impact and dept of their characters and their influence on subsequent works.  This is because their characters are grounded in real life people's characteristics, therefor natural and consistent.  They have various flaws that even seem annoying at times, but they are ultimately memorable because they remind us of real people, despite being presented at times as pure fanservice.

I mean, of course, I get that their characters would be ridiculous and unrealistic when literally transferred to reality, but if there really was a person like that in a world like that, they would be realistic and consistent, and therefore interesting people. In BG Senpai, the characters are inconsistent, the world is inconsistent, and put together they are incredibly inconsistent, if rather convenient for the titillation of the authors' (and, by extension, the viewers') fantasy. This fantasy goes something like:

"Effortlessly Cool Messiah Makes All The Girls Swoon, But Lo And Behold, He is CANONICALLY MONOGAMOUS with the obvious and heavily advertised ULTIMATE WAIFU. (and that's still totally deep and intellectual because there's so little visual fanservice and everyone talks so softly EXCEPT THAT ONE SISLOLI OMG)"

Mai-san, or rather, Bunny Girl Senpai, is based on the author's understanding of people as portrayed by various anime waifu tropes, and not at all about how people really are.

Well-written characters, reflecting real people, have a central motive that consistently drives them.  It may not be obvious or specific, and it may not be 100% of what's on the character's mind at all times, but it governs their thoughts and actions, as well as their character arcs.

The only "consistent" motive BG Senpai has throughout the series is to be a titillating girlfriend to the male lead, and by extension, the author and the viewers.  The rest of her character traits fluctuate wildly depending on whatever the author at the time fantasizes would be the most adorable and romantic situations, again, based on his favorite animes, rather than real people.  Naturally, her only real character "arc" or "development" is that she increasingly becomes a more and more ideal waifu to the male lead as the show goes on.  That's it.

You would argue that her big motive is to get back to her acting career, and you would be wrong.  That wish of hers is only shallowly mentioned throughout the series, whenever it would be convenient to portray the side of her that is professional and admirable.  Her actions throughout the series do not reflect this drive consistently, as she seems to be quite content being the ideal waifu to the male lead and the school idol.

She doesn't stand alone as a character, but exists solely to cater to the "ideal girlfriend" fantasy of the male lead, and by extension the author and readers.


Speaking of her relationship with the male lead, it is the most unbelievable and cringey "romance," even considering how unrealistic romance tends to be portrayed in anime.

Their relationship is nothing more than a fulfillment of a fantasy in the author's mind, and by extension, male teenage viewers.

She is a renowned beauty queen and a national celebrity.  And yet, she is completely reserved for the male lead.  She is a pure virgin with little experience with boys, and apparently has a special, existential, and completely unexplained link with the male lead that all but guarantees his chance with her.

Seriously, did you ever have those fantasies in high school where your crush is a super popular girl and you can't even approach her, but one day an apocalyptic event occurs, only leaving you and her alive on Earth?  And, as time passed, you would come to lean on each other more and more, until... yeah.

That is literally how "deep" their relationship is.  It's the daydream of someone who's not really met girls in real life and believes that the perfect waifu can be won over in a short conversation that showcases what a unique, edgy, and intelligent guy you are.  Then she will see how different you are from all the handsome jocks and rich moviestars around her. "Oh, my love, you are the first one to treat me like a normal girl and tell toilette jokes in front of me.  Hold me as I swoon."  Please wake the F up.

It's a lazy romance daydream for guys who blame their unpopularity on how they're "too intelligent compared to peers and misunderstood.  It's that cringey fantasy about how the perfect girl will somehow be swept off her feet by the sheer display of your intellect and enlightened ways.

There is no "chemistry" between the leads.  Senjougahara and freaking Kaiki show more chemistry in 5 seconds of the Okinawa airport scene in Koimonogatari than the entire Bunny Girl Senpai.


And don't get me started on the male lead.  I don't even remember his name, so forgettable he was.  Continuing with a common theme in this anime, Sakuta (l just looked up his name) is apparently what the author (and, by extension, male teenage viewers) fantasizes himself as.  Laid-back and comfortable with himself, apparently a high-school student who doesn't care about what others think of him?  Yeah, that's realistic.  You just know the author also had no sense of presence back in school, but it's all okay because he's like that because he's okay with it, not, you know, because he's just thoroughly unpopular.  He's friendless by CHOICE, alright?  And, despite not possessing any notable qualities, or any significant effort to grow as a person, girls are swept off their feet by these spontaneous, grand romantic gestures he occasionally whips out.  Seriously, guys, stop daydreaming.  That is not how it works, and these big romantic gestures will completely backfire on you and just be cringey as F, at least if you do it like in this show. You are not, and you don't "identify with" this absolutely lazy and featureless character who gets girls to fall for him by virtue of random romantic gestures that, more often than not, actually endanger the girl physically or socially in an exceedingly selfish and reckless urge to show off.  Really, go try announcing to the whole school about your undying love for the most popular girl in your school and a national celebrity, 3 days into meeting her.  See how that works out.  If you really pull that off, and you can document the event to me, I will revise this review to say "This is the epitome of anime, and (insert your name) is a god."


Even Araragi Koyomi, even freaking Hachiman, had realistic, believable reason for being the way they were.  Hachiman's character is grudgingly likable and realistic because, after those rather unrealistic and cringey outburst of selfless social suicide by Hachiman, he is shown to be agonizing over the impulsive decision, being embarrassed to death, just like any real person would.  And despite him claiming to be a loner by choice, he is clearly seen to be struggling with loneliness and insecurity, JUST LIKE ANY REAL PERSON other than some nobody's pathetic delusion of who they really are. In stark contrast, Sakuta in Bunny Girl Senpai is some kind of Nietzschean ubermensch who doesn't care about how others think of him.  He really is a loner BY CHOICE.  He is exactly what the author (and, by extension, the teenage viewers) WANT to see themselves as: being loners due to being too intelligent, too deep, too misunderstood, not at all because they are fundamentally unlikable, self-absorbed, and honestly just not popular.


This would go on for pages if I listed off every example of how poorly, and LAZILY written the two main characters and their relationship are.  About how the show constantly uses TEH ULTIMATE WAIFU as a get out of jail free card for covering up bad writing.  So let's discuss some other characters.


THE SCIENCE GIRL.  I'm pretty sure her name is Futaba, but honestly don't care.  She is the "science" character of someone who's never interacted with real scientists and only learned science through anime.  The scientific concepts she discusses are not real science, but "science" for someone who only learned science through anime.  If you really thought the bits about Schroedinger's Cat and LaPlace Demon were "deep" and "intellectual," I feel really bad for you because you are apparently an unpopular daydreamer who ALSO has bad grades.  There is really nothing going for you, my friend.  At least unpopular nerds who are actually smart get a second chance in college and a third chance in working life.

And I say that not to be mean, but in complete faith that nobody, not even the people who like the show, would be so clueless as to find one iota of scientific, philosophical, or otherwise cognitive stimulation from the "Science Talks with the Science Girl" segments.


THE POPULAR ATHELETIC FRIEND.  I don't even vaguely remember his name, and honestly it would have made zero difference if he was introduced as "token popular friend -kun."  Literally the only reason for his existence is to establish that Sakuta is indeed "unpopular by choice."  He CAN easily hang out with the cool kids, if he wanted to, but he DECIDES not to because he is already at peace with his spot in the teenage social tapestry.


Notice a trend here?  Every character and every interaction in this show exists to further facilitate the author's (and, by extension, the teenage viewers') fantasy of being this cool, suave, naturally charismatic guy, who is too intellectual and mature to play the social game, NOT, let me remind you again and again, because they simply lack the qualities that make popular people popular.


I could go on and on about the failings of this show, but I am surprised by how long it's already gotten just from the few examples off the top of my head.


Ugh, actually, let's do just one more, since it's a biggie:

Kaede the "I'm not a loli imouto" (more like LOLimouto)

Bros, this is NOT how you write a character arc.

First, there is no argument against the fact that her character's sole purpose is to pander to the loli little sister fantasy in the author's mind.

I already hear the outrage: 'But no, she has a tragic back story as the victim of the Adolescence Syndrome."

First of all, if you want to portray a sympathetic little girl sadly afflicted with a mental disorder, you DON'T nicely package that "mental disorder" in a kawaii panda outfit and market it to the siscons, with direct explicit incest tease lines thrown in.  Aww, the poor girl has cancer; let's dress her up and blow up our Instragram. For the majority of the show, Kaede is NOT portrayed as a poor trouble little girl whose childlike mannerisms are the result of a tragic incident.

No, she is either a fetish bait for people who are into siscon/lolicon. And for people who are not into that, she is basically a Jar Jar Binks who speaks several times louder than every other character in an annoying and unrealistic baby girl speak, while not contributing anything to the story.

There is no foreshadowing or plot-relevant mention that her Syndrome is causing her to behave in this unrealistic, annoying manner.  You are apparently supposed to just roll with it and see her as an adorable object of your sisconic love, until the very end, when oh, apparently that part of her dies, and we have a moment of silence for the passing of the imaginary 2-year old lolibait.  

The only reason I found her character unsettling and disturbing was because it was actually unsettling and disturbing, NOT because the show hinted at the dark origins of her current state.  Come on, bros, this is fiction writing 101, and if you didn't notice gaping holes like this, then honestly my only expectation is that you are gullible and you fell for this show's trap hook, line, and sinker.  The lazy writers of this show shaped your thoughts with sickly sweet romance with BUNNY GIRL SENPAI and made you subconsciously forgive every bit of lazy writing that should have annoyed you.

Kaede-chan is not a realistic, deep representation of.. whatever she was supposed to represent.  She is another convenient PROP to further gratify the author's (and, by extension, the teenage viewers') fantasy of having a cute, obedient little sister.


Frankly, this is how I see this anime happening:


1. Author - OMG how good was Bakemonogatari.  Ima write a fanfic, except Senjougahara is going to be more moe and they will be more lovey dovey~!

2. Investors - Dude, I hear SHAFT execs still wipe their butt with Bakemonogatari money.  Let's do a cheap imitation of it.  Hey, look this LN's basically got the formula down.

3. Fans - YES pretty girl!  And she's witty, so I don't seem shallow!


Let me hastily wrap up this review because more discussion will only go back to the same point: 


This is a shallow anime and a shallow trap for those who mistakenly think they have better taste and that they are misunderstood by their peers, when the truth is that they are actually dismissed and ignored by their peers.  It is a 13-minute long masturbation session by the author fantasizing about winning over perfect waifus with grand romantic gestures (that require zero actual effort or growth on his part and apparently are without any consequence)  and his self-delusion of inherent maturity and depth.  The trap is constructed to fool you into thinking there is inherent maturity and depth in the show and that you, the viewer, are specially mature and deep for praising this show, when in reality, it is essentially the dirtiest ecchi only without visual nudity, and just as unrealistic harem anime as those you specifically criticize in order to assert your "good taste" and "superior intellect."  You didn't enjoy this show because it was "deep" or it taught you anything meaningful about the human condition.  You praise this show because it had a pretty bunny girl senpai in it who caressed and stimulated your deepest, most unrealistic, most shameful fantasies without explicitly showing nudity and sexuality that would have made you feel guilty and shallow and hesitant about praising this anime to others.


Now, if you will excuse me, I must clear the overnight run of this mediocre series by going through Monogatari again, and reveling in how intelligent and self-aware an anime series can really be.

I came for the sexy bunny girl, I stayed for the intriguing mystery and drama, but in the end neither was delivered on.
There is very little sexual titillation happening here, the mystery and intrigue leads absolutely nowhere, and the drama is just stupid and makes no sense, in spite of going as far as trying to use popular pseudo science babble to pretend it's clever.
This is trash, pure and simple! The only reason I score it as high as a six, is because it did keep me watching.
It's not very rewarding to watch, but it keeps tricking you into wanting to see how it goes!There's a half dozen far better animes lying around half watched on my HD just because they didn't manage to hook me this way, and that's why I must give some credit to this manipulative trash for at least keeping me hooked until the pointless end. 


But I felt totally empty afterwards. Nothing that happens or is said here makes a lick of sense, and there is no payoff to anything. A random person/event may hint at some grand mystery, but it is never resolved. What you think was a clever setup for a later plot reveal was just a clever setup to make you keep watching by baiting you with some random bullshit that isn't connected to anything.


The characters are likewise empty and senseless, but they do project an aura of seeming like they might be something more than what they seem at first. It just turns out they were actually just as empty and senseless as they seemed in the end, and the aura of potentially interesting development was once again just meticulously crafted to sucker you into watching.


Everything in this show only makes sense if you watch it passively like a zombie without connecting any dots in your mind, because if you do you'll soon notice the dots just don't fit into a coherent whole.


For example, our main dude is an introverted social outcast, SO YOU CAN RELATE TO HIM, YOU FILTHY OTAKU YOU!


But he also has lots of friends, has great social skills, and is super relaxed around girls, and has godly self confidence, and beats up jocks with an attitude problem without breaking a sweat or losing his cool. In other words, this character makes no sense at all and cannot actually exist in the real world, because he breaks the fundamental laws of human psychology. ALL SO YOU CAN FANTASIZE ABOUT BEING COOL, YOU FILTHY OTAKU YOU!


Our main dude's love interest is another introverted social outcast people ignore to the point where they literally can't see her, and who is at the same time admired by everyone because she is super talented in everything, and she is of course also drop dead gorgeous, and a super famous TV star. In other words, this character makes no sense at all either, and is an insult to the laws of logic. ONCE AGAIN, ALL SO THE FILTHY OTAKU VIEWER CAN FANTASIZE ABOUT GETTING THE PLAIN JANE NEXT DOOR HE'S TOO CHICKEN TO TALK TO, EXCEPT HE ALSO GETS TO PRETEND SHE'S ACTUALLY SUPER HOT.


(It's kind of annoying when a writer projects qualities he despises on his audience, and then tries to pander to his own projection this way. But whatever, it's anime, and this pattern isn't exactly uncommon... If I took serious offense to being treated like scum I'd probably stop watching anime altogether. lol!)


The two leads have what seems like cool and quirky/funny banter going on when they're flirting, but it really isn't anything of the sort. It just *seems* like it is cool and quirky/funny on the surface, but if you stop and think about what they're saying for a second, none of it makes any sense. Their attitude towards each other makes no sense, and the content of their conversation is equally senseless.


And then they apparently "fall in love" and start dating, which is the cue for the girl to make herself scarce for the rest of the show, to make room for the main dude hanging around with other girls and building his harem. BECAUSE THE FILTHY OTAKU VIEWER  WANTS TO DREAM ABOUT BEING A LADY KILLER.


Except it's all totally innocent of course, he never has any lewd intentions with any of the harem padding girls, and he is super in love with the main girl. BECAUSE THE FILTHY OTAKU VIEWER WANTS TO SEE HIMSELF AS NOBLE AND FAITHFUL.


The main love interest never gives our main dude any sugar throughout the entire show by the way. She comes off as disinterested and/or mean towards him, depending on her time of the month or something. Meanwhile he manages to come off as disinterested to the entire world, her included, and yet somehow obsessed with her and totally devoted to her at the same time. When he's not busy building his 100 % platonic harem.


This show was clearly intended to come off as looking unique and "deep", while secretly pandering to the filthy Otaku the writer thinks is his audience, but it's really just a senseless and boring mess.

Rascal, Bunny Girl, and the Misinterpretation

2018 is indeed, a strange year for anime. Stretching from the melodramatic effect from Violet Evergarden, high tension of Megalobox, and goofy comedic aspect from Hinamatsuri, it sure is a bizarre phenomenon that captures most of our heart. While entering the last 3 months of its legacy, a wild, eye-catching, and fluffy (if you want to call it so) Bunny Girl appeared with a solid promise of 13 episodes. Hyped by some but unknown by the other, Rascal Does not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai (or I’ll just call it ‘Bunny Girl Senpai’) seems like your typical highschool romance anime that repeats every year with the same plot all over again. Fortunately for Bunny Girl Senpai, that was not the case.


Bunny Girl Senpai is one of the most, let’s say ‘influential’, anime of 2018. From the poster itself, resembles an ambiguous and obscure description of the series’ entirety. One would probably judge the anime by its poster, and reach a conclusion that this is a harem anime. Let me convinced you that it wasn’t like that, in fact, Bunny Girl Senpai doesn’t even bring that subject at all. It was a bouncy ride at first, but if we zoom out our vision and understand it from a bigger scope, I believe that Bunny Girl Senpai can deliver us to a satisfying journey.


There are some arcs in this anime that really caught my attention, one of which is the Koga’s Arc (the part that Koga and Sakuta tried to solve a problem together). From my understanding and point of view, Koga’s Arc resembles problems and delusions that teenagers are facing nowadays, and they use a very good interpretation to express the following case. I was completely flattered and it reminds me of my days in high school when I did something similar to the main protagonist’s doing. It was a sad moment.


Another example of Bunny Girl’s advantages is that it stays on the structure of puberty and adolescent problems. Other anime may differ to a different angle of the story after a few or more episodes, creating unbalanced and undecided move to direct the story afterwards. Although it combined supernatural (some will call this science fiction?) elements to it, I think Bunny Girl’s story is still acceptable and pretty enjoyable at its core.


Moving on to my next point, some people are complaining that some arcs are not that great. For me, it was Nodoka-Mai’s Arc that bored me the most. I mean, it’s not a bad arc, it was decent with some pretty shaky and surprisingly good ending to it, but I think the placement of that arc is a bit misconducted. Bunny Girl only had 13 episodes and I just can’t find a good excuse to put that arc in a -near end- tight spot. I understand the possibilities for season 2 and the movie in the future, but I consider that a bleak direction to make. 


After finishing the whole series, I sat on my couch for a moment and then reflected of what just happened in the series. Like, it explicitly mentions some great issues, such as puberty or adolescent syndrome (not the real name, but you get the point) and how the people around us still haven’t realized how bad it is. I don’t know about you, but this series touched me in a different way from the other series. Overall, I will say that Bunny Girl a binge-worthy anime with some slight issues that are probably overlooked by its deep and emotional adventure.

I’ll keep this really brief, since I just wanted to interject my thoughts on why I rated Bunny Senpai low:
Bunny Senpai peaks at episode 3. The show goes downhill after that.
The dialogue while witty, comes off pretentious and doesn’t sound like the type of conversations teens would say 
The supernatural adolescence syndromes are poorly explained. They’re plot devices that happen so Sakuta can help each girl until they conveniently fade away after they’ve addressed their problems. Then afterwards his big tiddie science friend tries to link it to Quantum physics to again make it all sound smart, but is really just pseudo intellectual bullshit.
The showconstantly depicts Sakuta as this ‘good person’, but most of the time he acts like perverted, sarcastic asshole that it’s hard to relate to him.

The last time I got emotional from watching an anime was Madoka Magica, one of the first shows I watched when I started almost a year ago. Since then, nothing has been able to get to me in comparison, although Plastic Memories did get somewhat close. Then this show came around.
At first, I didn't know what to expect, thinking, "This show is probably just another romance anime," and putting it at the bottom of my Plan-to-watch list. How I was wrong. This show is so much more than that. Every character goes through problems that many of us have gone through or are currently goingthrough, just to a more exaggerated extent for the sake of story. It is very easy to become connected to all the characters, and their development throughout the story is outstanding. You laugh with them, and you cry with them. You genuinely care about every character. Rarely can you say that about an anime anymore, and after watching this, I can say just about no other show can compare.\n\n
This is no Bakemonogatari clone, even if it seems to follow the same basic idea and does have some similarities. This is its own story, one that will be remembered for years to come.\n
To the authors, directors, and all the staff who created this wonderful show, ありがとうございました。

All of the suspiciously convenient plot devices and countless Ex Machina's really rustled my jimmies. I mean I don't come in to any anime expecting to be an accurate representation of life, but this one went a bit overboard. I believe this anime is best enjoyed if you just don't put too much thought in to it. You won't realize the absurdity of it and just enjoy the mediocre ride. 
You accidentally fell in the beach? Better go to the hospital.
You ran around in the rain for like 4 minutes? Better go to the damn hospital.
Oh thank you 16 year old classmate with an IQof 260 accurately explaining all of my situation with quantum physics and other stuff that normal 16 year olds know.


I don't know whether to commend the storyline or not. On one hand, it's borderline plagiarism to the Monogatari series with not as much breasts. On the other hand, it still was enjoyable. The character arcs throughout the story were really well executed, Kaede's arc even left me a bit misty eyed. 


The character's were a bit lack luster in this show Kaede being an exception . If you weren't a Dues Ex Machina, like the literal guardian angel in the anime, or a convenient plot device like the literal kid genius who rivals Albert Einstein you were just there to accommodate the pretty lame MC. 


It was a pretty cheeky anime and had its cheeky, heart warming moments. You really shouldn't think about too hard. I suggest watching the first 3 episodes and the last 2 episodes with more intent than the other ones. You could really watch the rest on auto pilot, dub perhaps while your about to fall asleep.


Came for the Bunny Girl, stayed for the Panda Girl.

This is an honest, critical review of the anime. I won't draw comparisons to other animes, like so many have already done, but instead review it based on its own merits (or lack thereof). This review also contains massive spoilers.
What does this anime boil down to? Simply put, pseudo-intellectual wish fulfilment. If you've had meaningful relationships in the past, and/or possess a background in science, prepare to have your eyes rolled and your intelligence insulted. What Twilight and 50 Shades of Grey are to the literary world, Bunny Girl Senpai is to the anime world- albeit arguably less atrocious.
Bunny Girl Senpai is about a socialoutcast, loser MC named Sakuta who rescues Celebrity Damsel In Distress, Sakurajima Mai. They start dating, but the wish fulfilment doesn't end there. Along with his nationally renowned celebrity girlfriend, the MC has a whole host of girls who are thinly veiled love interests/waifu baits with whom he makes blatantly sexual comments to with no social repercussions. This is fresh escapist, fanfiction material that tries to present itself as intelligent and thought provoking, but ultimately fails.


This is probably the fourth time I've seen Schrodinger's Cat mentioned in anime alone. You'd think by now the author could just recite it from heart without having to Google it (hint: he should have Googled it). But no, he somehow manages to fuck up this morbidly elementary quantum theory with his generic science girl trope. What's worse, he continues the science babble in future episodes, and viewers soon realise that Puberty Syndrome, a cheap plot mechanic, will never be fully explained no matter how white a HS girl's lab coat is.


The dialogue, for which whatever reason receives a lot of praise, is stilted and... not actually that witty. People will tell you it's dry humour, and maybe it's not your thing, but dry humour is definitely my thing- Monty Python skits and Mad Men is dry humour; Bunny Girl Senpai's dialogue is just dry and uninspiring. At one point in the anime, the MC asks his girlfriend if she's on her period. That would be a knee slapper, had I not heard and used that line a hundred times before I ended my middle-school career. If you find the dialogue witty and nuanced, then I daresay you have the wit level of your Mother's Basement (no pun intended).


Unfunny dialogue aside, the relationship between our apathetic edgel0rd MC and his fantasy girlfriend is an inspiration for jaw-dropping frustration. Moments of intimacy--emotional and physical--are rare and fleeting. 99% of the 'tension' is the MC making lewd or romantic advances, and Mai rejecting them. In fact, Mai is so busy being a celebrity, she hardly has time to be a girlfriend to Sakuta, much less a friend. What she does offer, however, is cartfuls of empty promises that lead the MC on, chastisement and belittlement, and guilt tripping. But that's okay, because she's a hot tsundere celebrity, right?


Yet Mai is never there for Sakuta, despite him making visible effort and sacrifice to be there for her. Then, in the one time he needs her the most, she is surprisingly... not there. Instead it's Shouko who comforts him. When Mai finds out that someone else comforted him while she was busy not giving a fuck about the MC, or noticing his scars re-opening, she gets jealous and leaves in a bitchfit, and it's somehow Sakuta who is profusely apologising. Afterwards, when they kiss and make up, she ruins the moment and doesn't actually kiss him.


The lack of a kiss isn't the most frustrating part. That's the straw that came after the camel's back was already broken. Sakuta didn't even know her birthday, despite them dating for the better part of 6 months. That requires a laughable suspension of disbelief, but with the lack of emotional connection and intimacy shown between them, I can actually kind of believe it. If Mai was completely fugly and NOT a celebrity, would our MC, or even the audience for that matter, like her as much? My bet would be a resounding 'no!'


But enough of Mai. In the world of ruthless storyboard editing, the rule of thumb is this: if something can be deleted and the story comes out the same, then it should be deleted. If the anime (and LN) followed this rule, we wouldn't have a Koga, Futaba, or Toyohama arc, because ultimately, they just return to normal cardboard characters, or appear for less than 30 seconds in the rest of the entire season. But that's not how you sell dakimakura or figurines, is it?


What's even more comedic than the anime itself is how much praise it receives from e-celeb AniTubers. In one analysis, the YouTuber goes as far as stating that the theme of challenging social norms is somehow new and profound, and is unique to Japan. Well, sorry, but it isn't. Every setting and situation has a general atmosphere and vibe that needs to be read, and every society has its norms and rules. But hey, rebelling against society's trends is just soooooo creative! It's almost like there should be a plethora of teenage media and literature dedicated to rebelling and discovering your own identity! OH WAIT.


The real story revolves around Sakuta, Kaede and Shouko, and to a lesser extent, Mai, because of her amasing first arc. But I could argue that if Mai was deleted altogether, you'd still have a compelling story about Puberty Syndrome and the mystery surrounding Shouko's true identity. Even if you kept Mai in, you'd still have plenty of time in 13 episodes to cover what's really going on with the core cast without having to resort to a movie to tie up loose ends. But that's not how you sell movie tickets to fans, is it?


It's not all terrible. My highlights are when grown Shouko gets some screen time, and Kaede's one episode of glory. Even though Shouko has an incredibly limited time to shine, she really, really shines. That was the first time I've ever heard anyone, fictional or otherwise, say that if she can wake up and be kinder than the day before, then that's a successful day. It's a rough paraphrase, but the sincerity and heartfelt delivery of her character won me over. If I ever met a girl like that, I would do my best to keep her and not let go. I'm sure she's bound to have flaws, but that is an amasing way to go about life.


What really touched me with Kaede's arc is that she struggled to resolve her issues on her own without being spoon fed the answer from Sakuta. She made a list of goals, and one by one, she managed to push through, even when the MC told her it's all right to quit. Kaede isn't just another Waifu Damsel, and she puts forth an incredible determination to overcome her fears. Seeing her progression is one of the only times the anime impressed me.


(Sidenote: Sakuta's magical advice more or less boils down to just telling the girl to do what she wants, and being an apathetic enabler. The most hilarious resolution was Futaba's arc where her insecurities of self-image and sexuality cause a supernatural occurrence. Instead of directly addressing the issues of exhibitionism, guilt, and shame, All-Star MC invites her to the fireworks festival, which somehow resolves multiple layers of sexual anxiety and stress that all girls go through, and even a lot of women into adulthood.)


In conclusion, Bunny Girl Senpai falls incredibly short of the praise and hype it's received, and comes off as mostly boring- but not enough to drop... maybe. Throughout the series I kept wondering if I SHOULD drop it. It's not 100% awful, because believe me, there are some terrible titles out there; however, it teeters between mind-numbingly boring and moderately hopeful. For me, it's a lesson learned: if you're thinking about dropping an anime, drop it. It's not worth trudging through it like a chore in the hopes that a couple of favourite characters will have a chance to shine. Maybe they will, maybe they won't. But in the end, it'll likely be a disappointment.


Final Score For Loser Fantasises About Dating a Celebrity and Being a Fuckboy: 4/10

This show was a 9 for me until episode 12. The way things unfolded after that really escalated the show's appeal. To be fair, the first arc was great followed by the other very good arcs, albeit, paler in comparison to the first, however, the finale was exceptional enough for me to change my opinion. At first, I thought of this show being meant for fedora donning weirdos because of the bunny girl theme. The depth of characters this show managed to reach in only 13 episodes, for me, was comparable to be of equivalence to Re: Zero. It also happens to have similar torturethemes going on and if you liked Re: Zero, you're probably gonna like this as well.

Hi MAL. Surprise! That’s my reaction to watching this show, but also only my second review. I've been meaning to type more reviews, but time just slips by and I feel like it’s too late sometimes.
I want to preface (similar to my first/previous review, I highly suggest reading the beginning of that review so you get a feel of my background) that I do not watch a lot of anime like many users here. I tend to pick a couple shows from each season that I actually deem interesting and see if I like it. When I do a season preview with my friends, thisshow barely made it to the surface since there was quite a bit of shows that peaked my interest.


I also want to note that most of the shows I watch with my significant other, however this one I watched by myself. I believe that watching anime with more people can affect experiences and feelings. She was not interested but I still was, and oh boy I glad I stuck with it.


I think the biggest thing to take from this is that, when people try to explain what this show is like, a common thing is “Oh it’s like if Bakemonogatari and Oregairu had a little baby”. The thing is, I haven’t watched those. Like I always say, comparing anime to others anime make reviews and discussions a crap shoot, so that’s probably the last thing you’d hear me talk about. Obviously, it’s even tough for me to keep that factor out of my head when watching/reviewing a show. I strongly believe that watching a certain genre or style of anime for the first time captures your mind more than it would the second or third time. When I recommend an anime to someone, I ALWAYS ask what shows they like or what they have seen. Anime is not one single entity of medium/genre. So, if you go to the MAL page of this show, scroll to the bottom and see the recommended shows; if you aren’t interested in those shows or haven’t seen them, you probably won’t enjoy the show, but that’s probably. Maybe this will be the first one from that list. One last thing is that if you have seen those two shows, you will most likely enjoy this show unless you’re one of the people who thoroughly believe that once you’ve seen it, it’s unacceptable to see it again. Not everyone has seen everything. Enough about that, you can probably see what kind of reviewer I am now, let’s move on.


---


Story: 9/10


Fantastic story. It’s not quite perfect, but that’s why it’s a 9. They leave some out to add on with an OVA/movie, but we’ll get on to that later. Curiosity was the main feeling watching this show. My first reaction going into this show was a simple synopsis: a boy named Sakuta who was the only one able to see this girl, Mai, wearing a bunny suit in public. That’s it. That’s all I knew. If that doesn’t peak your curiosity, I don’t know what will. I was just like “why?”. I know many friends who were like “what is this show about?”. People were expecting some kind of typical harem/ecchi show, but I can definitely say it is far from that. I think they did an amazing job luring people in and making them stay. We were all in the same boat. It slowly progresses more towards why Mai has this problem and that other characters are going through the same ‘syndrome’. While Sakuta is helping them, he is trying to help himself because he too is affected by the syndrome. I won’t spoil anything because it all makes sense when you watch and listen to this show.


However, I really want to point out that the first 3 episodes of this was one of the best rides I’ve been on watching an anime in a long time. That 3rd episode really solidified my thoughts on where the show was going and I’m glad I was able to experience those 24 minutes.


Character: 10/10


I absolutely love the relationship between Sakuta and Mai. Their exchanges and feelings towards each other are enough to outshine anything else in this show to make it a perfect 10/10. Sure, the other characters pretty good, but seeing the two on the screen makes my heart happy. When it comes to like shonen shows, people like personality or physical development. Like say a character gets a new power or something. However, that could take tens of episodes or a whole arc. You think that 3 episodes would be a joke for development, but this rapid development between the two like I mentioned earlier was breathtaking. My eyes were wide open and maybe some tears even came out just from sheer joy. I have a bias when it comes to relationships since I’m a sucker for romance, which this show entails. And not like little implied romance- actual boyfriend/girlfriend romance (see many of my highly rated shows). So, I have to say many of this show’s ratings might be bumped up by a half to a full point just because of it. I will bring this up again later.


The only thing I can really take away is that the characters fall into typical tropes but I feel like some are needed in this show. They don’t make it blatant (well except one, but it makes sense in the end). Like I said, I’m not going to really compare this to other stuff. They’re just common trends/tropes in most anime, but it’s portrayed very well and honestly doesn’t affect the outcome at all. In Anime and a high school setting, some of these devices need to bet set in order to lay a good foundation. That’s what this show did. They really don’t throw it in your face but when you get to know a character you go “Oh they’re this kind of character”, but obviously each one has a reason for it, not just because ‘the show needs this kind of character’. Get what I’m saying?


Art: 8/10


There’s not much to say about the art except that it’s pretty nice to look at. It doesn’t awe me, but the character animations are pretty smooth and I like each character’s design. Everyone feels unique or stands out which is good in this type of show. They make each character rememberable. I enjoy their school uniform design and I appreciate the attention to detail on some shots or scenery. Minor CG for crowds/background characters but it’s not so bad it’s distracting (I can just point it out). I mean Cloverworks (The A-1 rebranding/branch) is still pretty new, but I think they did a great job.


The thing that stands out the most to me is that when the characters are out of uniform or in their weekend outfits, they actually have different clothes on every other time. I really appreciate when artists or the design team put work and effort into this. I think when it comes to this kind of show it makes it stunningly more relatable and feels like you’re there with them. It’s not an easy task to do. 


That brings up this topic, which also related into sound, is the ending of each episode. Them changing girls or singers every couple episodes is ASTOUNDING. It’s what made me want to watch each one. I adore when studios do that. Definitely brought up half a point at least for that alone.


Sound: 8.5/10


The voice acting and dialogue carry this show so hard. I usually rate my sound just on music and voice acting. As mentioned, I like the endings. The ending song is okay, not something I would want to add to my playlist of songs, but it’s good enough to listen to when I watch. However, I’m not a big fan of the opening. It’s a little annoying besides from the memes I’ve seen about the song name and how it’s sung. Let’s say I always skipped the intro after seeing it a couple times, but I watched every ending.


The background music forgettable. The voice acting is good, sometimes great.


Back to the dialogue. Seriously probably the biggest and most pivotal reason on why this show is good to me. I love a good conversation. Maybe it’s boring to some, since it’s not a shonen or action-based show, you have to pay attention, and it rewards you. I can’t get enough of Sakuta’s smart ass remarks or comments, but I’m always itching to see how Mai reacts. They’re actually in a relationship, which I rarely see in anime, but those scenes/lines sky rocket to the top of my list if I see it. There was so much in this show that’s why I like it so much. A little obsessive but you know when Dexter says “omelet du fromage” and those girls by him just melt. That’s what happens to me whenever I hear Mai talk. I’m sure Sakuta felt the same way.


Enjoyment: 10/10


And now we’re here. Definitely a show I enjoyed from start to finish. Had some huge spikes of enjoyment, but that’s how the episode formula works if you know what I’m talking about. I had many laughs, a few tears, and a lot of smiles. That’s a 10/10 for me. I wasn’t disappointed in the slightest bit. I couldn’t watch for each episode every week!


Overall: 9/10


Adding the scores up, it comes up to about 89% which I round to a 9/10. The show itself is lacking the full story (since they made a movie/OVA with the remaining stuff), but just from it alone is enough to make an amazing anime.

Thanks for reading. Let me know what you think, I might type more reviews.

There is so much WOW factor in this anime and easily my top 10 for 2018. Despite the misleading title and the visual art that may put people off by thinking its another romcom series. How are we so wrong, plus the synopsis did not do justice with how amazing the series was. 
Story (10/10) - You cannot walk out of this show and say oh it's just another decent high-school anime. This series takes it to another level by utilising the 'puberty symptom' at its fullest to represent how each character is facing as they are in high school or growing up. It capturesthe hardship of overcoming those symptoms during our teen days, or even into adulthood. Also, like the fact that it's not just a simple fix but requires them to face it head-on and find solutions to resolve these issues. This carefully crafted story, supported with the talented director for this series, demonstrated how each episode our protagonist went out of his way to help each character to fix their adolescent issues, and increase his harem. 


Art (9/10) - Stunning I would say. Especially the well-orchestrated opening video captures the magnificent background image of this series. Not to mention the character design, well made them quite attractive to the audience eyes. Simply the time spent on character design by the team of illustrators to effectively reflect the beauty of the characters. 


Character (9/10) - Ahh yes, our man Sakuta becomes the man of the season. Despite his lazy, dull and straightforward personality. What I like about him is that he's willing to step out of his comfort zone, which is doing nothing, and go out of his way to support each character of different arcs. But I am more interested MAI-SENPAI! Cute, tsundere and adorable mature character just made my day and how she understands Sakuta very well and showed him the highest level of trust. Cares for him after his public confession and the blush the needs to protect. 


Sound (8/10) - I enjoyed the opening music 'kimi no sei' so much that it now sticks in your head. The well-tuned music gives a lot of energy, and you never get tired of hearing it. 


Enjoyment (9/10) - Saying that I enjoyed the show is an understatement. Every episode I am just so invested in seeing whether the problems will be solved or does another barrier to it. But what I enjoyed more was the interaction between Sakuta and the girls as he loves to tease them with his shameless opinions. I love slice-of-life romance anime after all. 


Overall (9/10) - IF we look back on this show, it can reflect on how we experience in our teen days, and this anime clearly showed all those symptoms we faced. Not to mention our protagonist Sakuta have to suffer as he reached the limit of his abilities. 


For more review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u6-tqE9mO6Y&t=193s

Note everything bellow is my opinion. So disagree if you like, it won't change my mind
Anyways, "Rascal does not dream of bunny girl senpai" in my opinion is a very good Anime, It hits a lot of marks that other anime's failed at. Below is a detailed review. Please watch the show and form your own opinions, but do read my review below if you have the time, I really appreciate it. No spoilers involved.
Seishun Buta Yarou Wa Bunny Girl Senpai is, at first glance, what appears to be a generic psychological harem slice of life anime thatchecks off all the boxes for what it needs to become a relatively okay anime. Cute characters, a seemingly deep story, a nice soundtrack, beautiful animation and art style, and well fleshed out characters.


In most cases, an anime like this would be a relative "meh" for me, and I would generally end off the series with a thought along the lines of "pleh", and think: "hey, that wasn't bad." But that wasn't the case at all.


Many people who view this and don't truly understand the depth of what is being discussed here will say that it was alright, and view it like any other slice of life anime that they've seen with characters that play into a general type. Hikigaya Hachiman from Oregairu, Ayanokouji from Classroom of the elite etc. were all splendid characters that generally fit this relatively monotone character that doesn't really care about life and is fine with being alone and misunderstood.


But this is different. The advanced physics concepts discussed here, such as the observation theory or Schrodinger's Cat need not be fully understood to appreciate this anime. This anime tackles many social issues without conforming to the generic anime tropes of one MC who defeats all the bad guys and gets all the girls.


Bullying, amnesia, discrimination, as well as familial issues, all have been addressed through the various characters in this anime, and each in a clear and concise manner. They did not try to create magical solutions for each of these problems, and nor should they, as there is no clear cut method for dealing with things like that. A realistic viewpoint is presented here, and Sakuta realistically solves none of the overarching issues presented. He can do nothing about ostracisation, nor what people think, nor their perceptions of him and the other people involved. He simply can be there for the people he is close to and provide support as they have supported him.


The use of the Puberty Syndrome in the anime is a metaphorical, physical representation of the effects of the overarching issues on the people involved. Be it his sister or the female lead, or even other friends along the way, the use of the Puberty Syndrome highlights the problems that people face and the repercussions of people's beliefs and actions. I can't go into detail about this without spoiling the anime, but the slightly dramatized and personified versions of these issues the characters face help to teach a lesson not only to the watchers, but also the characters themselves as they learn and grow from the experiences they have faced, and come to terms with it and deal with it on their own. Sakuta is not the God MC that girls fall over, he is simply a friend and a close ally that has been supported through his own issues, and is now lending his hand out to those that need it.


Sakuta as a character displays not only growth and maturity of character, but also a degree of reliance on others to help him, just like a regular person. He has proven that he can help solve people's problems, but needs help to do so. He is not infallible, nor is he the one who goes out of his way to help everyone he sees and knows. He is given a proper motive for his actions, and the diversity of obstacles placed in his path was a welcome change for me.


The rest of the characters are well developed, or if they were not then they accomplished their purpose in this work. The animation and soundtracks fit perfectly and were never disruptive to the experience, and in many ways have enhanced it. Good job to the studio and writers for that one.


Overall, this was a stunning anime with maybe not the most satisfying conclusion, but definitely a fitting one that I would like to see more of, especially in the 2019 movie, and maybe even read the light novels should they ever be translated. This was an enjoyable ride, and each character has their own flaws and hubris that they will overcome themselves, with the main character being a fresh change from the stereotypical anime MCs that can solve everything. Sakuta cannot solve everything. Sometimes he cannot solve anything. In the end, the other characters saved themselves, at best he lent a helping hand.


I highly recommend this anime.

High school is typically embellished as the end all be all for the Japanese as the last period of time where they were able to enjoy their youth before the workforce.  That and the fact that a lot of kids from all ages watch anime are the main contributors as to why 'high school' is such an oversaturated setting.  But let's take a second to add a dash of realism to everything, where high school isn't as fun and everyone has problems to see where that gets us.  And maybe a bunny girl too while we're at it.
Story:
Azusagawa Sakuta is a man of very fewemotions.  His deadpan face and witty personality is a deadly combination of traits that lead him to be an antisocial person and have barely any friends.  Partially.  One day as he goes to a bookstore, he sees a girl parading around in a bunny suit waving in front of people's faces without getting so much as a reaction back.  He recognizes this girl as Sakurada Mai, a child star who did dramas and commercials way back when.  As it turns out, everyone doesn't notice Mai since she has 'Puberty Syndrome', and Sakuta, having experienced the phenomenon himself, decides to help Mai for her well-being...and maybe for himself.


To understand this show is to also understand 'Puberty Syndrome', described as an unexplainable myth that seemingly warps the world around an individual based on their problems.  The show explains it way more complicated than it needed to be without a concrete explanation that isn't theoretical, but in simple terms, whenever someone has a personal issue that they can't resolve, weird shit happens to them and their wish is fulfilled at a cost.  A monkey's paw if you will.  While interesting, the result of this complicated phenomenon coupled with some very lengthy explanations utilizing theoretical physics makes some portions of the show interesting, but exhausting.  It's arguably my least favorite aspect of the show because I think the author and by extension everyone else involved with this adaptation tried way too hard to put in scientific reasoning when it really could just have been handwaved by magic, despite how cool theoretical physics is.


Regardless, what Bunny Girl is ultimately about is Sakuta solving various girls' problems with their lives, first starting with Mai, gradually expanding out to several other people around him in order to effectively save them from themselves.  It's a tired plotline, but the freshness of the concept comes from Sakuta as a character, as well as the personal conflicts that occur within the series' main girls.  Each girl has a believable problem.  Things like relationships and bullying are common themes for the show and are only escalated by the impact of Puberty Syndrome.  Because of this, the internal turmoil feels genuine and the pacing and time each arc is given only makes the show better cause there feels like care, attention, and conflict with each arc.


Not only that, but the show also manages a relationship built on trust between its protagonists.  Dialogue is very much the series's strong point, and just the way the characters interact with each other make everything just that much more interesting cause there's just so much subtext and emotion behind the way the characters are talking to each other before the ultimate breakdown moment at the end of each arc.


My only real complaint comes with the final arc, as I feel like as an ending, it had pacing issues (and explanation problems) that didn't fit as neatly as the other arcs.  It just seemed like there was too much shoved in, and I really wanted more from it considering the person who was being tackled at the time.  Despite that, Bunny Girl's story is very much the adolescent experience turned to eleven in order to personify and antagonize people's personal issues as the core problem for the characters, creating believable conflict in a more magical spotlight.


Overview:

+ Great pacing

+ Fantastic dialogue

+ Very believable arcs

-  Last arc felt rushed by comparison


Characters:


Sakuta serves as one of the many reasons why Bunny Girl is one of the best of the Fall 2018 season.  Not only is he an active protagonist who willingly takes on the task of helping those around him by his own volition, he also possesses wit to combat much of the cast's responses no matter the situation, as well as changes over the course of the series.  His relationship with Mai only adds to this, as the trust forged between the two create such a strong bond where they're each other's shoulder to cry on makes things that much better.  He is very much the driving force of the show, and really things wouldn't be the same without him.  My biggest complaint however is really his role in the ending arc, particularly the second half, cause nothing really was clear about that, and his own internal turmoil doesn't make as much sense as I think Cloverworks wanted it to.


Mai serves a lesser role to her partner, but still an important one, not only being the first of several girls to be helped by Sakuta, but also by being Sakuta's motivation for many things.  The fun part is how Mai as a character serves separate to the relationship between the two, as what we see is a character who manages to be kind of an opposite to Sakuta himself in terms of personality, but also similar in the fact that the strain in their relationship can be resolved and is a result of both parties being at fault, leading to some very mature moments between the two that honestly end up being the best aspects of the show.  Given the reputation romance has in the anime medium, it's rare to see such a mature relationship, between two high school students no less, blossom and stay relevant throughout the show despite some of the crazier stuff that happens.


The same goes for the rest of the cast.  At least in the case for the four other girls who have their cases tackled over the course of the series, their problems and overall character get fleshed out enough for the audience (and Sakuta) to care about them.  You get a sense of personality from these girls.  Less tropes, more mix of everything: needs, flaws, strengths, wit, all of this makes the show more rewarding cause you see positive change, enough to make the characters WANT to change rather than just "here's my arc, I'm done".  Change is slow, and the show knows that, going far enough to establish the solution to the puberty syndrome, but just enough for everything to not be fully resolved since teenagers at the very least still don't have their shit together.


Overview:

+ Every character feels real

+ Genuine growth at all levels

+ One of the realest relationships I've seen in the medium


Art:


Produced by Cloverworks, Bunny girl has a consistent quality to it combined with a solid and kinda boring color scheme that's actually real to life.  There's not much embellishment or color to everything cause everything's kinda drab.  Like life.  It's a pleasing style regardless cause everything is very simple and solid, so what you end up with is very little flooding the eyes, but just enough to give you a pleasant style with consistent quality checks.


The only downside is the fact that the show hardly has any wild animation that would warrant intense movement.  Characters don't really move a lot, as most of the show's content is shown through its dialogue rather than its movement.


Sound:


I want to come up front and say that I do not like either of these tracks.  "Kimi no Sei" by the peggies is a high energy rock song with a soprano singer on lyrics.  It's a good song and definitely has its many highs given the energy during the chorus coupled by smoother lower moments.  By contrast, "Fukashigi no Carte" sung by the various seiyuus of the girls in the series is a smooth, jazzy piece that accompanies each arc of the respective girl.  Interesting, and definitely worth a listen due to really just jazzy it is.


Now tell me, what part of any of these songs fits "Magical Teenage Problems Drama" the show?  Personally because of how much they contrast the content of the show, I don't see these tracks as belonging to Bunny Girl no matter how good they are.  It's like a culture shock almost.  I expect to watch something energetic with the OP, only to end up watching drama, and by the end I think I'm in a bar.  It just makes no sense to me, and for that, I don't like these songs being tacked to this show.  Standalone however, they each have their own merits.


Personal Enjoyment:


I remember coming across Bunny Girl when it was being adapted into a manga.  It was such a weird concept but after a while I was like "Huh, this is pretty good".  So really, I was surprised when an adaptation came to light, cause I always saw it as this underground thing.  Turns out, it's one of the most popular shows of the season.  Huh, who'da thunk that good writing, good characters, and overall good aesthetics could create a good show?  Fucking blows my mind.


Anyway, there's not much I can really say to sing more praises about the show since I've been doing that this entire review.  While not one of my favorites, its overall quality is just so well made that this series is just objectively good from almost every standpoint.  My only gripe is how the final arc really could've used more time.  And a better explanation.  It felt like a weak end by comparison cause it seemed like they were rearing up for a massive reveal after the twist, but it just never came to light.  For that, I'm frustrated, but ultimately not really surprised given the time constraints.


If this isn't on your list for shows that you want to watch from Fall 2018, it probably should be.  Bunny Girl is objectively one of the best shows of the season, managing a lot of parts and putting them together in such a way that's both believable and engaging to watch.  Also mildly depressing considering high school is definitely not a favorite time for most people.

People might say it's average, it's uninspired, yet so many seem to love it. Who's right? All of them. When you look at it from one angle you could see the moe-pandering, erotic comments, factory-line melodrama. Yet, you could look at it from another angle and see the sometimes well-realized characters, sometimes more sensible humor, sometimes more interesting banter.
"Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai" is a Frankenstein mixed bag of stitched-together conventions done well, and to me that is it's main problem. The anime doesn't have a strong identity and the plot takes the backseat, quickly appearing as random gimmicks that mess withsome characters. However, what pulls things together and leads the way is the characters and the dialogue. However, even with that understanding, the issue continues in how the show prioritizes itself.


You might hear some say the pacing of "Bunny Girl Senpai" is horrible, that it encapsulated too many stories in too short a time. My take, that isn't the problem. The show is directed very competently and does a fantastic job at telling stories briefly. The problem is this format naturally places too much focus on the plot, which is a vague series of mini-obstacles to an unclear resolution. This show would've done well with either being less ambitious in it's length of story-telling, or in adding a few more episodes of down-time to focus on the cast. It also could do well to have more thorough lore that makes the series of events in this feel more coherent or progressive, while now it feels completely lost and meaningless beyond the ensuing character interaction. It could've also doubled-down on it's ridiculous nature and tried to justify itself with logic less (this criticism being directed at the tedious usage specific character).


"Bunny Girl Senpai" is a victim of improperly managing priorities and suffers quite a bit because of it, yet it manages to have some engaging character moments between some overdone drama. I believe the show lives up enough to the hype and succeeds in being an almost best-of summary of things you'd see in Clannad without some of the added nonsense. I understand why someone would give it an 8 out of 10 if the more extreme silliness of the show didn't phase them to the negative in some way, but there's enough grounded heartfelt dialogue that most of the time I felt an incentive to keep watching.

Absolutely outstanding.
This anime is probably the most unexpected rare gem of the season, thanks to the incredibly misleading synopsis that tried to push the bunny girl aspect of the anime, that doesn't actually have much to do with the series as a whole. In short, if you're looking for one of the best romance animes ever made, look no further than Bunny Girl Senpai.
*Non-Spoiler Review*
The story of this anime is told through several character arcs that focus on the interaction between our main character and a girl within the series. For reference, think Bakemonogatari, and you'll have a pretty good idea of how the storyis structured. Each arc was told brilliantly. So much so, that at times, I thought I had just witnessed the series climax, only to witness an even greater climax in the next character arc. It is primarily a romance anime, however, I can assure you that it won't be like any romance anime you've ever seen.


The best part about this anime is most definitely the characters. Each and every one of them gets their moment in the spotlight, but even if it isn't their character arc, they still are part of the story as a whole. I absolutely loved the dynamic between Mai and Sakuta. Both of them had very distinct personalities. It was if they were alive in some way, and not just being voiced by VA's. They've both become a part of my most favorite characters of all time, and I will most certainly remember them long after this series has passed.


There's something about Bunny Girl Senpai that is just so fun to watch. I can't find the words to describe it accurately, but you could say that I had fun reading dialogue, and that's only ever happened back when I was watching Bakemonogatari. Yes, this anime is similar to it, but I like to think that it's created an entirely separate genre of its own. One that I hope will continue to be explored in future anime seasons.


Please, watch Bunny Girl Senpai. You will not be disappointed. I can guarantee that.


Thank you for reading this review!

At first I didn't even imagined that i'd watch show about freaking "BUNNY GIRL SEMPAI". Getting recommendations to watch it made me interested. How can people like it? That's when I was surprised. Ths show is amazing and I'll tell you why.

This anime has gourgeous image with great animation. Animation here is smooth, refreshing and makes you value tranquility and serenity of this show.

To be honest, i didn't noticed any kind of outstanding OST's or etc. What I noticed is proper use of silence and calm tunes. Sometimes not using any sound is better than using it.
Characters: 9
Not introducing us to alot of characters is a smart move. Some  shows fall apart when they show too many side characters, that will never show up again. There're not a lot of those characters in this anime.\n
 Those that do get the spotlight are getting the best out of it. Main character is great. His harem DOESN'T even feel like a harem at all. Considering he has more than 5 female friends and only one male friend. Character dynamics are established and used properly. \n
Though I have some complaints about main relationship, but this goes to spoiler category.\n

Something about this show ade my heart pound. I felt excitement whenever something good happened and thrilled when something strange or bad happened. Especially first few episodes felt amazing and heart-melting.\n

When i was watching the show, I noticed how paceof this story is quite different than in other anime. This pace is strange, it feels unnatural. The event that I expected to happen in the last episode, happened VERY EARLY ON. This uncomfortable feeling didn't leave, since pace also changed sometimes. Don't you feel it when in one episode covers one month, and thevery next episode shows us lesser than one day? Yeah something like that.\n\n

Goddamit this was an unique show. One of its kind i would say. This is the show that will help you clear your mind, thoughts and etc. Though, it will also give a ton of information.\n
Now I want a petition to rename this show, because:\n
A) IT HAS BASICALLY NOTHING TO DO WITH BUNNY GIRLS\n
