So... Yeah

How can i even begin to describe this show. It was an amazing experience. I am a fan of the whole romance school trope and when i saw this on upcoming anime i was like oh god this is another trashy fan service school romance anime sign me up.
I was to be disappointed if that was what i only liked. Bunny girl senpai had nothing really to do with fan service, bunny girls and pointless drama over a lack of communication 99% of these animes seem to have between the mcs.
This anime was a masterpiece. The relationship between the two was never the cause ofmajor drama, rather the anime showed how they got together and became closer as multiple strange things tested them as a couple and as individuals. i cannot think of any anime that comes even close to this in this department. I am sick (well i say that but still watch it so LOL) of the whole genre where the MC is a total idiot, or a total wuss or just a flustered moron whenever the girl is around. 


I could go on for well a lot longer but many of the other 10/10 reviews cover well most of my points so i'll just leave it at this. Below is something i came across that is rather annoying as it is misleading.



The rest of this will contain spoilers


I saw a review that mentioned incest baiting. Whist i myself prefer to have nothing to do with the topic, Bunny girl senpai was not that bad, the little sister sometimes made questionable remarks. HOWEVER the reason this anime gets a pass is 


1. Kaede has no memory of more than a couple of years. Sure they are siblings but to her she doesn't have the whole i grew up with him eww concept. in fact seeing as he is the only person she trusts/talks to as she cannot remember anyone else etc makes this somewhat acceptable. 


2. the 'incest baiting' was more about feelings than lust. That matters. refer to point 1 if you cannot understand


3. it was never serious. more of a joke. she never got upset about sakuta getting a girlfriend, she in fact became friends once she got over her fear of well humans apart from her brother. 


4. Possibly the most important point. Sakuta never blushes or gets flustered like mcs in other animes. That reaction alone is enough to gloss over the issue.


5. its rare. its doesnt take up more than MAYBE 1 minute of screen time across 13 episodes, 99% of their interactions are well what you'd expect from siblings where the parents are absent.

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai or don't expect something the Cover shows you ;)
The Show basically is about a second-year student at a high school near Enoshima which meets several girls that are experiencing this so called "puberty syndrome." For example, he meets a wild bunny girl in the library. She turns out to be an actress on hiatus, Mai Sakurajima, who is also his senior at the school. For some reason, no one else can see this girl.As Sakuta searches for answers to help Mai, they spend more time together, and he eventually learns of her hidden feelings.
Plot/Story9/10 


The Series with an unusual Cover starts of as an normal Slice of Life Show but slowly adds an supernatural theme the "puperty syndrome" on it.The puperty Syndrome  can either be interpreted as an supernatural entitiy that screw up others lifes but more likely its a reflection of a state in Reality  that a lot of people go through be it through mental illness,puperty or an identity crysis.


But back to the Story in the Anime. It is divided into Four Arcs,where in one Sakuta and Mai get to know each other, Futaba comes to terms with the fact that she fights with her inner demons which is expressed to a second Futabe that has her own needs her own personality etc , and the last arc deals mainly with sister Kaede, who is basically the most important character next to Sakuta that the story represents.


Kaede, Sakuta's Sister is the reason to his believes that he "trys to be kinder each day"  which he embody through the Character Shoco and this perfectly shows why the Story Writing is good.

Because Besides its romantic and supernatural vibes it creates a relateable Cast that have each their own Struggles and Problems.



Animation / Design 9/10


Nothing really to complain about the Characters are moving smooth, the backgrounds are beautiful and  manage to put the characters in front so that they feel alive


Characters 10/10


I've said a lot in the Story Section that's why i review here the  Characters as a whole


Overall you can say that each character has its own Struggles & Characteristics that resonates within them and give the anime the feel of depth.Each one of them is relateable be it  told through the Syndrome or as a character itself.


Audio/Soundtrack 8/10


kimi no sei / kimi no sei / kimi no sei ..eh what? 


yea that OP / the Ending is Pretty catchy and reflects very good the soul of the show



Review Conclusion 9/10



So what we can say about this Anime. Sure people can say it has not a really linear narrative and is more focused on the Characters  but that doesn't make the Show any less good. It shines through that with fleshed out characters,cute girls,smooth animation and a supernatural theme that you haven't seen in that way before which can be interpretated in different ways. 


I can recommend it to everyone who like Slice of Life but also have nothing against a little bit of Supernatural Themes =)

Anime is an incredibly incestuous medium. Whether that’s good or bad is more up for debate, but I think it’s fairly obvious to everyone that anime borrows heavily from itself. It has its own series of in-jokes and references, its own tropes that it keeps going back to and trying to subvert, its own way of cannibalizing its peers for ideas, story beats, and character archetypes. Every anime is its own thing, yet every anime also owes much of its makeup to the stories it draws from, and part of the fun of getting sucked into hardcore anime fandom is becoming acquainted with this strangenew language in how the medium references itself and uses your pre-established knowledge of its styles and tropes to influence your perception of every new iteration. All that being said, though, while I’ve gotten remarkably used to anime’s self-referential tendencies in my admittedly brief time as an anime fan, I don’t think I’ve ever before seen an anime that so clearly screams “Compare me to something you’ve already seen” as Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai. And unfortunately, that’s not entirely to its benefit.


Admittedly, it might not be entirely fair of me to tie my opinion of this show so closely to its most obvious inspiration. After all, every story deserves to be judged on its own merits, and it’s how the pieces come together in the end that has far more importance than what pieces are used in the first place. But man, is it hard to pry my impressions of Bunny Girl Senpai away from the Monogatari series, because it’s copying that storied franchise’s playbook so obviously and directly that comparing the two feels almost inevitable. Like Monogatari, Bunny Girl Senpai takes place in a slightly skewed version of our world where people speak in a mix of obscure references, tangled wordplay, and rapid-fire snarky quips that gives every conversation the impression of a writer perhaps a little too pleased with his genius. Like Monogatari, the conflicts center around supernatural afflictions that all have some thematic purpose for the characters they afflict, though in this case it’s more directly focused on the struggles of modern adolescence and based on quantum mechanics over symbolic linguistics. Like Monogatari, our protagonist Sakuta is a misanthropic loner who gets swept up in helping various girls solve their afflictions by coming to terms with some aspect of themselves that the afflictions represent, adding them to an ever-growing sort-of-but-not-quite-harem of supporting characters. Hell, even the archetypes the girls fall into feel directly cribbed from Monogatari: the tsundere-adjacent main girl who officially enters a relationship with the main guy at the end of the second arc, the abrasive loli type, the braniac who looks hot in glasses, the cute little sister, you get the idea. If there was ever a piece of media I could accuse of just copy-pasting what it’s ripping off, it would be this show.


Again, though, taking obvious direction from a previous story isn’t inherently a bad thing. Plenty of classic stories from across the world build on previously established ideas and themes, putting their own unique spin on familiar territory to great effect. Hell, Monogatari itself was steeped in anime culture and the tropes we’ve come to expect from it. And truth be told, Bunny Girl Senpai does a fine job of capturing the ballistic wit of its parent series. Sakuta, his girlfriend Mai, and all the rest are full of no shortage of funny one-liners and creative potshots, weaving dense webs of dialogue through the most inane comments. The actual problems the girls face are very well thought-out, reflecting the struggles teenagers actually face today in terms of social pressure, the increased lack of privacy thanks to social media, trying to live up to expectations you’re not sure you can fulfill, cyberbullying, and more. I also appreciate the clearheadedness of some of its narrative choices. Mai is decidedly Sakuta’s girlfriend by the end of the second arc, and that is never throws into question by any of the other girls he interacts with. The little sister Kaede has a clear crush on Sakuta, but the show never pretends there’s actually any sexual tension between them, or that Sakuta isn’t comfortable handling her advances in a mature, non-fetishistic way. If nothing else, that’s one thing Bunny Girl can wave in Monogatari’s face any day of the week.


But therein lies the problem as well; as chaotically broken as Monogatari could be at points, it was also one of the most brazen, audacious, and all-around brave franchises I can remember. It took huge chances at pretty much every turn, and while that means its failures could be massive, its more-frequent successes remain to this day some of my favorite moments out of anime. Bunny Girl just doesn’t have that same level of balls-to-the-wall bravery to set it apart in the same way. As an example, there’s a scene in the first episode where Sakuta’s verbally sparring with an abrasive girl, and he quips “are you on your period?”, to which the girl descends into flustered anger and is unable to manage a proper retort before storming off. It’s... honestly kind of lazy writing, and it’s not the last time the show hits such easy, obvious beats in place of its more creative snark. Can you imagine how this scene would’ve played out in Monogatari? Would Araragi’s instense verbal fire ever cough up a hairball as lazily misogynistic as a period comment? Even if he did, would Senjougahara, Mayoi, Kanbaru, or any of the rest respond by flusteredly walking away? Or would they punch back with a flurry of emasculating puns that spiraled into a completely unhinged back-and-forth as both characters sought to conquer the other in a whirling game of words? Hell, even when Araragi admits to groping Mayoi in one of the worst running jokes ever, at least Mayoi doesn’t take that shit lying down and immediately jumps up his ass with all the spitfire a bratty elementary schooler can produce. That kind of unhinged mania is why that franchise became popular and important enough that Bunny Girl was created to emulate it in the first place, and it just doesn’t feel as fresh or challenging or courageous.


Perhaps I am being a little unfair. Bunny Girl Senpai isn’t a bad show by any means, and I enjoyed watching it a lot. But the fact is, I can’t think of any aspect of this show that I don’t compare negatively to its own senpai. The animation is solid and nicely fluid, but it doesn’t hold a candle to Monogatari’s bonkers vision of an art-deco dreamworld. The dialogue is quippy and enjoyable, but not nearly as much as Nisioisin’s stream-of-consciousness million-thoughts-a-minute insanity. The main couple is cute, but I’m always comparing them in my mind to what is still my favorite fictional romance ever. Bunny Girl Senpai’s only real crime is one of not measuring up to what it asks you to measure it up against, and that is incredibly disappointing. On its own merits, though, it’s a smart and swift-footed exploration of relatable teenage angst, and there are far worse ways to get your fix of overly verbose character archetypes making mincemeat of the Japanese language.

I've been wanting to review this anime for quite sometime now.  And finally, I can.  Here's my review on: Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Sempai. 
Story: (7/10)
The story is all over the place. Yes, it follows a straight path, but you're never sticking to 1 story. The title suggest "Bunny Girl", however, the name is only relevant for about 2 episodes or so.  At the start you'll think that the main story is building Sakuta Azusagawa  (The MC), and Mai Sakurajima's relationship. However, that gets put on hold. I kinda like to look at this anime as a animatedvisual novel, since in visual novels, there are typically different routes you can take. In the anime you see Sakuta experience each of those routes. Each route has their own well written story, but because of the short 13 episodes, the stories never feel complete. Just when you feel like you're getting attached, they take it away from you, and move on to the next story. But that doesn't mean they're bad stories. In fact, I like them a lot, but they're squeezed into that short 13 episodes, that makes them feel incomplete. But that was kinda just my opinions on the story, so now i'll tell you what the story is really about. The story is about Sakuta Azusagawa, who encounters multiple supernatural phenomenons in his daily life. These phenomenons are caused by feelings a person has, and turns them into something much worse. Sakuta, having experienced these things before, helps the people around him get through this "sickness", and make them realize why its happening to them, so they can do things differently, and fix their problems. Pretty basic, but enjoyable.   


Art/Animation: (6/10)


I really didn't really like the art direction in this anime. Each character just looked really plain to me, and the settings didn't look that great either. It just looks very generic. The animation the other hand; seemed pretty choppy. I don't know much about animation, so I can't really tell if its good or not.  But I have defiantly seen A LOT better than this. 


Sound: (9/10)


The opening, and ending songs, are really good in my opinion. The OP gives of this energetic rush, what looks, and sounds nice. The really love the ending song. I really like how lay'ed back it sounds, and sometimes I like to listen to it when I go to sleep.   

Personal preference though.


Character: (9/10)


The characters are defiantly the best part of this anime. Each character has their own personality, and makes them really enjoyable to watch. My favorite being Sakuta, because I love how straight forward he is with everyone. Especially when it comes to the girls.  Like for example, if a girl says "what are you looking at, pervert!" , Sakuta will straight up say "You. I'm thinking very lewd thoughts about you." Or something like that. Probably not the best example, but that's all I could think of.


Enjoyment: (10/10) 


This anime is a blast to watch. If you take everything I said before, then this anime is really a good anime. In my personal opinion, this anime is a 10 out of 10, but since this is a review, I simply can't give it that, due to its flaws. In my opinion; the characters MAKE the anime, if it wasn't for them, then it would be a generic rom com  anime.


Overall: (8/10)


This anime defiantly has it's flaws, but its defiantly worth a watch in the end. You'll probably end up enjoying it as much as I did. But anyways, thanks for reading my review. If you found it helpful, then let me know. And if you thought this review sucked, then please criticize it, and tell me how I can improve. Thanks for reading.

So assuming you aren't blind and you've read through the synopsis first and you've taken a good look at the score, I want to talk about why this show is good but slightly overrated.
We all remember when the show was about to air that it was labeled as the classic fanservice anime that comes along every season. But wait, something's off... the score is above the legendary 8.00 threshold for godlike fanservice anime! What the fuck how is that even possible? You may find asking yourself. And to be quite honest, I feel the same even after finishing the show. The story itself is nothingearth shattering- this doesn't mean that it's terrible and deserves to be gutted, but instead, means exactly what I said, nothing special. 


If you came here for the thumbnail, you might be disappointed when I tell you that our one and only bunny girl is in that outfit a grand total of 2 times. Well if that's enough for you to turn around and say goodbye to the show, that's fair enough, since I almost did the same.


When an anime comes in with extremely low expectations but goes above people's expectations, people tend to start jotting it down as the "masterpiece of the season". This certainly is the case for this anime, since I really do think it's overrated. At the time of writing this review, Bunny Girl is at an 8.63, but I'm expecting that to go down a bit after more people start watching it. It's at the score it is right now because the majority of the viewers are complete filth such as myself who give pretty generic garbage a 7+ since we enjoy that type of shows.


I would say if you're fine with romance and a bit of a harem tease-esque show, go for it. It's your usual harem, except it isn't... just better in every way. The mc establishes a relationship as the bunny girl's boyfriend fairly early on, but the show doesn't completely revolve around that. Instead, it revolves around some pseudo-science concept called puberty syndrome. To me, that was a big "hehe xd" to my face because what a bunch of bullshit that was. Anyways, if you just don't focus on what the overarching story is or if you don't look for any clues as to what puberty syndrome is, you'll 8/10 enjoy watching the show. 


Overall, the score doesn't lie... if you came to this show for an experience similar to enlightenment, sorry but you won't find it here. Maybe a character to add to your favorites list or something along those lines, but nothing that will make you jump out of your chair screaming what a great show that was. It wasn't too memorable and the characters except for Koga and Mai don't really stick to me, but if anyone asks me how the show was, it was good enough for me to say that the show was good, and they should give it a try.

Just from viewing the title and poster i assumed it was a typical fan service anime, but boy was i ever wrong. Never would actually expect this anime to actually have such a deep complex meaning towards life. Going to put minimum amount of spoilers as possible on this review :)
Basically the anime revolves around the life of a High school teenager Sakuta, trying to live his daily life normally, but supernatural occurrences known as "Puberty syndrome" is affecting the people or lets just say the girls he encounters. Whom he must try and help.
Characters 9/10
We have our two main characters Sakuta and Mai, their personalities a lot refreshing and enjoyable to watch, also it contrasts a lot with each other but when two come together they carry good quality conversations and really have a good chemistry for a romance anime. 

They aren't the usual cliched characters with the same generic background, behavior pattern as most of the high school characters have. So that's a bonus. 


The main male character or lets say the "Rascal" Sakuta, who has a nice refreshing quiet, self-contained attitude and with a kind of a interesting dark past which slowly gets revealed during the series as story progresses.

But what sets him apart from the other normal MC's is his surprisingly normal, cool yet interesting personality, his high quality conversations which most of the time are sarcasm, his humor, ability to talk to female characters at a refreshing way.even able to roast them and crack jokes at them especially with his famous semi lewd jokes which is definitely enjoyable, but also his serious nature and ability to handle problems with intellectual prowess in a sensible and calm way when the situation arises like mainly helping the girls with the puberty syndromes. 

Also i forgot to mention our boy has a bit of a fetish of masochism which is presented in a quite humorous way. :3


Then we have our Female MC or lets say Sakuta's "Bunny Girl Senpai", Mai who is a fairly famous actress, goes to the same school as him, and the first girl he helps with the syndrome. A beautiful calm matured girl with a sense of maturity, also has a bit of a tsundere personality not too much which i find really refreshing and nice to see. 

Also speaking of other good traits, she cooks well,skilled at her work and studies, knows how to support Sakuta when in need, being romantic to him at times and also knows how to keep him in check giving him a little bit of physical punishment like pinching him and stepping on his foot etc. Yep Best girl qualities for sure.


Other side characters too which i found personally interesting and likable. For example


Futaba rio, sakuta's close school friend, who's really sensible, smart and a science student, mostly found working in the chemistry lab and whom sakuta seeks advice for the syndrome problem and is the main source of help for him.

Also she likes to tease and insult sakuta in a friendly way, and every time calling him a Buta yarou (Rascal). 


Kunimi his very close male friend whom he knows for a long time, A carefree, athletic,jolly guy,  together with futaba all three of them are like really good friends. 


Toga , Sakuta's Junior in school, who is a little scatterbrained, and is a bit over conscious of her social life and status and  how other people look at her. 


Kaede, the most adorable and cute girl in the series in my opinion,Sakuta's younger sister. who had a incident in her past due to which she confined herself at home,  loves her elder brother and panda's the most and also is timid and shy to talk to others. 

Clings to sakuta when he awakes in the morning, tries to express her sisterly love in the most adorable manner. Really is a heartwarming and lovable character.


There are other good characters too which are interesting, not boring and good personalities too, but didn't appeal to me that much.  


Story 8/10

Anyways coming to the main story, more than romance the plot is basically about Puberty Syndrome affecting the girls and how Sakuta tries to solve them.

The syndrome's are so well presented and how their connections are explained in relevance to actual Scientific theories for example Schrodinger's cat, Laplace's demon etc.

But more importantly how these syndrome occurrences are due to the emotions, the personality, and the past of the characters in the story and actual in real life problems too.

Each girl with syndrome is given a certain set of episodes,which is the Syndrome arc, and it goes at a good pace and good character conversations and meaningful interactions which will hook you. 


You could say the viewers can feel the same vibes as the monogatari series (If you have watched the series that is), especially with the main characters personality and different encounters with the girls. 

Art/Animation 8/10

Speaking of Animation and art, Its really detailed, clean and well made.Color quality is good too and well balanced. Will kinda remind you of Oregairu. Cloverworks did a good job overall though.


Sound 9/10

Going to sound, Nothing much to talk about, Sound quality is good, especially with background music which goes well with the occuring scenario and scenes 

The Opening Song (Kimi no Sei) though by the Peggies is amazing, from the animation, the scenes and the visuals, how it is presented to the lyrics.


Also i like the ending song (Fukashigi no Carte) which is really pleasant and interesting to watch, because it has a nice melody to it,apart from the music changes with each arc,syndrome and the girl concerned and is sung by the VA of the respective girl. Good Stuff.


Conclusion: 

Lastly, i would say that  this series is really good.The supernatural element with the mysteries of “puberty syndrome”, how it is presented,explained, connected and solved. 

A good bit of romance, a bit of slice of life and comedy, roller coaster of emotions, drama and plot twists with such good refreshing MC's and other characters with good interactions, development, visuals with good pacing is really more than worth your time.

A really High recommended watch for sure.

Having watched a lot of romcom animes in the past this was a nice surprise.
Seishun combines romance, comedy, supernatural elements and modernism in a fresh new way.
The series manages through character interaction and comedic timing to make you feel for the characters. Even early in the show does it test your loyalty to the characters and make you relate to their journey.
The supernatural element tends to be a tough deal like in kokoro connect, but it tends to feel alright in this one because of the sudden appearance of a new plot.
What I meant with modernism was more related to my own viewing experience ofromcom animes. \n
The more casual sex jokes and a more casual approach to relationships is different than previous shows in the genre. There's more focus on comedy and quick romantic feelings rather than building it up slowly. \n
That felt like a new thing to me though not bad in its own right.\n\n
A comedic and romantic show with a strong focus on characters and also tackles both old and modern tropes in anime. \n
A must view for anyone active in this community.

This is the Deishuu Kaiki of anime shows - an imposter that succeeds even though it's a fake. It's a "low"-effort deliberately engineered masterpiece-wannabe you cannot miss, because you may end up LOVING it. That is - if you forgive its great sins. Even if you don't - you may still enjoy the ride.
I usually refrain from watching new anime shows during their premiere season, but when a BILLIONAIRE recommends a new anime to another BILLIONAIRE on Twitter you cannot just pass on the opportunity to check what all the fuss is about.
This is a very enjoyable show and definitely worth watching, but it has3 glaring problems:


1.PRETENSE. 

It has a vibe of a manufactured piece of work by a craftsman who, without any deeper understanding, simply copied all the tricks that worked before. A well known method in many arts - when something works just do it again. Chances are it will, indeed, work again - even if you don't understand why.

It borrows heavily from deeply flawed, but in their own ways masterful and inspiring shows like Haruhi, Bakemonogatari and Oregairu. The difference is these shows knew exactly what they were trying to accomplish and succeeded at. It copies some of their tricks quite well (nothing bad in that), but it mostly fails at copying their charms and there is not much of its own, original one. It's like tracing a human form from an artwork of a genius - the character in your art will also have perfect anatomy, like in the original, but all the rest will fall flat - just like the story in this anime...


The world is shallow like in an average slice of life anime, which is baffling for a supernatural genre. There is seemingly a lot of mystery, but there is not a bit of a mysterious atmosphere. Nothing. Nada. It tries to hide its shallowness behind some pseudo-scientific jibberish that adds nothing to the story, but at least it can create illusion of depth that some viewers will appreciate.


2. CYNICISM. 

Overly witty dialogues might be impressive to some, but they are so artificial and unauthentic the characters turn into "smartass" types instead of the insightful, intelligent people creators most likely thought they were making.

People say that the main couple has great chemistry and to some extent I agree, but It's really hard to escape that impression of overdone dialogues that may make you roll eyes. People don't talk like that. If you want believable wittiness with intelligent flirtation that can allure you with sweet teasing then watch Spice and Wolf and see how a beautiful, romantically implied chemistry actually works.


There is also another overdone thing, which is actually the biggest offender in this anime:

3. INDIFFERENCE. 

The characters are so full of themselves, so smart and above all and everything they wouldn't even care if the Earth was hit by an asteroid as big as their egos. Nothing impresses them, because they are apparently too cool to be impressed by anything. This is another example of not understanding the shows it was inspired by, where wittiness and cynicism was balanced with fears, insecurities and other emotions and imperfections that made the characters extremely human. There are some flawed secondary characters there, but the MC and his closest friends are just androids saying their well written lines.


This review may give impression that I'm hating on this anime, which is not the case. Despite the fact it's just a "fake smart anime" it's also a lot of fun. I realize that and still enjoy it, so I blame myself for falling for these simple patterns this anime exploits, not the authors. 

After all, this is the Deishuu Kaiki of anime shows.

Welcome to the low-key best anime of Fall 2018. Don't let the anime cover fool you. The anime is definitely not here to shove the image of a hot bunny babe to everyone's eyes, but do enjoy it in the short moments that they do. 
The anime follows the story of Azusagawa Sakuta, the chillest and probably the best mc of the season. Sakuta is a laid-back high school loner because he "doesn't care about the atmosphere." The atmosphere is an imaginary something that people especially the youth consciously or unconsciously follow so that they could fit in.  It's a bit too complex toput into words, but the plot kinda reminds me of OreGairu which is another good watch if you haven't watched it. One day, Sakuta meets the hot celebrity senpai in a bunny suit Sakurajima Mai. Turns out Mai-senpai can't be seen by most people anymore due to the Adolescence Syndrome. (Again, pretty complex thing to explain but the anime is really good at explaining it so have patience.)


Story: 9

Story is not very realistic, and the conflicts are centered around the phenomenons that happen to the characters. Not really problem for me. Not completely unique as well. The conflicts in the anime  reminds me of Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya. If you enjoyed that, chances are you will enjoy this too. You will definitely love the conversations here. Witty and provides good laughs without trying hard. Really just good script and chemistry of personalities of characters.


Characters: 9

Characters are not ultimately special, but you'll grow fond of them, they have their uniqueness and personalities that gives interesting and witty delivery of conversations


Art: 10

Art is just so good. I normally dont complain or say anything about art. Simply it just looks stunning, and proportions of body are very well.


Sound: 9

I dont ask a lot for sounds, but the OP is hella catchy while the ED is also nice and gives off that kind of sad, melancholic feeling when you finish the episode wanting for more.


Enjoyment: 10

I wait for this the most if not Goblin Slayer. (On the other hand, Sao alicization seems not keeping up with the excitement I used to have with it)


Overall: 9

Cant score perfect 10, feels like a biased score and I believe this isnt yet a masterpiece and season's far from over, but the anime is currently scored 8.55 overall and thats really high

Ok...so i dont really write reviews....but come on....this anime blew me away...like edge of my seat, crying, and shaking, that first episode draws you in for a bukkake of feels....and the next one locks you in for a feels train that so intense and deep....you'll feel like a changed person...
The story is so deep, and the mysterious is so flippin sexy....i love it...
Ohhh...dont get me started on the potential waifus....
Animation is decent, negitive for using CGI....but tbh most anime do...
Ohhh....almost forgot....the Music....ugh....way to good ' like getting ear Fu#ked by Frank Sinatra and house music.
Now tbh... im a weeb down to my weeby core....ive seenmost anime this year like the weeb that i am, but this anime takes Number one spot for anime this year, for me atleast....\n
If you have not seen this anime.....what are doing....?\n
-korutaku, A Freindly Weeb

¡Me gusto mucho!


Al empezar me enganché a este casi de forma inmediata. Hasta me impresionaba lo rápido que pasa el tiempo cuando la visualizo, aunque no puedo decir que tengo un amplio catálogo de animes vistos, si puedo decir: "¡Guau, esto me está gustando más de lo normal!".


No pensé en escribir nada, me da flojera. Lo que me animo a escribir es que aunque tiene buena puntuación general las reviews que más destacan son mayormente negativas y quería aportar un poco a un anime que sí, se lo merece.


La historia es buenisima y continúa a buen pie pero el final no fue de lo mejor, lo sentí algo apresurado, pero estoy satisfecho. Le sumo a su vez su arte que en general, aunque no tiene la mejor animación, su opening y ending (sobre todo el ending) son fantásticos.


Su sonido es muy bueno, el opening engancha y el ending enamora, y además si dan atención al ending, con cada cambio se escucha una voz diferente (como si cada personaje tuviera su propia voz). No hablaré de los personajes, tienen que verlo. El protagonista no es un princeso, se vé que dice y hace lo correcto porque és así, no es forzado. El resto de personajes también deben verlas, no me quiero extender esto ya que cada personaje tiene su personalidad definida y si las digo perdería la emoción por conocerlas.


Y es todo, espero que guste como me expreso al escribir y que sea entendible. Esto va para la comunidad habla hispana ¡que no les veo! Gracias por leer, por lo menos sé, o creo, que leiste el principio y el final ¿no?. Chao :)

This is my first time writing anything on this site because I just like to enjoy anime and don't really care whether or not people approve of what I like to watch. But after seeing how some people are treating this anime I felt like I just had to share my ideas on it too.
First and foremost I gotta say that this anime isn't at all like others of the same genre and i'm saying this after watching almost every popular anime of the genres involved, it's most definitely one of the best these genres have to offer
The characters, specially the MC and the MaineHeroine however were definitely more interesting, endearing, rational and lovable than any other anime of the same genre I have seen before. I recommend this anime wholeheartedly!\n
I know me saying how good it is doesn't really make much of a difference to someone who's already decided whether this anime is any good or not but I just wanted to write the stuff I love about this great show, I thought I owed the anime and it's creators that much. \n

It was a fantastic anime with a unique premise. The vibe was very similar to the vibe in “Your Name”, except it was gloomier. The introduction to the first arc with Mai instantly got me hooked. From the MC’s interaction with his school friends to his interactions with his little sister at home, each held some weight. Each scene, episode, and arc had meaning. To some extent, each character was explored and had a separate arc or episode of their own. They were all unique in their own little way; this tedious detail left a big impression on me. The pacing of each episode wasperfect. The morals and actions of each character made sense and were followed to a fault. The ending of the anime was heartbreaking, but it was also unforgettable. It left a sense of longing. “Did everything that just occurred happen for naught”?

I actually planned to complain about the negative comments here, but I rather want to prove them wrong because it better brings my point across, that this anime is amazing. 
I heard many people say that Sakuta Azusagawa is a shit character, I disagree! Sure he may have said things to girls like are you on your period, but this is completely taken out of context. Sakuta was told by a girl to leave one of his best friends alone because of Sakutas bad reputation (which is also due to a false rumor, which he isn’t responsible for) This girl is also the girlfriend ofhis best friend and thinks she is „caring“ for her boyfriend by doing so. To this Sakuta teases her with asking if she is on her period, to which the girl responds with go die. 

Sakuta is one of the kindest character I’ve seen in Anime. He actually adopted the philosophy of being a nicer person everyday. It is not the typical harem anime. Sure girls have problems, and he helps them cope with them, but other than with Mai he never shows any kind of doing it so they Love him. He does it because he cares, most of the times. If he doesn’t already have a deeper connection with someone he developes it by helping them. There is no goal other than to help others the same way a distinct girl helped him, but I won’t talk about her to much in case you haven’t watched the show.


You know what is also great about this show, the character are all human. Everyone is trying their best, but it is hard fighting alone, so the push Sakuta gives them actually isn’t the reason they are happy. He is the trigger that makes people stand up for themselves and ultimately let’s them choose not to follow the crowds expectations. 


I could talk about a lot more but I think nobody will read further so I am just writing one last sentence. Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai, is not for everyone, but if you listen closely to the dialogue, the characters will make you root for them and will in the end make you cry.

Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai is overrated, mediocre, and astonishingly egregious that takes influences from different light novel animations and doesn't know what to do with it. 
There' have been praises from Bunny Girl Senpai over the Fall Season from different anime critics. One of the positive criticisms from the anime was that it felt like the Monogatari Series. The only comparison that people said was that the main characters help other girls with their problems.
However...
The art, animation, and sound design weren't critiqued or mentioned anywhere. 
Therefore, my only strategy going into this anime was to expect nothing more or less sinceI want to learn why people like this anime so much.


I expected nothing from this anime... yet I was still disappointed. 


Story -- 3


The plot is simple. We have our protagonist, who is a male,  and also an average high school boy that take their free-time devoting himself to different female characters. These problems oppress them and there would be a solution for their issue. Of course, the method is specific. 


The concept of this anime uses Quantum Physics, supernatural events, atmosphere, and puberty syndrome (which is a made-up term). The atmosphere in the anime determines whether or not you want to keep out of their situation. 

The use of theories from Quantum Physics (Copenhagen Interpretation, Laplace Demon, etc.) is outstandingly stupid because of how it's interpreted and used to solve these supernatural events even though it has nothing to do with their "problems." To use a high school explanation of Quantum Physics for the purpose giving it an excuse of adding depth to solve these "complex issues" proves that this was written by a pseudo-intellectual. It gets even worse when the writing, after a couple of episodes, give up on Quantum Physics explanations and idiotically write out many pointless supernatural events which had nothing to do with Quantum Physics. 


It also doesn't help when the pacing is just ridiculously slow when every arc is just a beach episode for its own. There are scenes where I wished they could end quickly and move on to the meat of the anime. Whatever thoughts I received from these pointless fillers are always how miserable the supporting characters are, how boring the comedy feels, and how awful some scenes were which their only purpose was to make the character look cool. The filler is just there to add a humongous tautology. There was no foreshadowing, depth, or enjoyment whatsoever. 


Every ending is also an anticlimax, too. 


Character -- 3


Azusagawa Sakuta, the male protagonist of the anime, is an ostentatious jerk who shamelessly harasses classmates while helping them in situations they somehow couldn't solve. This behavior from the main character appears constantly in almost every episode and the script wants you to laugh at it only for it to become dull over time.  His second quality as a character was his background which we didn't learn more about until the very last arc of the anime. There was no development to be noted from the main character because he's just too one-dimensional in every arc and basically does nothing cool; not even something remarkable UNTIL the very last arc. 

Therefore, Azusagawa Sakuta is nothing more but a jerk who just helps other girls out of self-interest and the scar on his chest is nothing more but to feel bad for the main character. I can't even find any relatability or any deep meaning towards his actions. His actions are just dumb and he's not even aware of it sometimes. 


Now mentioning the main character, I should tell you that the other characters are practically dumb as well; the characters are too dumb to solve their problems which can they can be relieved from by doing one simple action. That simple action is effective for most of their cases because it just shows how the concept of the atmosphere is so boring in this anime. 


JUST! DO! IT! 


No wonder why the anime was terrible pacing because instead of making actual complex themes and explore them or just getting it over with, the script decides it would be a great idea to prolong the end of the arc as if the script was aware that the circumstances in the anime are just too stupid and easily solvable. The pacing couldn't even give more depth to the character. 

Mai Sakurajima receives little to no character development, and the chemistry between Sakuta and her is very transparent, but I couldn't care more for her problems; although there was one part where I do feel bad slightly. Tomoe Koga is also annoying since her only problem was that the main character wasn't attracted enough to her. Understanding Futaba Rio was also annoying. Despite her being smart in Physics, she wastes three episodes just to conclude that the only way she can solve her issue was to communicate with her other self which the Quantum Physics explanations for her troubles doesn't make sense. Toyohama Nodoka is also annoying as her only problem was to be better than her accomplished opposite 

The rest of the supporting casts has no purpose for the story, and I've always questioned: "why do they deserve screen time?" 


However, there was only one character that stands out AND is better than the rest of these characters. Kaede's problems were more realistic than the other girls, and she solves her problems by doing something instead of relying heavily on the main character. This is also her arc where we get to see Sakuta's good qualities as a character. 


Sadly, I wished the other characters would actually feel more real so that they feel more appropriate for this story. These characters are but contestants for best comic instead of best drama.


Art -- 3 


The art was also terrible. The backgrounds were over saturated, the objects didn't have any textures or intricate details, the character designs were boring and unappealing, and the composition looks lame and unfocused sometimes. 

The composition was out of place because there were many CG cars that would distract you from following the main characters. There were also facial expressions in the backgrounds that looks awkward and distracting.


The animation was also terrible since the character movement would also look stiff. However, in other scenes, the animation would improve but would only last for a few seconds. 


The visuals are also boring to look at, too. 


Since this anime was made by "Cloverworks," I could completely understand why everything looked low quality.


Sound Design -- 4 


There was nothing remarkable about the sound direction for the anime since the sounds were designed by Iwanami. Everything sounded generic and uninspired. However, there was one sound clip where I had to confirm that my ears weren't interpreting incorrectly. After I confirmed it, I began laughing because the sound was too horrible to defend it.


The music was okay, I guess. I liked the ending song...


Enjoyment -- 1 


I did marathon this with someone I know since we halted at the same episode. Although watching it completely in a single day didn't wear us out completely. 


We had some good laughs, some confusions, and there were times when we got angry at the direction. But what this anime has proven was that seasonal anime that becomes popular by the consensus would always be terrible. 


It wouldn't matter how many times people tried to defend this...


If you enjoyed this anime or even this year, that's good for you. However, it'll be hard to convince me to return to popular stuff in future seasons since 2018 had killed it for me. 


Overall -- 2 


This review was written by a Monogatari fan. A big surprise that a concept similar to the Monogatari Series still wouldn't make me enjoy some of the trash I had to endure since it couldn't do anything well.

'Never judge a book by its cover' - This couldn't be more true with this anime, it is a treasure. Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai (Seishun Buta Yarou Wa Bunny Girl) is a superbly crafted series surrounding a high schooler called Sakuta and mysterious cases of 'adolescence syndrome' which gravitate towards him in everyday life.
In short, adolescene syndrome is unusual and varies case by case, but astonishingly mental scaring can manifest in the physical form. Some examples include: A desire to be ignored but results in becoming non existent, replaying days (think ground-hog day) to get a more desirable outcome, and evenhaving a split personally disorder which creates a copy of said person born from desires (notice me senpai?).


As you can tell, this disease is the integral theme running through the show, all of which draws the protagonist Sakuta. The anime is also enchanting from Sakuta's developing relationship with Mai, an actress on hiatus. From the first episode its explained that Mai is suffering from adolescence syndrome impacting her visibility in life. Here enters the bunny girl outfit.


The relationship between Sakuta and Mai is complicated at times, but along with the shows theme the anime does not become tedious and is in fact quite thought provoking for a show with bunny girl in it's title. The series explores struggles which may well hit home to some, including cases of online abuse, social anxiety and the desire for acceptance in the modern age.


Each character with adolescence syndrome is given time to express their individual personalities and you can't help but feel for their own unique hardships. I think the most heartbraking of them all is Sakuta's little sister, but you'll have to wait until the series climaxes to understand.


I watched the show via Crunchyroll Premium subbed and the story, art style and VAs are top notch! I must also give salute to the infectious opening Kimi No Sei by The Peggies. This tune perfectly suits the show, it's one of my favourite tunes from anime out in 2018. The lyrics are genius to pair with the relationship between Sakuta and Mai.


It's difficult for me to praise this anime much more without going into spoilers, but as I refrain from doing so in my reviews, what I will say is this... Give this anime a watch, cast aside any initial conceptions (you could easily overlook it) and get to the golden episode, for me that was episode three. At this stage you will truly start to understand why this series is worth persuing and sticking with.


This show was one of my absolute favourite's of the entire of 2018 - so I really do feel passionate in my attempts to persuade you to watch it! I honestly feel you will not be disappointed, especially if you (like me) enjoy slice of life anime with a dash of romantic comedy, but also want a show that stays with you.


If you need one thing to rope you in, check out the opening tune Kimi No Sei by The Peggies (It's so catchy!) 


I rate this anime 10/10 - Story pace, art style, VA, audio - it's the perfect package and I wish the series didn't end after 13 episodes. @RayeRayeChan


You can watch this show on Crunchyroll 


The trailer is available via AniplexUS

The main problem with this show is its lazy writing. It attempts to make some analogies with quantum physics and existentialism on the plot development but fails completely, to the point everything seems extremely forced and unconvincing. The core of the plot, which is the "adolescence syndrome" is in fact an interesting concept, as it depicts how society perceives you and how you perceive yourself. The problem is that this isn't explored at all throughout the series, as it lefts everything poorly explained, and it gets worse after the first half of the anime, as the plot feels very disconnected from its original idea. Maincharacters don't have enough carisma, and secondary ones have even less, yet the anime dedicates entire episodes to them, it's hard to understand. \n
Well, at least you could say the ending theme is nice.

If you are willing to ignore the constant over explanation of the plot device "Adolescence Syndrome" and an extremely uncharismatic main character I recommend this anime, due to its unique sense of emotion.
Adolescence Syndrome is used to represent emotions or other aspects of a character. And this is a very interesting idea. For example, a famous actor is nearly forgotten, evoking this unreal sense of loneliness. However, this sense of emotion is constantly being belittled by an attempt to create a 'mystery' within this anime, accompanied by extremely odd scientific analogies. It seems like the writers were unsure what this anime was meant to be.
Aswell, the main character is insufferable. While having many interesting traits, such his lack of a phone which gives this sense of willful isolation, his character contributes little except for a constant juvenile sarcasm. His remarks constantly ruined the mood throughout the show.\n\n
Overall, this shown has many interesting ideas and emotions, but the execution is just poor. So, if you are willing to ignore that, I recommend it.

This anime honestly is a love or hate. I personally loved this due to the characters and the mysterious story. The "puberty syndrome" is what this anime is mostly based off of. Most people were giving hate on this anime, but I'm here to say that this deserves a watch. It may seem like an ecchi/harem type anime from clips you see, but this is definitely not the case. The outro song as well is one of my favorites too because they change the singer with the main character it's focused on. Listen to the outro song as you watch the series and you'll noticeit changes ;). 


~sidenote~

The ending was suited but honestly could've been better. I hope that the movie and the second season come soon because I'm very hyped for them

Ah, Bunny girl Senpai, the show which lured me in thinking it was a show about girls in bunny costumes. While I did get a little bit of that (not as much as I expected), I definitely am not disappointed - this is a standout show. A great watch that was heartwarming, entertaining and relatable at times.
What actually makes this show great is that it is relatable - growing up we've all experienced certain things, the fear of being left out, not being part of the 'cool' people and being mocked; at times feeling we are lesser than others and wishing we could be them.Even though they did add some magical/sci-fi twists to it, the base of it all is realistic enough and is definitely something many of us can identify ourselves as having been there before.


The story and characters are amazingly written. They managed to flesh out and develop each character really well in a short span of time - usually 2 or 3 episodes per arc. The dialogue and interactions between characters was refreshing and entertaining - I loved the banter between our 2 MCs and basically Sakuta with anybody - speaking exactly what he thinks. The animation was decent - nothing exactly outstanding but it was good enough to complement the great story.


As for sound - I have to point out arguably the catchiest opening of the year. I literally sang along every episode like a fanboy - who wouldn't when you hear the unmistakable 'KIMI NO SEI KIMI NO SEI'. The ED was also great.


A really entertaining watch - yes, while it does have that Monogatari - Oregairu vibes and some accuse it of being a plain copy, they are actually pretty different and I appreciate that. 9/10 for me.

These last few months have been quite busy for me,and after i finally found some time to watch this highly spoken about anime,i have to admit that i was pleasantly surprised by it .So old school review,here we go:
STORY(8):
you can read the synopsis to understand the overall premise so i will concentrate on the most important aspects,first don't come into this expecting a fantastically written anime that tackles some highly deep and philosophical themes,it's your usual romcom but with much better execution,an amazing pacing and most importantly,the story never felt heavy,although some parts did feel quite forced and melodramatic,it wasn't enough to impact the flawof the overall story.


ART(8):

honestly,it fits the general athmosphere of the anime perfectly,well-balanced colors,great animation with very little derpy moments,very pleasant to the eyes,the animators did an amazing job,nothing more to say.


SOUND(6):

One of the things this anime could have done better to be frank,opening and ending seemed very generic and just didn't do it for me,the ost was also not very memorable ans sometimes straight up annoyed me to be honest,im a very big  music fan and it is a very capitalizing point for the show but it fortunately was able to make up on some other aspects.


Characters(6):


Ah,the characters,one of the things most people love about this show the most,for me they were just ALRIGHT,nothing more nothing less,I did love Mai,but when it comes to the mc of which i already forgot the name,meh,just meh,i din't really like him and he seemed just like your average light novel mc who's a perverted asshole,the last arc made me hate him even more but i dont want to spoil anything so ill just keep it at that.the imouto is cute but all that character devlopment just to be thrown out of the window at the end,why wtf?


enjoyment(9):

Ah,the subjective part,honestly im probably just biased cause i havent seen a show in quite some time and it just made me skip my judgement on so many aspects,i just turned off my brain and enjoyed the show das it.


overall(8):

Very good show that could have done way better,i defo dont agree with the current mal community score and if i wanted to be more technical the real score for me would be closer to 7.75 but i can only do a natural number so yeah.

would i recommend it?hell yeah.

Would i want another season? HELL YEAH.

Am i particularly excited for it?kind of.

Please ignore the review bombs that this show is receiving per its completion. These are not at all indicative of this show's quality. I not am against people having a negative opinion on the show, but it is clear when people deliberately attack it, in the hope of dropping down its score. 
So, what does "Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai" have to offer? What we have here is a quality high school drama, with a touch of the supernatural, disguised as quantum science.
Rascal Senpai has the viewer experience the high school life of the ensemble characters, surrounding the MP,as they struggle through everything from romantic hardships to social ostracization. These real life issues then manifest in physical form, like someone living two lives forming an actual clone of themselves. This allows those viewing to see, in a way, the struggles that people face within their own psyche in a more tangible sense.


For the lead we have Sakuta, a self described rascal. Rather he is a straight laced guy with a calm demeanor. Often he can come off a bit one note, but can be seen throughout the show as being multilayered, having moments of strong emotion for those he cares about.


What for most will be a draw-in for the show is the comedic and witty banter between the two leads, Sakuta and Mai, the romantic duo. Though there becomes less and less of this overall as the show progresses, the character writing remains strong throughout. The first three episodes on their own could be a self contained film and are arguably the strongest point in the 13 episode run time.


To summarize the positives; great characters, a few phenomenal character arcs, strong writing throughout, one of the more grounded romances in anime, consistently funny, and a real heart-string puller.


For negatives; A dip in animation quality here and there, a few anime tropes, an inconclusive ending, and no real overarching narrative.


None the less, these few negatives do not detract from the overall enjoyment, in my opinion. If you at all enjoy romance/drama, this is not one to miss. 9/10

Alright, since I've been seeing way too many negative elitist reviews on this show (even one literally saying it was plagiarism, why bother watching the whole thing if you said you hated it from episode 1), I thought I should forward my thoughts on it out there. I'll try keeping this short since I know you don't like reading a college paper on an ANIME review.
I like this show (A LOT), and now am dealing with the rare instance of feeling like an arrow just pierced through my soul. Out of the however many shows that came out this season, this was the only onethat I was able to watch all the way through, and I loved it.


A lot of people have been comparing this show to the likes of Monogatari and Oregairu, and I can definitely see where they're coming from. However, just because there are similar archetypes between the shows doesn't make Bunny Girl Senpai a direct copycat. 


From the very first episode, I became extremely intrigued to learn more about the characters and world. The witty dialogue was able to keep my attention throughout the episodes, and with me who isn't very interested slice of life shows, the show gets immense credit.


Most protagonists are cardboard cutouts of each other, and having one in a slice of life show where a great deal of the genre revolves around the characters, the show is inevitably hindered back. I'm happy to say however that Bunny Girl Senpai's MC, Sakuta, is a very intriguing character who says whatever's on his mind, creating many memorable and unique conversations.


The romance aspect of this show is something I'm extremely fond of, as unlike many harem-esk shows, Sakuta actually stays romantically committed to one girl, opposed to getting in the pants of every girl he stumbles across. Before I end this review I just need to put it out there that Mai is the best waifu of 2018.

Some might understand the anime, some  might not ....
The story is very unusual, it is unlike any other animes that I've seen, but the plot is kinda let down, you might not understand things about this anime, it is a problem solving anime, it tackles different problems like bullying, not being true to your self, and such.
The good thing about this is its character and art. You will surely fall inlove with the girl characters, like mai sakurajima in bunny suit, sakuta  is great male mc his not a usual mc...
Hopefully the movie will be great...
I definitely recommend you to watch this anime,if you are type of person that loves to watch anime but wanted a unusal or unique anime.

Usually, I stray away from harem-bait type shows and I find anime romance over the top, but I have to say I really enjoyed this show.
I'll start with the cons first :
-The animation leaves a lot to be desired, although it's not to the point where you consistently notice the drop in quality.
-It is one of those shows where the male MC solves all the girls' problems. Some people might consider this a con, but I recommend watching this either way.
Pros:
-The characters have actual chemistry and their relationships are actually believable. Don't let first impressions fool you, it's not a harem-y show, It has alot of powerful messages and refreshing character interactions. (very reminiscent of Monogatari)\n\n
-The music is great. Some people might find the OP a little jarring, but personally, I found myself singing along to it. The ED is especially beautiful.\n\n
-The story is touching and somehow relatable. It's like daily life meets supernatural phenomena. Cliche at first but all the scenarios are well done.\n\n
I say watch this show without overhyping yourself. I find that a lot of people end up disliking shows because they were expecting a masterpiece. Create your own opinion first.\n\n

I haven't really done a formal review on this site before; usually I just include some brief comments on the tags of each entry in my anime list, but I just finished this show today, and I have some thoughts on it, so I figured this was a good time to start writing reviews :D
Anyway, I'm not going to bother delving into each sub-category, since I know that some people may just want an earnest reflection instead of a fragmented review (which is what I prefer in reading them)
Bunny-girl Senpai is not a show I originally intended to watch this season, as the title andposter made me believe it was a harem of some sorts, and that genre isn't something I typically jump at without reason to. But after seeing how well it was doing I checked it out, and ended up loving it. I don't know how many people would agree with this remark, but the show screamed "Monogatari"....Like....a stoic and detached protagonist helps one tsundere girl get rid of her paranormal problem brought upon her by her mental and emotional distress, then ends up dating her afterwards, then helping other girls with similar problems.....it literally sounds just like Monogatari's synopsis. I think that similarity is the primary reason why this anime has done so well....However it's lackluster in comparison to the great Monogatari. For one, while I love stoic protagonists, I feel that Azusagawa became less and less interesting as the show went on....one of the major things that killed him is how his demeanor did nothing to match his personality. To take Araragi as an example: Araragi started his series heavily detached, and stoic, but as his relationships and experiences grew it was apparent that his demeanor was loosening. He became more social, and outgoing, and wise as a result of his exploits. Azusagawa on the other hand, goes through similar experiences but doesn't really change as a result. The only changes we see are in his freakouts which are super uncharacteristic to the point that they just weirded me out, because Azusagawa really just went from one extreme to another, rather than slowly getting more emotional as the story progresses.


One strong point that this series has (and everyone seems to acknowledge) is the realistic and charming nature of the relationship between Azusagawa and Mai. This however, is also a bootleg version of Araragi and Senjougahara's relationship from Monogatari.....as in the dynamic is LITERALLY the same, only that, yet again, there is no growth outside the start of their relationship. Their interactions are enjoyable, but the sad part is that the relationship doesn't really deepen at all, which loses it a lot of points.


There's also Futaba, your bootleg Tsubasa (aka large chested, glasses wearing science girl who acts as the main protag's guide of sorts in dealing with numerous situations) also from Monogatari :D Only that yet again......you can guess the rest at this point :\n

Anyway, to sum it all up, this show had an extremely strong start, which is why I was so into it during the 1st 8 episodes or so (I even considered a 10 rating), but then the show's hard weakness set in: its lack of development. And I know I compared this show to Monogatari a lot, but that's because Bunny-girl is literally the same show only shallower and sub-par by comparison. My end verdict: If this show interests you and you haven't watched all of the Monogatari series yet: Watch the Monogatari series. It is far, far lengthier, but it is well worth it. Otherwise, for those who have watched Monogatari: watch it if you really feel like it, but be warned that this show becomes more lackluster as it goes on, ESPECIALLY if you start to become aware of the Monogatari similarities, as they'll make you appreciate the show less. However, if you watch the show all in one sitting, I think that the momentum from the 1st half of the show should carry over to the other half. I watched this show as it was coming out, so I didn't really get that option :( 


I really don't think that this show deserves the 8.67 it has as of me writing this review :\ If I could give decimal ratings, I would rate this show more of a 7.7. I think there are plenty of shows this season that deserve that score instead.....*cough**cough* SSSS Gridman *cough**cough* Run with the Wind *hack*

Pros:
- Interesting concept, even if many of the story arcs and phenomena occurring are highly derivative of other (in my opinion, superior) anime.  There's enough of a unique twist to keep it from feeling like just a rehash of other series
- Characters are all likable and easy to connect with in some way or another.  The phenomena that occur throughout creates a great sense of drama and character development throughout making the story that much more interesting
- Satisfying conclusion
- Artwork looks amazing throughout.  There are some very rich uses of colors and some interesting "camera" angles throughout
- Probably the funniest anime allseason (even though I wouldn't call it a comedy necessarily).  The deadpan delivery of some of the more ridiculous lines makes it even better.


- I really like the OP to this.


Cons:


- As mentioned previously, some of the derivative elements from other series stick out like a sore thumb.  In some cases its almost an entire reenactment of events but with different characters.  This problem gets resolved after the first three episodes.


- Deceptive title and summary could turn people off to an otherwise great show.


- Too many bath scenes.  Not really a major con, per se, mostly just an observance.  When I look back on this show, I'll most likely think of people taking baths.  Just saying.


Overall: 


Aside from one other show (that I have yet to find out the conclusion of) this is probably the best series of the Fall 2018 season.  Its a shame the promotion of this was so crappy, because it really does give perspectives to the psychological experience during adolescence and early adulthood in a very creative way.  While it does take a few episodes for the plot to really get interesting, I still recommend this if you enjoy romantic comedies with some drama and psychological twists as I do.

This Déjà vu feeling of SNAFU and monogatari series looming in, you got the edgy character who's sarcasm out weights everything, making even serious moments a joke and then the whole anime about solving issues of all the girls, yes top-teir waifu list. And to add more the gimmick of all time in anime if something can't be realistically portrayed, we have 'Quantum mechanics'. Why is time not moving forward? 'Quantum mechanics', oh, there are two exactly same character,' Quantum mechanics', incest? ' Quantum mechanics'. But honestly speaking this anime was worth while, with puberty and adolescence as the go to main theme here, theanime tries to tackle it in the most interesting way, bring in girls cause that's what appeals this market. With each character 'problem' arc being around 2 or more episodes, I think this anime brings out issues like bullying, your first love, rejection, identity crisis and more. And that ties well with the theme of puberty and how everyone is not exactly perfect during this times with doing stupid stuffs like there is no tomorrow but if you have never experienced any of the above, you're an absolute chad. Now moving on the cause this is suppose to be a structured review, the art or the look of the anime is kinda bonkers, could've been better, I mean look at our protagonist, the BG character looks way better, maybe the budget was for the waifus after all. And then the characters itself, where the usual suspect at, where the dere's at? And finally the sound "Kimi no Sei=kanashii ureshii". So is it a watch, up to you honestly, It's anime man, just watch it. Some may like it, some have 'Quantum mechanic' IQ and may not enjoy, who am I to judge?

Finally got to watch the show after waiting for all the episodes to air so I can binge watch it (glad I did because some of the cliffhangers would have felt like torture). I was suprised to find that the show lived up to my expectations it was fantastic and I found myself flying through every episode. I was planning on taking a break from anime because I am feeling a little burnt out but this show was so good I can't help but want to search for more like it.
I enjoyed every episode, all the episodes had something to offer whether it be humour,the interactions between everyone or advancing the plot.


The MC was brilliant he actually made me laugh a lot and was a likeable character who wasn't wimpy or afraid of girls like most anime MC's are in rom com's. Mai was a great female lead, not sure what she is classed as but she didn't seem to be a tsundere she actually felt less like a character type and more realistic. She didn't hit the MC or belittle him; she just teased him - although it usually backfired. Honestly both of the leads of this show are some of my favourite anime leads ever and if it wern't for them the show wouldn't be anywhere near as good as it is. I also liked his three friends and sister. I was glad Kunimi was actually useful and not a joke character like the MC's guy friends usually are in other anime.


To those who kept saying it was like Monogatari and Oregairu. I can kind of see that although I think only the first 2 episodes felt like Oregairu the rest not so much, the structure and characters did remind me of Monogatari though (if Monogatari was a bit more normal). The stucture of a new supernatural arc every few episodes, Kaede and Tomoe's stories felt kind of like Nadeko's being split into two. Mai also reminded me somewhat of Senjougahara and Sakuta is pervy and helpful like Araragi. But again this show is more normal compared to Monogatari (don't mean that in a bad way - their different but similar).


One thing I was worried about was that there would be too much fan-service because the MC is meant to be a bit pervy and the whole Bunny Girl aspect. In the end I was pleasantly suprised and found like no fan-service I am so happy about that because I hate fan-service in animes. Even Oregairu had too much fan-service and weird camera angles in my opinion, really not a fan of that.


If the show ends here and doesn't get a season 2 I would be okay with that, the ending felt somewhat satisfying and I hear there will be a movie covering the Shoko story. However, I would still like a season 2 but currently there doesn't seem to be enough content to make a season 2.


Now I am going to go look for more anime like this.

From the first episode, Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai was not what anyone expected at first glance. I for one came to see a cute girl in a bunny outfit and I am pretty sure that goes for most of us who decided to watch the show. I expected a harem, ecchi story but instead received a well-written, interesting story. The harem setup is there but the show is not a harem at all. Bunny Girl Senpai is entertaining, fun and at the same time tackles mature and realistic situations. 
“Puberty syndrome- abnormal experiences rumored on the internet to be causedby sensitivity and instability during adolescence”. This is what the story in Bunny Girl revolves around. Just teens going through the hardships of adolescence. But abnormal things occur to them. For some reason I decided to check if it was an actual illness after seeing the first episode so I can assure you it is not an actual illness. Just something made up for the plot of the story. 


The story starts off with Sakuta Azusagawa, a high school student who one day sees a bunny girl at the library, appear in front of him. That girl is Mai Sakurajima, Sakuta’s upperclassman and popular celebrity actress on hiatus. She is experiencing puberty syndrome and is invisible to most people around her. Sakuta is on a mission to help her overcome the problem that is causing this phenomenon. Mai is not the only one experiencing this though. Throughout the story, other girls start appearing with puberty syndrome and Sakuta is the one who helps them. 


Besides the attractive girls in the show, the concept of puberty syndrome is what kept me watching the show every week. As stated earlier, the characters in the show are going through the hardships of adolescence but abnormal things are happening to them. For example, Mai’s effect from puberty syndrome is that she is invisible to nearly everyone around her and forgotten by them as well. This is because she is overwhelmed by the show biz and hates that her mother forced her to do things and unconsciously wishes to not be known at all. Tomoe Koga has this effect of repeating the current day she is in and living a simulated future. This is because she is unhappy with how situations turn out for her. She wants things to go her way, wants to be liked and accepted by everyone and does not want to have a bad reputation. We have all gone through something similar that the characters are going through. Adolescence is one of the most significant points in our lives. We are developing not only physically but psychologically as well. We have a lot going on during this period and I believe the show captures it appropriately. I guess that is why I found it appealing. 


In addition to Mai being my favorite character, I really enjoyed Sakuta as well. He is cheeky and a smug character and makes sarcastic remarks most of the time. He has all these girls around him but isn’t all googly eye for them like other MC in other animes. There are rumors about him going around school, sort of giving him a bad rep but he is pretty much careless. Besides all this, Sakuta is a person who sincerely cares about others. Before the events of the story, Sakuta and his sister, Kaede, go through puberty syndrome themselves. Seeing his sister in a bad state makes Sakuta feel terrible. At his lowest point, he meets Shoko Makinohara, his first love if I am correct. She is there for Sakuta when he needs support and helps him get through his situation. Shoko is the one who sort of shapes Sakuta into who he is in the present. He understands what it feels like to be in a situation where you feel almost incapable of doing anything. Just like Shoko was there for him in his time of need, Sakuta wants to be there for his friends who are emotionally feeling unstable. I believe this is what makes Sakuta a great character and that is why I like him as well. 


The OST for this anime was nice and the animation was well done as well. I really liked the character designs for all the girls and I’d like to say that it is also what kept me watching the show as well. The dialogue is nothing special but it is really intriguing. Of course, my favorite interaction is between Sakuta and Mai. The dialogue between them is great. It feels authentic. The romance between them is good too. It is not over the top. It feels natural. I’d like to say that it is a pretty good representation of how relationships actually are. Apart from the fact that Sakuta is with a new girl every other week and Mai does her best to not be bothered by it. Do that in real life and you are getting dumped pretty quickly…Unless you have someone as loyal and understanding as Mai, in which that case, you are one lucky person and I envy you for finding true love. 


I have seen people have trouble with the explanations given by Futaba about the abnormal situations the characters are facing due to puberty syndrome. They say it is nonsense and vague. To those people, I would like to say: IT IS AN ANIME. I mean if you really expect a in depth explanation to each phenomenon happening then you really have high standards and probably did not enjoy this anime as much as others. Just go with what they give you. I don’t think the exposition is what you should be focusing on in this show. The main focus should be on the characters, their emotions and situation. That is what the anime is about. Adolescence. The explanation as to why it is occurring is secondary and not as important. 


I have to end with some criticism I believe. I would have liked the story more if the characters didn’t just seem to disappear after their stories ended. I kind of completely forgot Koga existed a few episodes after her arc ended. If Futaba had not been important to the story then I would have forgotten about her to. Each character did have their time to shine and it was done well so it is not that big of a deal. Also, the ending did feel sort of open ended and rushed. It felt jammed and I feel like an extra episode or two could have made it better. Apparently, a movie is coming out sometime in the future so it might answer some questions that were left unanswered. 


I enjoyed this anime more than I should have and I am guessing that is because of the lack luster summer season. This is probably my favorite anime of the fall season. If you are looking to watch a cute girl wander around in a bunny outfit for 13 episodes straight then this is not the show for you. Believe me, I was also disappointed at the lack of appearance made by my bunny girl waifu. If you are looking for an entertaining show with a good story and a great cast of characters, then yes I do recommend that you watch Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai.
