This is another season where the popularity of the most watched show is unwarranted. But then again, that is basically every season. When we take a look about what people have been saying about Bunny Girl Senpai, the results are totally polarized. There are folks who will call this show garbage and give it a rating ranging from 1-4 and another group who will rate it 9-10 and discuss how it provokes meaningful thoughts on the nature of its themes, how great an experience it was during this season of anime.
Spoiler Alert: I belong in the first group!
Bunny Girl Senpai was a lot of funwhen first going in. The animation is decent, although CGI crept in at some horrifying intervals and those proved bigger jump scares than anything Goblin Slayer had to throw at me. The theme song was a little catchy, but the ending not so much. It was a bit of a surprise for most and you can see the subversion of expectations as everyone applauds it so much now, and I suspect for the reason that I am alluding to. With such a ridiculous title, everyone was expecting another uninspired light novel adaptation and to receive something that even dares to scratch at mediocrity was manifested tenfold in quality to these people who need only a little bit of nudging in their pleasure spots to have them raving about its merits. 


Sakuta is the protagonist and he doesn’t really care about many things, except being a good older brother although you don’t really see that side to him too much until later on when it starts becoming more prevalent in the plot. He’s a witty smartass who also happens to help everyone in his harem’s problems. It’s really sweet actually. To counterbalance that witty smartass demeanor, we have Mai who is quite as cynical and matching in verbosity throughout the series. Their dynamic serves as a focal point for the series’ narrative to unravel in multiple directions without straying too far. Many herald their relationship as the best couple of the year and I am not sure what to say to those people except that their relationship is a little strange. We have two characters that are more archetypal high school characters than actual individuals and while they may have quick banter and back and forth, that does not equate with any semblance of profundity in their relationship. Sometimes directors have their characters come across with the appearance of snappy dialogue to obscure the fact that there’s nothing actually special or clever going on underneath the surface. Anything in Bunny Girl Senpai is done extraordinary more impressively in something like OreGairu.


Before I go on and make that passage any more long than it needs to be, I should actually address the premise of the show. By that, I mean the concept of “Puberty Syndrome”. Look, it makes sense to have a ridiculously titled show have a ridiculous made-up pseudoscientific disease to go along with it. Even better, they have the audacity to tie actual scientific concepts such as “Schrodinger’s cat” and use it to explain away literally anything that has to do with “Puberty Syndrome”, especially early on in the show when the viewer has the most questions pertaining to first what it is and second why the hell it should be in the show to begin with as a plot device. Many of the decisions they go with concerning the syndrome are consistently insulting to the viewer. I have seen complicated scientific ideas play out in a fictional sphere and more often than not, they are used quite terribly. However, there have been some phenomenal cases where I have witnessed with my own two humanoid eyes there to have been success. The Zero Escape video games for example, in their entire trilogy, have consistently confronted the most obtuse ideas in their already complicated narrative. Virtue’s Last Reward tackles Schrodinger’s cat and String theory for a bloody example! Here we have puberty syndrome, which we understand is supposed to be a manifestation of the latent complexities and hardships of being an adolescent. I’m young too, not young enough to be in high school anymore, but young enough to remember how terrible that entire ordeal is. But I don’t need people out there to be presented with such a cheap imitation of that process.


In addition, what kind of flawed protagonist did we need to have take us through this series? I understand Sakuta has some brilliant if not over the top sections in the final episodes with Kaede, but these female characters are introduced and dealt away with so quickly that it is impossible to question how they are not one-dimensional plot device in themselves. Sure, there are 13 episodes, but these are light novels so while the responsibility does not lie entirely with the direction of the anime director, the original author has to be called out for having such a lazy format and unfocused structure to their narrative. I am tired of arcs centered around one character for two or three episodes and they are discarded with. It is immature to play with one’s toys and dismiss them once they are tired of them. By the time the final episode had ended, I was left with nothing to ponder about when it came to all these arcs that the author had presented. We are supposed to walk away with a message besides the overtly repeated scientific diatribes of Puberty Syndrome or the difficulties of growing up as a modern teenager.


If anything, the most interesting concept that Bunny Girl interweaves into its plot is the role that social media plays in modern society. Every single character interacts in some manner with the online digital space. Interestingly enough, Sakuta is the single character whose minimal interaction with social platforms allows him to be the harbinger in solving everyone’s problems. I wonder if there is a message there! Mai is an actress whose presence is exemplified throughout the media to a large degree, especially as a press conference in Episode 11 or 12 expands upon. Kaede is a result of the bullying and hostile behavior a teenager can confront in high school, becoming a reclusive and a victim of the vitriol young people can do to one another. Japan is most of all guilty in these charges. Social media has such an influence on people’s lives that it is fascinating to observe how being so connected has made it so lonely. Sakuta’s intelligent female friend whose name I don’t care enough to remember has an online personality very different to the one she expresses personally to Sakuta to the point that another “clone” version of her is created to emphasize on the disparity of their behavior and the self-perception of that individual. Mai becomes invisible to the world even though she is regularly shown on advertisements and television. SOCIAL MEDIA IS A BIG DEAL IN THE MODERN AGE IS A THEME HERE.


But instead let’s focus on Sakuta’s remarks on whether or not you’re on your period half the time instead of properly pacing the show to confront these thematic ideas of great intricacy. 


I prefer to speak about what the show is about and teases than what it actually has to say.


This review was taken from my original blog post posted here: https://www.fictionalfreak.com/anime/2018/12/26/i-dont-really-take-bunny-girl-senpai-seriously


Fictional Freak is a new blog of mine where I talk about anime and gaming, later when I feel more comfortable literature. I want to use it as a platform to talk about art in a more meaningful way than most people do, in the format and depth of something in the vein of what the youtubers MatthewMatosis or Joseph Anderson do regularly but in text form with posts being more frequent depending on the degree of depth. Additionally, I want to use it to improve my writing over time.

This anime was so close to a perfect score. It's such a strong anime, especially given the number of genres it's able to pull off well.
Let's start with why this anime didn't get a perfect score. The story was very segmented. In some cases, that type of style can work, but I think the story ended up a bit too choppy. It was book-ended by an important beginning plot and an important ending plot, but the things in the middle were just side stories, if that makes sense. Kind of how cult classic shows will have a monster-of-the-week styles where every episode is a completelydifferent story without much continuing plot. 


That being said, every element of this anime was fun to watch, regardless of the choppiness. The humor is so well done and unique thanks to the main character that's leading the story. Sakuta getting to play off of Mai's humor was great as well since they're very similar characters. They've both made it onto my favorite characters list, in fact. 


Actually, the characters are the best part of this stellar anime. Talking about Sakuta again, he was written with A LOT of depth and a good history as well as a good potential for development. You get to see everything from his dry humor to his darkest breakdowns. There isn't a moment spared when it comes to Sakuta's development as a main character. Also, as an aside, I enjoyed the fact that Sakuta wasn't your typical protagonist when it came to the mystery-solving element of this anime. He picked up on things quickly so he wasn't the stereotypical clueless character that you see often with these types of anime. 


Everything else was great about this anime. The opening was awesome, the art was slightly different (and dare I say, better) from your standard anime, and the enjoyment factor was sky high. 


100% would recommend this anime to... anyone. The quality is there, the characters are there, the plot is there, the humor is there, the drama is there, the romance is there. It's all amazingly done. Nothing was sacrificed to make room for anything else, and that's why this anime is so good. Watch it, watch it, watch it.

Honestly, when I first saw this anime, I wanted to watch it because it had romance and the female protagonist was kawaii as fuck, so I could imagine how good it would be to have such a cute girlfriend in real life. Shigashi, I didn't know whether it was a good show.
 It could either be: 
1. A boring ass, fake show with dumb male main character and slut-like harem. 
2. A decent anime. 
However, it turned out to not be any of the options above. This anime is extraordinary. As I predicted, the female protagonist is a waifu for sure - my best waifu.\n\n
The story is amazing and the male main character is intelligent. \n
However, I must say that some scenes made me pissed off as fuck, but it did it on purpose, so I will let it pass. \n\n
In case you don't know, what made me pissed off was a dumb female character who trapped the MC.

What can I say, another anime with a unique premise that jumps happily and quickly on the harem band-wagon...enough said... Seriously, once you get past the gimmick, their isn't much else here. 
The anime has strongly written dialogue but that strength is used poorly, covering up the major holes of lack-luster plot, uninteresting or poorly utilized characters and themes which rely sourly on the interesting concepts.
Honestly, if you want something similar, I recommend something like Hyouka, sure the dialogue isn't well written but the story and characters are much more engaging. Another, to a lesser extent, Kokoro Connect, good premise(s), engaging characters in a somewhatclear and comprehensive plot.

Do you like deep stories with dark humor? 
Do you like a little bit of verbal ecchi here and there definitely not disgusting or raw?You have come to the right place, IMO its a bit of Bakamonogatari, Oregairu and Haruhi suzumiya....so going straight to it  i'm going to tell you why i absolutely love this anime. it should be a 10/10 but no 10 is reserved only for me hehehe
Story 9/10
Forget that misleading bunny girl outfit on the anime cover you saw its all bullocks, you are expecting ecchi but sorry to break it to you you're getting none, if that's why your hereplease take your leave now....yeah you heard me.

Half of the show is based off a romantic relationship between Mai and Sakuta. 


The other half is about a constant argument between these two and Sakuta trying to get a happy ending for everyone (girls, who cares about guys anyway anything for fan service, i mean my waifu are so fuc____sexy). He tried his hardest to help everyone, now the story of puberty syndrome flying around at first to me was stupid but the anime unravels rather beautifully then you find yourself loving the stories, cos it's definitely not centered on Mai but more on Sakuta.



Art 7/10


Definitely not near perfect, but decent of course it could have been better but nothing much to say here



Sound 7/10


Personally the OP theme was meh, the ending theme was better, through out the series the soundtrack was decent. nothing much to say here either.



Character 9/10


The person that made this anime beautiful to watch is Sakuta, doesn't care what people think about him, isn't afraid to embarrass himself in public, can go to any length helping a friend even if it puts his reputation on the line somewhat like the protagonist in Oregairu.

Mai, koga, futaba and kaede all fall in place with their character development it begins to feel like you've know them for a while but you find out so much has been done in just 6 episodes. also thhe chemistry between Mai and Sakuta is hilarious but sincere. Beautiful development yeah i said it.



Enjoyment 9/10


I loved this!! I love this!! I loved this!!

Do you need me to say it again. the pacing was well done, you begin to connect with these character and the best thing about this is that you can relate with some of these characters, even though the puberty syndrome issue is a fantasy the stories behind them happens in reality and that's why i absolutely loved it.



Overall 9/10


Need i say more, just watch! You wont regret it.

--------THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS--------
Story (3/10):
So far, the story divided into two individual stories. The first one is about Mai Sakurajima, one of the main characters, and the second about Tomoe Koga.
Each one of those girls suffers from an abnormal problem (Puberty syndrome) that Sakuta Azusagawa, another main character (though he should be the only main), help to solve.
episodes 1-3, The bunny girl:
The bunny girl, Mai Sakurajima, became invisible because of the "Puberty syndrome". Sakuta, as the only person who can see her, trying to help her and on the way found that her problem is similar to the idea of "Schrodinger's cat" experiment. The storyitself sounds interesting, but in general, it doesn't make sense.

For example, how they connected "Schrodinger's cat" to the story? As long as you don't open the box, there's 50/50 chance of the cat being alive or dead, so as long as the box is closed, the cat is dead and alive at the same time. Well, how Mai Sakurajima's case connected to this? As long as she doesn't act/model, there's 50/50 chance that it never happened? When you put a cat inside a box, you know about its existence, you just question the result. When Mai Sakurajima became famous many people knew about her existence, including her mother, and that it, there's no expectation for a result, it's not questionable. 

So what's the connection? Why the people have to completely delete her from existence? If they forgot about the existence of her career, then she became a regular, random, person you meet on the street and not a ghost.

And how her mother connected to it? Even if everyone forgot about her career, how her mother forgot about someone she gave birth to? Mai needs to sew her umbilical cord back to her mother, to prove it actually happened and she actually exists? What?


Then, after Sakuta, with the help of the school genius Rio Futaba, finds out about the problem and that if fall asleep he will forget Mai (What?), he makes a very "romantic" move by trying not to sleep. Mai, that for some reason understood what's all about, mixing his drink with sleeping pills, and Sakuta can't resist the pills and fall asleep. 

Then, Sakuta wakes up, he forgot about Mai. Sakuta looks at his hand, see Mai name, and he remembered about Mai... oh, wait, it's from "Your name", but it's pretty much what happens there. Anyway, our character ran out and for some reason screamed that he loves her, how it's event connected? 


episodes 4-5, Tomoe Koga:


And again, there's a problem that caused by the puberty syndrome, and the series keep throwing scientific theories without a connection to the problem our poor girls suffer from.


Tomoe, a 1st-year student, experiencing the same day again and again, as she never satisfied with the result. Sakuta, who get effected from Tomoe's time-jumps, deciding to help her as she reminds him about his incel sister, and somehow with the help of Rio, they determined that Tome's puberty syndrome has something to do with "Laplace's demon" - It doesn't -  There's no connecting between "Laplace's demon" and her time-travel.

So Sakuta tells Tomoe a couple of good words, hit a guy, and that's it - happy end.


Art (7/10):


It's a pretty good animation. That's it.


Sound (6/10):


The ending song is nice. Other than that, nothing remarkable.


Characters (3/10):


So far, and I don't see how you can get out of this, the characters lack developing. Yes, it's a pretty short anime, but it's not an excuse. The characters can't make such decisions only after 2 episodes. Where the love came from? I'm supposed to be sad without giving any reason to care for the characters? 


Enjoyment (5/10):


So far, it's not the worst Anime out there, and the jokes, aren't too bad. 

It's definitely something to watch between Anime's, if you're bored, or just want to expand your watch-list.


Overall (5/10):


So far, it's a pretty bad Anime from the story perspective and character developing. The character developing problem appeared mostly because of the lack of episodes, but the story itself is bad from the beginning.

To be honest, after watching "Your name" and "Owarimonogatari", it feels like this Anime tried to copy some of their aspects, it didn't go very well in my opinion.



Obviously, there are more episodes to watch, but there's no hope left in me.

"Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai"
What was on your mind the first time your read the title? You expect to see a senpai with bunny girl outfit all the time? no, it's not.
Don't even think about "meh, based on the title, I bet this show will have a lot of fan services".
The title is only applied to the first arc- first episode to be exact. After this you won't get another chance to see Mai-senpai in her bunny girl outfit (actually there is, but only for a split second but I won't spoil on what moment).
Story:
If I have to describe this show, I'dsay that "Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai" is a combination of Oregairu, Bakemonogatari and Suzumiya Haruhi (based on these 7 episodes) and actually I can add 1 more title/reference because I already got spoiled from my facebook timeline, but I rather not.


When I say this show have a resemblance of Oregairu, it's the MC and Heroine, but don't worry, this show doesn't have slowwww pace like Oregairu and of course the MC and Heroine are even better than that from Oregairu. (Oregairu fans please don't be mad at me)

I'd say the MC & Heroine on this show is an upgrade version of Oregairu's.

Nuff said.


How about Bakemonogatari reference? This show also have odd cases (it's called Adolescence Syndrome in this show) and need a proper way to solve them.


And as for Suzumiya Haruhi's reference, remember the "Endless Eight"? This show also have it, but only took 1 episode.


Enjoyment & Character:

How about my experience after these 7 episodes?

Usually, when you see Comedy, Romance, School, Supernatural genre, you'll met a cliche show, a tsundere heroine, dense MC or even a show that have no real story.


But how about "Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai"?

Well, I still can't believe myself after 7 episodes I still don't have a single complain.

Why? because this show:

- Have no unnecessary drama

- Have no dense MC & Heroine like any other generic SoL/RomCom

- The pace is well maintained and not rushed

- The character development is noticeable, especially between the MC and Heroine


I dare to say it's the best show for this season


Sounds:

I liked the OP and ED, especially the ED, it have a dedicated for its arc.


Art:

It's all good, similar to Oregairu season 2.


Overall:

10/10 for me as for now


Yes I gave it 10/10 because I generaly love SoL genre and this show did exceeeeeed my expectation.


Watch this show and you won't regret it.

The biggest surprise of this season...
Art/Sound:
The art style is appealing and fits the genre of the anime; giving me Oregairu vibes! The sound in general is great, the voice acting is some of the best you can get with a fun OP and ED.
Plot/Characters:
Plotwise, there isn't much but what we have is executed well enough where I can overlook the simplistic story. However, the characters are fucking phenomenal, they carry this anime throughout and resemble the Monogatari series' dialogue-heavy style that always keeps the viewer engaged.
Overall:
Every category for an interesting and enjoyable anime is ticked off and eventhough the plot is mediocre or decent atbest, this flaw is overlooked by outstanding and memorable characters that make this anime so good!

SPOILERS AHEAD, IF YOU HAVE NOT YET WATCHED THIS SHOW THEN I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU DO BEFORE READING. -
-
Holy cow, that was a show. Where do I even begin with this? Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai (shortened down to Bunny Girl senpai) is, in my opinion, a contender for anime of the year in 2018. A year where we've had incredible anime such as: A Place Further than the Universe; My Hero Academia Season 3; and Yuru Camp (just to name a few). The sheer essence of this show brings hope to my heart for the future of anime and writing. Thisshow is a gift we don't deserve. Everything about this was impeccable, the OST was atmospheric and really added a great tone to every scene; the visuals were beautiful and a charm to look at; the voice acting was spot on and every character felt like a real person; and the writing was simply incredibly, with some intensely emotional scenes. I loved the creative ideas executed in this show, they really captured the themes and topics they were tackling in a beautiful, yet, moving way. I can only dream that we get another show like this one. I'm also incredibly exited for the upcoming movie which will be showing in Japan in the early summer of 2019. I'd like to conclude this by thanking the writer of Bunny girl senpai (『Hajime Kamoshida』鴨志田一) and the studio CloverWorks for their hard work and for giving life to this dream of a series which many anime in the future should learn from.

(Pardon my poor english throughout the entirety of this review and I might have excluded some aspects.)
Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai or "A rascal does not dream of a bunny girl senpai" as its relative name, had a massive wave of hype back when its release date was announced up till the first episode to only be met by massive disappointment by the masses. "It did not live up to expectations" is what I'd initially felt upon watching the first episode, but that was but a stepping stone in efforts to reveal a bigger picture.
(The rest of the reviewcontains spoilers for the entire anime.)


Watching the first episode baffled the majority/ (if not) the entire audience. From the outer shell it does make it seem like some classic run off the mill romance, high school comedy anime, classic anime tropes etc etc. Your "typical anime waifu" being portrayed as one of the main characters became all too convenient to be called a cliché. This was all but a distraction from the main point of the series.


"the adolescence syndrome" given as a name to describe the supernatural events that has been recurring to Sakuta Azusagawa and crew. Each girl that Sakuta encounters during his journey attempting to cure each one from the syndrome had their own individual problems regarding the matter and I will go through each one to explain the deeper message that the director was trying to convey.


(Tomoe Koga):


Tomoe is your typical anime loli character that the storyboard writers put to cross off from the "high school romance anime plot" checklist. But to counteract the negative side of what the character brings to the story, there has to be a balance, thus her problem was brought forward. 


To put it simply, she has feelings towards the main character Sakuta and is unable to suppress that feeling on her own. She attempted so by pretending to be his girlfriend, but that had quite the opposite effect, the same day has been set to loop since she could not confront her own feelings for Sakuta. That is when Sakuta gave Tomoe a chance to confess her true feelings after days of observation, this has undoubtedly, ended the never ending cycle of Tomoe's torment and she was finally able to move on. 


This particular case addresses stowed feelings for another and holding back the regret of not confessing at ideal moments. The message here might appear empty in its value for now, but it will all be explained in the end.


(Rio Futaba): 


Futaba has stumbled into quite a troubling predicament whereas a doppelganger has phased into existence out of thin air. Confusing it may be, both of them similarly resemble yin and yang, a lighter and darker side to the same person to maintain balance. The original Futaba portrays her lighter side of herself whilst the doppelganger portray the latter. 


The background of the situation centralizes on her feelings for Kunimi, who already has a girlfriend. Futaba's inability to accept her own feelings for Kunimi has caused an anomaly, her doppelganger displays what she would do in order to attract and seduce Kunimi, even obscene acts she dared not perform: taking seductive pictures and posting on social media. Sakuta knew that to tackle the issue at hand, he has to bring the key component that Futaba has to confront. Sakuta calls over Kunimi to talk with Futaba so that she can come into terms with her own feelings. Surely enough, Kunimi rejects her, which puts Futaba at ease and thus the doppelganger disappears as a result of her efforts. 


The case here is similar to Tomoe's but it brings out what extents adolescents can go to in order to achieve their goal, even acts that the host itself restricts. (I have difficulty explaining but hope you can catch the point)


(Mai Sakurajima & Nodoka Toyohama):


Nodoka Toyohama, the younger sister of Mai Sakurajima attempts to follow her footsteps to fame. But how life was never that straightforward in the first place and has placed Nodoka lower than Mai's worth, where Nodoka currently is a growing pop idol whereas in comparison to her older sibling, Mai was a national celebrity. 


The supernatural phenomenon here plays by the idea of "stepping in another's shoes" and the issue at hand was the both of them switched bodies. And thus the daily ups and downs of the other's life begins, Mai easily handles Nodoka's pop idol routine whilst Nodoka struggles to keep up Mai's busy schedule and even screwing up in the process. 


It has been said by their parents that Mai was the better sibling of the two and she holds up true to the title she has been bestowed with, coping with both academic studies and her celebrity career, she excels at both fields without issues. But Nadoka was out of her league, she struggles in desperation with both studies and her own pop idol career/schedule in hopes that she will be on par with her older sister. 


The rest of the situation was still playing around the idea of being in the shoes of another. But all in all jealousy, pressure from comparison and the idea of stepping on the same stage as someone you admire was the key message behind it.


(Kaede Azusagawa):


Last but certainly not least, the sister of the main protagonist herself, Kaede azusagawa. Her case is really simple, social anxiety disorder intertwined with multiple personality disorder. Social anxiety is the difficulty in performing basic social interactions such as interacting with another person.


Kaede's social anxiety has been caused by trauma from being bullied throughout her middle school days. This has caused her to purposely lose all her memories, even to an extent that she forgot who she was. She lived out her days living with her brother while their parents moved to other places because their mother could not accept what she became. 


Throughout the whole anime, each girl that Sakuta encountered, Kaede has trouble making friends at first but it helped that every one of them was friendly towards her, this was the effects of social anxiety in ploy.


As Kaede attempts to break free from the shackles of social anxiety, she felt determined to break free, one step at a time. But to no avail, it was not as simple as what Kaede has wished for, but it can be done through sheer perseverance and willpower. Her efforts finally bear fruit and she was finally able to make it to her school grounds, but that is when things turn out unexpectedly for Sakuta. She has regained memories of her formal self, her self before she got bullied. However on the other hand, she has no memories of what happened after she lost her memories the first time round until the point where she regained it.


This was the transition from her other personality(having social anxiety) and her original self. (Frankly this scene was pretty tear jerking)


Conclusion:


All in all, the adolescence syndrome encompasses problems that children/teenagers face during their adolescent stages of their lives, where each scenario addresses some issues that they deal with during the process. The message was well conveyed and definitely not brought clear in the first few episodes, but I assure you the entire series is worth a watch so that the audience going through the same phase can relate to this well scripted anime.


Story: 10

Art: 10

Sound: 10

Character: 10

Enjoyment: 10

Overall: 10


Definitely recommended

It seems like most of the reviews for this anime are either "It's the best thing that happened to humanity" or "It's worse than Hitler". Now - I'm not on either of sides, but I cannot for the life of me understand WHY this anime has such a high score.
When I watch anime I want the story to be coherent. Now that doesn't mean the story has to be realistic, it doesn't have to be backed by scientific studies, it doesn't have to make sense in our world (I do like fantasy xd), but I expect the anime to at least know how to handleit's own story and world. And this anime doesn't.


Let's not beat around the bush: this anime has glaring similiarities to the Monogatari series. A sarcastic highschooler helping girls with their paranormal problems. And my opinion Seishun Buta Yarou is just a worse version of Monogatari. But how is it worse? Its problem lies in the way it handles it's own story, it' own world.


In Monogatari the paranormal phenomena our cast of characters experience are tied to yokai, ghosts, gods and japanese mythology in general. Does it make sense in our world and do they try to convince us it makes sense? No, it's mythology. In the anime's world it makes sense. In Bunny Girl Senpai on the other hand the phenomena are tied to quantum mechanics. Not only are the quantum mechanics very real, the anime uses real experiments, laws and theories to explain what's going on. Some of the explanations are illogical (ok the time loop might be the work of Laplace's Demon, but how in the fuck did the characters jump to that very roundabout conclusion), some of the experiments they cite don't make any sense (everyone around me was like "you have to watch this, they say things about the Schroedinger's Cat" and I watched it and I was very disappointed to notice how everyone failed to understand what that experiment was trying to convey), etc. It's painfully obvious the creator just read a "Quantum Mechanics for Dummies" kind of book and went with it.


Now - that doesn't mean it was a bad show. The animation is pretty, there isn't anything wrong with sound design, I even enjoyed the last story arc (mainly because of the lack of quantum mechanics xd), the characters and interactions between them aren't the worst (though in a lot of places they seem like dumbed down Monogatari)... At the end of the day 7 isn't a bad score. I could criticize it further for following generic anime tropes or whatever, but it's not like I didn't enjoy it, it just REALLY pissed me off in A LOT of places, so I don't want to give it a totally shitty review. But I don't understand how it has a 8.5 average, and I sure as hell don't understand how people can give it a 10.


Go watch (or better yet read) Monogatari instead. Xd


Tl;dr: If an anime uses real concepts to explain it's narrative I expect it to understand what it's saying and doing. This anime doesn't and it pisses me off. Other than that it's cool.


PS. I'm a Nisioisin fanboy. lol

I don't think the show does itself any favours by being named as it is, using the cover art that it did. It miss sells itself massively. I didn't pick up this show for months because i was under the impression it was yet another brainless service show, but that couldn't be further from the truth.
Whilst the show's worst trope offences comprise an apparent harem setup and a girl who could only be described as bordering on mentally ill since she talks about herself in third person and has a brother complex, this is executed as an actual genuine mental disorder that gets played outtowards the end of the show. Plus the harem isn't a real harem, he just happens to meet a lot of girls (all be it only too conveniently) who then become regular friends (though there is a second romance involved half way through).


The show plays out in many respects similar to the award winning anime movie title "Your Name", by Mikoto Shinkai. A seemingly supernatural phenomenon explained using scientific concepts like quantum physics causes strange happenstances which provide obstacles for the characters to overcome. The way the protagonist meets a childhood friend of his who academically proficient, particularly in scientific theory, reminds me of Steins;Gate somewhat in how they approach their strange problems.


The bunny suit itself plays a minor role in the over arching story, making only momentary appearances at the beginning and doesn't drive the story at all except to provide a quirky introduction. The characters are all written to be, as a story should, real believable people and not cookie cutter tropes designed for an easy ride. IE It has actually good writing that provides stimulus with its own merits rather than tried and true tropes that so often get abused these days. To summarise, the characters act and feel like how real people would react, nothing is too convenient.


I could analyse it further. but i think the most important points have been made. The story is an actual decent piece of writing with believable, relatable characters that go through real life emotions, if not in fantastical scenarios. The art is nothing short of great both in animation and background, the sound is acceptable and the overall enjoyment really just comes from the story telling.

At a glance, Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai may have you assume it is some sort of fan-service comedy title with its promotional art depicting series female lead Mai Sakuragawa in a bunny-girl outfit. However, the series falls more in line with titles like Bakemonogatari and My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU that offer snarky lead characters and exploring supernatural issues effecting its major characters. In the case of Bunny Girl Senpai, the series explores male lead Sakuta helping out several girls afflicted with paranormal problems related to everyday stresses experienced by teenagers, otherwise known as Adolescence Syndrome within the world of theseries.


Essentially, Bunny Girl Senpai is divided up into several story arcs that explore Sakuta helping out one of several teenage girls dealing with some sort of personal crisis that leads to a case of Adolescence Syndrome affecting them. Each arc devotes enough time to explore each character's individual personal problems and Sakuta doing what he can to figure out the source of them. This does make the series fall into a sort of storytelling formula as Sakuta will seek consulting from classmate Rio about the cause of a specific crisis and his classmates often wind up getting involved in the situation to some degree. But there is still enough fleshing out of each character's particular situation to make their dilemma relatable to audiences as Sakuta aids each girl in overcoming their personal crisis. The final arc of the series involving Sakuta's sister, Kaede, made for perhaps the more emotionally powerful arc of the series with the vulnerability that Sakuta shows in caring for and expressing concern for his sister's personal issues.


Outside of its main storytelling element, perhaps the more entertaining element to Bunny Girl Senpai is the chemistry between Sakuta and Mai. Some may draw parallels of their relationship being similar to Bakemonogatari's Araragi and Senjougohara, as both feature girls the male lead helped overcome a personal crisis, eventually start a relationship together, and the female lead snarking at her love interest at points throughout their shows. While I can see where these parallels would come into play with Sakuta also showing signs of having somewhat of a perverted streak he shows with his quotes in his attraction toward Mai, Sakuta has more of a snarky personality than Araragi and gets joy out of the snarky teasing that he and Mai give one another. In spite of this, both are shown to gradually develop a genuine relationship with one another and show varying degrees of concern for the problems both face throughout the series.


The only issue I really have with Bunny Girl Senpai is that there is a story element revealed later in the series concerning the addition of another character that doesn't get proper focus within the series. While related to the problems that Sakuta has while caring for Kaede, the character in question doesn't get properly explored and it looks like there will be a movie sequel released later in the year that will explore Sakuta's connection with her.


Setting this minor gripe aside, Bunny Girl Senpai still offered a great amount of psychological drama delving into the various supernatural afflictions effecting the girls that Sakuta interacts with. For anyone craving anime dramas like it, I'd strongly recommend checking it out at least once.

This show got really popular in the last fall season, it is appealing for a certain part of the comunity that really do like these type of series in which we can fantasize as to what is the root of the arcs presented in the story and it gives us the name of the cause of every problem that will be presented through each arc and it is: Puberty Syndrome. 
PS(puberty syndrome) is a distortion of reality in which the individual person sees himself in a situation that goes beyond what can really happen in real life, thus making it fantasy since the playground ofthe development of the syndrome is the head and mind of the characters and they create the problems unintentionally and go through them searching for a way to defy their limitations and make the way out of all the inconveniences possible. 


The story itself centers around a high school guy called Sakuta and his experiences with different kinds of representations of the puberty syndrome through his friends or acquaintances because every time a character has a realization of the syndrome Sakuta is right there for any number reasons going from helping them go through it or trying to find the solution to the problem. Mai sakurajima is a girl that can't be seen by people and seeing that begins using a Bunny girl outfit in order to know if someone can see her, Sakuta is able to see her and that way begins their relationship because being him the only person that can see her makes Mai see him as her only reliable and confident person. The relationship between Mai and Sakuta is well developed in the first arc of the story reaching it's climax in the finale of the arc, after that they behave more like a couple even if they aren't able to be always together because of responsabilities(work mainly) but they still are capable of having valuable time together. 


The rest of the characters isn't lackluster either since they have their own problems and realizations of the syndrome. Kaede is Sakuta's sister and a panda loving girl that cares for her brother and had a turnaround because of some events that happened in her school, Futaba is a girl that goes to the same school as sakuta and always gives him explanations supossedly based in analyticis with nonexistent proof, Nodoka is the younger sister of Mai and see her as an example eventhough she despise her because she always saw her as better than erself, Koga is a girl that wants to change the outcome of a certain event that happens in her school and Makinohara Shouko is the first person sakuta had romantic feelings for and seems to always appear in his moments of utmost needs. 


The music of the show is passable, it isn't good but it functions for the kind of show that this is. The opening is a good song and the ending along with the ending sequence can be entertaining for a couple of times but it isn't anything worth of praise.


The show had some flaws that kept it from perfection but those didn't really affected the final product all that much, some of these flaws are the lackluster reasons behind the puberty syndrome realizations, the lack of interaction between supporting characters and the nonsensical analytical explanations that Futaba gives everytime Puberty syndrome is mentioned, at the end this anime was a pretty good show with it's own message and did it really well.

I wasn't planning on watching this, well, ever. But then after it finished airing I saw a lot of buzz about it so I started in on a whim and then spent a day watching it instead of studying. Totally worth it.
Story 10/10: I guess its overall plot is just the main character helping different people suffering from this fictional Puberty Syndrome. The entire concept of this can be off-putting but honestly, there was enough explanation and pseudo-science for it to sound logical within the context of the anime, so I had no problem with the premise. This Syndrome manifests itself very differently in thecase of different people, due to which the anime is able to masterfully tackle some very mature themes, that you wouldn't expect to see in such an anime. It's generally a pretty smart show, and it has its fair share of plot twists, so I cannot complain about the story element.


Art 10/10: The art was one of the reasons I actually decided to watch this, I was drawn to the character designs from still images alone, and then seeing it all in motion just made it better. It always looks very smooth and shiny, and the backgrounds are breathtaking at times, so it's definitely a pleasure to watch.


Sound 10/10: I would dock off half a point at least because I absolutely hate the opening theme, but I cannot give this section less than 10 due to how much I adore the ending theme, and the incredible voice acting that made me wonder how such talented people exist. As for the ost, I didn't really pay attention to it, but it never stood out as being bad, so it's probably great.


Character 10/10: This is definitely a character-driven show, as there is less emphasis on the plot itself, as opposed to the characters' thoughts and feelings and reactions. Basically the entire point of this show is the characters. And it somehow manages to introduce quite a few characters, while also giving each of them a different personality and story and enough screen-time for the audience to grow to love them. But my most favorite thing about the characters in this show is just how human they feel. None of them are annoying, none of them are terribly childish or oblivious to the world around them; because there is such an emphasis on the characters' emotions, it makes them feel very mature and relatable. The relationships between the characters were also incredibly well-done, the protagonist behaved differently with different people, which is why I never got the feeling of a harem from it. And the romance. Oh god the romance. I have no words to describe it. I'll just settle for saying that it might take over Toradora! as my favorite romcom.


Enjoyment 10/10: I was drawn in within the first few minutes, and I just couldn't stop watching until I finished. There wasn't a single moment when it felt boring or slow, even though there is a lot of dialogue, and I also somehow grew attached to all of the characters, even though I tend to struggle when new characters are introduced at a fast rate. I'm really glad I didn't watch it as it was airing though, because it's probably better to binge-watch it.


Overall 10/10: Now, this is definitely not for everyone, as, like I said, it is very slow and character focused, but everyone who likes such shows should watch it, especially if you like well-developed, mature characters. Now I just have to wait for the second season, while praying that, if it ever happens, it'll be at least half as good as this.

I heard some pretty good things about this anime before watching, so i figured that I'd watch it sometime. Once I finally did, I was left a bit... meh. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai (Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai) is an overall good show, but not without some things that made it meh.
Story: 8
Probably like many others, this seemed to be another harem kind of show. Luckily, it isn't. Instead, it is an anime that tackles the struggles of adolescence. The idea of having a "puberty syndrome" to display the problems is nice. It is relatableto growing adolescence and adults who were adolescents themselves. The only part that was displeasing is the ending. The show ends with a resolution from a great problem, a very weird problem that occurs and will occur in this one episode, and a drawn out resolution to said weird problem. It made the series end pretty meh. It really wasn't a great ending personally. The Story Grade gets an 8 for the rest of the anime. Ending knocks it down 2 pegs as well as a problem that is in the Character Grade.


Art: 7

It's pretty. It's nice. Nothing really pops out though. It isn't very big or flashy, which is fine. It's a 7 because it is good, it isn't terrible, but it doesn't really stand out.


Sound: 7

Sound is just like the Art Grade. It is good, it isn't terrible, but it doesn't really stand out. Personally, the OP is not that big of a banger. It's meh. It doesn't really make me feel more in any kind of way. It's just there. It doesn't ruin the experience, though. On the bright side, voice acting is pretty good though.


Character 8:

Each character has something special to them. Aside from the "puberty syndrome," this show isn't a flat piece of garbage. Each character had a good bit of dialogue here and there. There is still a lingering problem though: the supporting cast gets some development, and then nothing. Plus, three characters (that I won't give names to) don't really change at all. It's problems like this that leaves a bit of a meh taste. I wish that they were still part of the big story. But because they are side characters, it doesn't show it. This problem occurs in many other anime. But still, the arcs each character gets is great, but what happens to them afterwards just feels disappointing.


Enjoyment: 8

The show is a fun time. With an okay OP to get you excited, each arc is always interesting with its new puberty syndrome kind of problem. There isn't a major problem that occurred while watching the show. It is just what happens after. The silly witty dialogue is great and will give some a bit of a chuckle. It's pleasant and very enjoyable.


Conclusion:

"Bunny Girl Senpai" is an overall good show. With its great character arcs and interesting topic of adolescent problems expressed through its "puberty syndrome," this show is solid. I recommend you watch it for yourself for an overall fun time.


Overall: 8/10

I don't get the value that some people on here place on comparing Bunny Girl Sempai to other animes that it supposedly "stole" from. So what? Ignore that. Did the anime make you happy? It did make me happy. I thought that everything about this show was wonderful, except that it ended after only 13 episodes. If indeed there are other shows out there that were stolen from to make Bunny Girl Senpai, well that is awesome to hear. It will be other chances to be happy once more. If you love romance, if you love... love... be it romantic or family, then Seishun ButaYarou we Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is totally worth your time. What in this world is original? Not much... all that matters to me is that at the end of it, I am happy. Stop tearing down this show for what it lacks and cheer it for what it has... this show has a lot.

This anime is getting a lot of love, and for good reason. It's kind of a twilight zone for teen drama. In this anime, a rather socially apathetic protagonist (Sakuta) helps five girls deal with some difficult buried emotions that thanks to a phenomenon called puberty syndrome, manifest themselves in extreme supernatural ways.  For example, a girl is being bullied online, and all the sudden cuts just start magically appearing on her body. 
Let's get the problems with the anime out of the way. The attempt to explain why these incidents are happening is so horrid, it would have been way better not toeven trying explaining it. The fact that only girls seem to need the protagonist's help is rather groan worthy only saved by the fact that only two of them have any romantic interest in the Sakuta, and Sakuta himself is insanely loyal to his hard earned girlfriend. 


So, to appreciate this show, I think it's important to understand this statement. This show is not really about Sakuta, it's about the five girls. Any and all plot in this anime is centered around a girl, not Sakuta. Sakuta ceratainly helps every girl get through the issues they are dealing with, but ultimately, the girls all have to deal with their issues. (except maybe Mai) These girls save themselves. Each journey is a worthwhile one. 


The advantage of the puberty syndrome gimmick is it's extreme nature makes characterization a breeze. Each girl gets basically three episodes, yet in such a short time, you get a satisfying full story arc, and the character feels fleshed out. 


A fun aspect is Sakuta's aloof personality bouncing off everyone he encounters. In particular, every conversation with Mai is pure gold. Those two together is always a joy to watch. In fact all the character chemistry is really good throughout the show.  Everything feels natural despite the crazy things going on around them. 


So, in the end I have to admit I really enjoyed this anime. If you go into knowing you're not really get one big story for Sakuta, but five completely contained tales about the girls themselves, I think you'll enjoy it a lot more. Its not perfect, but a strong recommendation from me.

This is not a very controversial opinion, but I think that this show has been fantastic so far.
Not because it's something that I have never seen before or because it made me cry. Simply because it created a beautiful and warm story that I enjoy thoroughly.
From what I've noticed from other people's reviews the biggest complaint is that the writing is the same as they have seen in countless other live novels. Of course I can't say for sure, but that might be a problem with the perspective they have on it. I think it's one of Rascals biggest strengths that it takes tropes thatwe are familiar with and kind of looks at it differently.


When I saw an Idol in the opening I couldn't help but sigh. No matter how great the other characters are, I was sure that she was going to annoy me. What this show then did was to make her a very human character, with some annoying personality traits but also some good ones and I couldn't really dislike her. Which might just be me, but I tend to dislike characters that are a bit too much to handle. Must sound strange since I'm an anime fan, but a bit too much really has to be a lot. Like a character that keeps switching between being an asshole and an adorable girl every two seconds without any consequences (no offense Hanebado, but full offense). The concept of taking tropes and changing them up is a fairly simple one, but I still respect them a lot because they're not always easy to actually do. It has a simple premise and writes its story accordingly, but in a charming and well set up way.


Of course a show like that can only work when the characters work as well, which I explained worked very well for me. I am aware that opinions are split on this, with people hating and liking some characters or hating the entire cast. Personally I really like every character that has been presented so far. I mean this show made me like the perverted protagonist type and that's pretty amazing, cause god I've had it with these harem protagonists. But this one is calm, honest, but also a nice guy when it counts and, a thing that I probably like about every character in this show, he's honest with himself. He knows his personality isn't great, but also doesn't shove that in everyones face. Because there's a difference between being a bad person and quietly accepting that and walking around telling everyone what your opinion about them is. Which is most likely not a good one. Now to the bigger part of the cast, the girls. I love girls. I love boys. Would have loved more boys. But the girls in this are fantastic. Adorable, strong, weak, mysterious and charming. No I'm honestly impressed look at these girls with personalities this is a treat. Honestly I feel like I'd start spoiling things when I talk about them more so let's leave it at that, but they managed to make me absolutely fall in love with the big brother obsessed little sister character. A miracle.


I think that's all I wanted to say. Except please watch this show, it's good for your heart and soul. Especially if you're in a similar situation as the character, though I don't think you have to be to relate to them. Watching someone just not care about the opinions other students throw at him is nice, watching someone else care way too much is nice, watching someone like the way they change instead of their real self is nice, this show is just nice! It's pleasant and fun, so please give it a go.

Spoilers ahead, beware
Typically, an anime under the genres of romance and school tends to come and go. Admittedly, I've watched an extreme amount of romance anime, way more than any other genre that I've watched. However, the thing about school romance anime is that most of them just don't stand out. I'd say about 80% of the school romance anime that I've watched were nice while was watching, but then I completely forget about them after two weeks once they finish. That's exactly what I expected from Bunny Girl coming into it. Actually, to be honest, I thought I'd thoroughly dislike Bunny Girl, because itsounds like an anime that follows typical romantic anime tropes, and frankly I was getting sick of them.


I was wrong. 


Through out watching Bunny Girl, I was greeted with a perspective of widely different situations that might have happened during high school years. I witnessed the true love that grew on Sakuta as he eventually fell in love with Mai. i witnessed Mai's constant struggle of figuring out who she was and what she wanted to do, albeit briefly. I witnessed Futaba's struggle in realizing that she loves one of her best friends, and the acceptance she has when she realizes that they would stay best friends, and there was nothing wrong with that. I witnessed Toga's realization that she would never date the boy she likes because he was already in love with someone else, and the way she just put it aside for the sake of the boy instead of hanging on for the sake of her. I witnessed the struggle of Mai's little sister, as she realizes that she is constantly under the shadow of Mai, who was better in every way. However, she still loves Mai because Mai was her sister.  I witnessed the growth of Kaede, who only decided to grow only for the sake of her brother, who was the only one who seemed to understand. Then, Sakuta's devastation as he sees with his own eyes that Kaede's growth and struggle was all in vain. 


Bunny Girl showed to me that romance school anime could still be good, and that they could still blow my expectations away. It was a beauty that I had witnessed with my own two eyes, and I am proud of that.

The anime Bunny Girl Senpai may not be as absurd as it sounds, but it definitely deserves the watch.
I'll admit that what brought me to watch this anime was the initial hype it received, and watching the first few episodes i found it quite cheesy because for one, I'm a physics major so seeing all these quantum concepts thrown around definitely made me laugh at how cheesy the whole show was.
Let me tell you watching these physics concepts be used to describe the situations of the characters, well let me just say that I need to have a word with the person behind all thisto explain that superposition doesn't work that way and a whole lotta other stuff. But after i got over them butchering my favorite subject i really got to appreciate the anime


Story wise there isn't that much to say about it, I mean any person that watches anime can predict what will happen in the next 10 minutes. But what really got me was the attention to detail the authors gave to the story. Sure you can tell how its gonna turn out, but the way they executed it was top notch, enough to bring tears to my eyes. The way each character interacts with the MC felt so refreshing and real, in a way it deviates from the typical character tropes in anime. And not to mention the banter, it felt so realistic, something real friends would argue about. 


On top that, each character is dynamic and was well fleshed out. Props to the producer for managing each character correctly despite the 13 episode limit. Each character had enough screen time to properly engage with the audience and make them relate to the situation. Perhaps what I liked about the anime was that, even though the base premise of it revolved around the absurdity of the situations, at the core of those situations were all problems every adolescent can relate to. It explores these problems by exaggerating them, using hyperboles to better explain how the character feels towards each problem. It reaches out to the audience and gives them something to relate to. 


The sound and music of the anime was the icing on the cake. The upbeat tunes and sunny melodies give life to the show, while the soft piano and slow pangs make each problem all the more heart wrenching and each resolution all the more satisfying. It gives you a nice down-to-earth feeling of youth and overall makes each scene more vibrant and more immersive.


Its that type of anime that gives you a warm fuzzy feeling after you watch it, and well, I for one can't wait to go back to school and live out the rest of my youth.

Rascal does not dream of bunny girl senpai,  what can I say? The name alone for some reason seems really off putting as I try to recommend this soon to be anime classic to my peers.  I believe there is some kind of stigma going around where "sexy" workings in anime that aren't blatant fan service set off some kind of virtue alarm.   Well turn off the white knight fears of association and buckle up,  for this is an unexpectedly amazing anime.Bunny Girl, is a fantastic story.  It focuses around a seemingly typical protagonist until he gets introduced to a series of amazing characters. Yet the basic tropes of Anime are bypassed as its not so much the individual,  but their situation that matters.  I really like how this show presents the seemingly everyday then with excellent care and poise wraps it in some bizarre circumstance.   Many shows have attempted this same effect,  but very few get good marks, and almost none get it as perfect as bunny girl.  It made me laugh, it made me cry,  its a fantastic experience.


               While not the most amazing show visually to be released in fall 2018, it did put up a good fight.  Its a bit isolationist with  the scenarios having about 8 locations  revisited a little too often,  but the diversity of the story and lighting choices,  hide the repetitiveness well.  A job very well done,  but I do feel some expense was spared.


              "KIMI NO SEI KIMI NO SEI", haha.   From the opening theme song to the ending credits, your ears will be just as happy as your eyes.   This team put on a lot of consideration into their final effects,  and I have no complaints about their song and sound effect choices.  The voice acting was was very well done.  I not once tried to figure out who was whom as they were the character more so than the voice of.  It's truly wonderful to me when I get that sold on a performance. 


        This particular program makes it very hard to discuss characters without tapping into the realm of spoilers.  So I will just say I adored them all.   From the main character to the supporting roles around him and the random passerby in the world he lives in,  they really sell the this universe as being a complete product.    Very well written, so much it's difficult to even pick favorites out of the lot.



             At the end of the day I enjoyed waiting each week for bunny girl senpai,  never knowing if I was going to laugh or cry.   Grizzziff Kingsbeard gives this lovely program a slightly gratuitous 10/10.   I definitely recommend the experience.

Review No : 1
TL;DR : a mediocre story that stem from a good problem/topic with good characters and a sprinkle of supernatural phenomenon that spice up and help with the pacing of the anime.
Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai or rascal does not dream of a bunny girl senpai might put you off after looking at its cover art and synopsis. At the start of the season there are two kind of people, some like me, who upon first reading about it in the seasonal anime chart chooses to avoid it because of its fan service nature and others thattry to watch it expecting a very mediocre fan service anime. At the end of the season though only one type of people remain, those that realize that it is not a good fan service anime, in fact it is nowhere close of what one would consider a fan service anime. So if you who are reading this is trying to find an anime to watch, consider trying this anime because it is different than what you first will expect.



Upon finishing this anime I have come to realize that this anime might have one of the strongest opening episodes or the strongest opening arc. Usually most anime and some great anime have quite a weak opening episodes. But rascal does not dream of a bunny girl senpai have such a great opening episodes and pace it self very well at the start. This strong opening and pace is very rare in anime and it is one the plus of this anime, a great strong opening arc. 


After a great opening arc though, some of the subsequent arcs have the same problem, the main problem of this anime, and it is the pacing, despite the good pace in the beginning, the pace seem to crumble because the anime try to adapt and fit in too many arcs or too many light novel books into 13 episodes. Most of the negatives in this anime stem from the decision to cramp in too many arcs into 13 episodes.


Now after the main culprit has been revealed lets talk about the other aspect of this anime.


The story of the anime tackles on problem that adolescences usually faces, such as the inability to read the mood, unrequited love, different sides of one self, and many other one. At first, it might seem there is nothing special about it, and certainly some other anime have also done it, but nonetheless this types of topics work perfectly with the characters and the other aspect of this anime. The story can certainly makes you reflect upon yourselves or make you remember about your past.


The stories also incorporated supernatural aspect known as the adolescences syndrome, the supernatural syndrome stem from the adolescences  problems that the many characters faces and manifest itself physically. The syndrome at first might seem something to just spice up the problem but I believe that it is necessary because it heighten the stakes of the syndrome and fasten the pace of the story, without it there would probably only two or three arcs and the many arcs would not fit because the pacing would be really slow and would not fit into 13 episodes. 


There is also some quantum physic terms thrown around in the explanation of the syndrome that might seem to be completely bullshit, even though it is largely bullshit, it actually helps in understanding and visualizing the syndrome for our characters and the viewer.


Onto the problem of the story, problems arises within the story because of the many arcs in 13 episodes. Some arcs receive three episodes while other receive two episodes, for me  a three episodes arcs is a very fast paced arcs, considering the nature of the problem the characters faces which involve emotion, a very fast paced arcs would not work well with problems that involves emotions, the slow burn effect that are needed would not be present. That is why on some of the two and three episodes arcs I wasn't able to stay interested.  And despite how beautiful and deep it could have been, one arc in particular feels shallow. This of course could have been avoided if they had decided just to adapt three fourth of what this anime adapted, or even better make a 23 episodes adaption of all the arcs that they had adapted.


All in all, the story is a decent story, and the supernatural physical manifestation is necessary  to helps heighten the stake and fasten the story, but with all the pacing help that the supernatural provided it is still not enough because there is just too many story in a short amount  of time.


The characters in bunny girl senpai overall is a well written characters. The two main protagonist have an interesting interaction with each other that keep the viewer stay invested and engaged. Their witty dialog, banter and actions keep the viewer interest in them. This reason alone for me make this anime worth the watch. The characters  are also not shallow, they can be understanding when tackling a problem. Become compassionate and shows empathy for others. Have certain level of thrust and jealousy. Are not so pure and can be honestly blunt. Overall they are not a one dimensional characters.


Next is the side characters, keeping mind the length of this anime the side characters  have a good balance between all of them in terms of their screen time. The sides characters it self are not shallow and you can definitely see some character development within them selves, whether it is moving on, finding new friends, becoming true to your self, being more mature and many other thing, the characters certainly changed and develop over the course of the anime.


Next is the actual usage of the characters, what good is a great characters if it is not properly use, and this improper use of characters usually what differentiate a good anime and a great anime. I always dislike one aspect that happen to most anime, pushing a side a well develop character after their main purpose is done. 


Keeping mind this is a 13 episodes anime, and the many characters that it introduces. The use of the characters is decent because most characters are still there and does not disappear. 


A very particular use of character that I see and very much like in this anime is that every action always have some connections and meaning, whether it is to introduce characters, for comedic or for romantic purpose there is always a fresh way to use the characters. This is something commendable about the anime and i would say it is the pluses of the anime. Such example are butt kicking that might seem irrelevant and will completely be forgotten but actually become a comedic tools of some sort.  


That being said I still believe that it would have been a better usage of characters if there is not so many of them, the problem that stem from the decision of cramming too many arcs into a 13 episode anime, hamper the slow and steady development of a character in a show that involves emotions like this and also makes the viewer not able to stay invested on one character because another character is introduced to close to each other.


Now for the technical sides of the anime, the background sounds, the opening song, the ending song, and the art or the animation, it is decent and serviceable. Though the Japanese voice actor fits perfectly well with the characters. The voice of the characters helps build in the mood in the scenes. It also able to perfectly conveys the characters during romantic, comedic, sad, happy, or serious moments.


Overall this anime is very enjoyable especially during scenes between the two main protagonist, I wish the focus was more towards them because their interactions are some of the most enjoyable i have seen between two mains characters. I have always been a fan of spice and wolf because of the enjoyable interactions between the two main characters. The regret of having finished watching spice and wolf is of course the realization that no two main characters in other anime will have this much enjoyable interaction between the two of them. I have search long and hard to find an anime that have as enjoyable interactions as the main characters in spice and wolf and to be honest, I could not find one, rare case like the monogatari series do have an enjoyable interaction between the main protagonist, but because of the screen time issue, i would not put the interaction of the two main monogatari protagonist on the similar level of those in spice and wolf. 


Of course the long search is finally done because with the airing of bunny girl senpai, I am happy to say that another anime have finally reach the level of enjoyable interaction between the two main protagonist, something which spice and wolf have already achieved. I also believe that the standard of interaction, interesting and not shallow interaction, between the two main protagonist that bunny girl senpai and spice and wolf have shown us should be the standard in all anime, and I wish that every new anime can and will achieve this level of enjoyment.


So overall and enjoyment wise I have to rate this anime and 8/10, the enjoyment I feel when watching the two main characters of course plays a big factor in this rating. Also the adolescence problems are something that I can relate to. And seeing what bullshit explanation of quantum mechanics they will says for a particular syndrome are very interesting and funny. This anime is an example of the sums is greater than its parts, because if you were to take a parts this anime, and separate its many aspect it would certainly seem underwhelming on its own, together though its many aspect creates a very enjoyable anime and I certainly can not wait for the movie.

And so the review wars begin. Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai is one of the few anime I've finished in recent years, and it's for a good reason that I feel many MAL users and reviewers have missed. 
Spoilers. Duh.
On the surface, this show is a sort of mix of OreGairu and the Monogatari series, borrowing a number of aspects from both. Some seem to make these similarities out as a problem, which I find utterly ridiculous. All art is derivative, and Bunny Girl is nowhere near similar enough to another series to be considered a rip-off. 
Bunny Girlis a layered, and surprisingly nuanced experience, which is NOT to be taken at face value. Many of the complaints I've seen about the show claim that it doesn't make any sense, or that its "supernatural" elements aren't realistic enough. I think the most important thing to understand about Bunny Girl is that it doesn't take place in the real world, and it's not trying to be a complicated, believable work of science fiction. The supernatural elements don't need to make sense, as they aren't meant to. The majority of the show's plot elements are symbolic and combine to create a much more cohesive thematic work. I'd like to begin by speaking about the so-called supernatural plot, and the way Futaba is used in its context.


The afflictions that various characters suffer from are not real. They are rather visualizations of the characters' mental states and difficulties and are visible to the other characters because they are involved in their plights. No, Mai is not actually a goddamn invisible superhero. It's because of her exit from the modeling limelight, which has caused a sort of dissociation and resulted in her FEELING invisible to those around her. The show exaggerates this for dramatic effect because there isn't much of a story without it, but regardless, the idea is sound, and this extends to the other characters. There are some exceptions, of course, as it can be assumed that Kaede actually does suffer from a dissociative disorder of sorts, which isn't unexpected given her circumstances. The cuts all over her body, however, can absolutely be called symbolic, metaphorical, or whatever other pretentious label you want. The point is, the show's got depth. Not absolutely everything needs to be taken entirely at face value, as I've seen so many do on the reviews for this show. 


This brings me to Futaba, as I've seen many criticize her various musings about the potential causes of characters' afflictions. Just about everything she says is complete, unfettered bullshit, and it's 100% intentional. The suffering of the characters can't just be boiled down to random philosophical concepts. Hell, sometimes the things Futaba says are so absurd and unrelated she could be considered comic relief. The audience is not supposed to take her explanations as gospel. The intent is for the audience to see through her pseudo-scientific crap and understand the teenagers' problems for what they really are: real, modern, and human struggles that can't be pinned down by a 19th century thought experiment. 


I think the protagonist, Sakuta, is also worth mentioning, as though he is something of a trope, I believe he is executed pretty well. He is quite similar to characters like Hikigaya Hachiman or Araragi, but I don't really think there's much of a problem with it. He fits perfectly well into the story, and his unending self-sacrificial tendencies are expressed physically in a giant fucking wound on his chest, that bleeds when he can't help others. Additionally, he isn't just the white knight that many make him out to be, as he undergrows a great deal of growth and maturation throughout the show. I'll admit I was genuinely surprised that instead of trying to restore Kaede to her braindead self, he accepted that she needed to be her own person and left it alone. Additionally, the character of Makinohara is essentially the physical manifestation of Sakuta's maturity, changing in age and providing him goals and insight into himself and the world around him. She's there when he needs to grow, and disappears once he fully comes into his own. I suppose you could call her a Deus Ex Machina, but I think her sole existence as a metaphor justifies her inclusion.


For those of you that have trashed on the show, dropped it, or whatever else, I highly encourage you to give it another try keeping in mind some of the things I've said here. It's exceedingly rare that an anime with this amount of heart and nuance comes out, particularly in the Rom Com genre, and I really do believe it deserves a fair chance. And for those of you who haven't seen it, give it a watch. It's not perfect, but it has quickly become a personal favorite, and not only did I thoroughly enjoy it, but I genuinely took things away from it, and that's the absolute best effect a work of art can have.

Story : 10/10
The story is simple but it strikes me a lot. It approaches with delicacy and ingenuity the problems teens face, which it metaphorises by exposing them as a supernatural phenomena. This approach gives a less rough and oppressive side to the problems encountered, without necessarily denaturing or softening them.
Art : 8/10
Nothing very transcendent but it is very pleasant to watch. The chara-design is quite common but remains endearing, as are the sets and animation in general.
Sound: 8/10
Like the art direction, the soundtrack does not mark but does its job perfectly and is rather pretty, although discreet. I like the opening though!
Characters : 10/10
Theother highlight of the series: the characters are extremely endearing.

Of course, Sakuta and Mai shine for their atypical personality.

One would think that Mai is the typical tsundere as one sees everywhere in the animes, but that nay! If she has a strong tsundere character, she adapts it in her own way and it makes her a very endearing and relaxing character.

Sakuta, the MC, is brilliant in his attitude. He is detached and calm (without being cringe, edgy or boring) and above all, his remarks are delicious. He shows a certain humor that I have not found in any other anime, or even series or film elsewhere.

The other characters are not left out, and they all have a little something that makes them endearing. The anime managed to very well build them in just 13 episodes.


Overall appreciation : 9/10

I waited eagerly for each new episode, and it was worth it!

The themes I touched touched me, just like the characters and their story

My only regret may have been the last episode, which I find a bit too condensed. The anime would have won to have 14 episodes, even a little more in order to develop even more characters and their stories. Well, it may be just gluttony to want more: p



Total : 9/10

A fresh anime and pleasant to watch

Not necessarily to everyone's taste, and not to look at the very first degree on pain of seeing an anime harem with psychology and romance in it

There is not really any action, let alone fights, but what a pleasure to watch!

Certainly one of the hidden gem and discovery of the year 2018, I do not regret trying it.
