Rien de bien transcendant mais cela reste très agréable à regarder. Le chara-design est assez commun mais reste attachant, tout comme les décors et l'animation en général.


Son : 8/10

Tout comme la direction artistique, la bande-son ne marque pas mais fait parfaitement son travail et est plutôt jolie, bien que discrète. J'aime bien l'opening cependant !


Personnages : 10/10

L'autre point fort de la série : les personnages sont extrêmement attachants.

Bien sûr, Sakuta et Mai brillent de par leur personnalité atypique.

On pourrait penser que Mai est la tsundere typique telle qu'on en voit partout dans les animes, mais que nenni ! Si elle a un fort caractère tsundere, elle l'adapte à sa façon et ça fait d'elle un personnage très attachant et reposant.

Sakuta, le MC, est brillant de par son attitude. Il est détaché et calme (sans être cringe, edgy ou ennuyeux) et surtout, ses remarques sont délicieuses. Il fait preuve d'un certain humour que je n'ai retrouvé dans aucun autre anime, ou même série ou film d'ailleurs.

Les autres personnages ne sont pas en reste, et ils ont tous un petit quelque chose qui les rend attachants. L'anime a réussi à très bien les construire en seulement 13 épisodes.


Appréciation générale : 9/10

J'attendais chaque nouvel épisode avec impatience, et cela valait le coup !

Les thèmes abordés m'ont touché, tout comme les personnages et leur histoire

Mon seul regret aura peut être été le dernier épisode, que je trouve un peu trop condensé. L'anime aurait gagné à faire 14 épisodes, voire un peu plus histoire de développer encore plus les personnages et leurs histoires. Enfin, c'est peut être juste de la gourmandise que d'en vouloir plus :p



Total : 9/10

Un anime frais et agréable à regarder

Pas forcément au goût de tout le monde, et à ne pas regarder au tout premier degré sous peine de n'y voir qu'un anime harem avec de la psychologie et de la romance dedans

Il n'y a pas vraiment d'action, encore moins de combats, mais quel bonheur à regarder !

Certainement l'une des perle et découverte de l'année 2018, je ne regrette pas de m'y être essayé.

Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai or Bunny Girl Senpai in short is one of the most popular anime in this fall 2018 season. This anime is often compared to others like the Monogatari Series and Oregairu. Is it able to live up to the hype though and is it able to make a name for itself compared the anime it is compared to?
Story: 6/10
The story of Bunny Girl Senpai is relatively simple, several teenagers have the 'puberty syndrome', a syndrome where all kind of supernatural things can happen like switching bodies, becoming invisible or being stuck in a timeloop. The protagonist Sakuta Azusugawa helps different girls to face their respective problems regarding the puberty syndrome. The problems I have with this story are that it is not original and the puberty syndrome is never clearly explained. The premise of the story for example sounds very much like the premise of Bakemonogatari. The show also reminds me of Kokoro Connect with several supernatural events like body switching happening. The second problem I have with the story is that the puberty syndrome is not explained very well, just very vaguely with several concepts of the quantum mechanics. The connection between the several syndromes and quantum mechanics is not very well used though, as it seems like the writer seems to not fully understand the several quantum concepts used. This makes for a weak connection between the puberty syndrome and its respective quantum explanation. The rest of the story seems fine as it makes for an interesting premise (seen with shows like Bakemonogatari).


Art and animation: 7/10

The art and animation of this anime are pretty well done. The background characters are pretty well animated (which is not done often), although sometimes with CGI, making them look somewhat worse. CGI is also used for several moving objects like cars and trains making them look a bit worse, but not by much. The main characters are also pretty well animated. The overall art looks good as well, although it does seem a bit basic.


Sound: 7/10

The sound of the anime is pretty good. The several music themes used fit pretty well with their respective scenes (although the several themes did not really stand out to me) and the voice actors also did a pretty good job voicing the emotions of the characters. The opening theme was pretty good as well.  


Characters: 6/10

The main character, Sakuta Azusagawa, seems pretty interesting as he has the stereotypical attitude to help several girls with their problems, but has a sarcastic attitude as well, combined with being very straightforward about certain situations. Other characters seem somewhat less interesting, Mai Sakurajima is a child actress and the typical tsundere and Rio Futuba is pretty typical in being interested in science and quantum mechanics. Every character gets a bit of development throughout their respective arcs, although it is only glimpsed over in the rest of the anime.


Enjoyment: 6/10

My enjoyment in the first few episodes of the anime was very good, following a premise like other very good shows and making me pretty interested in the characters. However, after the first two of the five arcs my enjoyment decreased a lot being less interested in the current character's arc and the writing seeming less well done. I also began to compare it more to other shows which executed a similar very well like Monogatari and Kokoro Connect, which caused my enjoyment to drop more because I felt like those shows executed a similar idea way better.


Overall: 6/10 (6,4/10)

So did the show live up to the hype and was it able to make a name for itself compared to other shows following a similar story? Well I don't really think so, the story is weaker compared to shows like Monogatari and the characters do not really get developed throughout the anime. The animation and sound are pretty good though. It might make more of a name for itself in its sequel movie, but we will have to wait and see.

So this was a great series that I really enjoyed watching every Wednesday.  A very charming anime, it exceeded my expectations in almost every category.
Story: The story revolves around our main man Sakuta meeting and helping girls with a weird condition called Adolescence syndrome.  Unique to each of the girls, he does his best to help everyone who has it for him and his sister have gone through it as well.  It reminds me a lot of the Monogatari series which is one of my favorite anime series.
Art:  The art is good. Nothing too special, all the characters look good whichI think is important for a series.


Sound:  Sound was good!  The opening song and ending song were both really catchy.  The characters sounded good as well.  They had some real emotion in their voices so props to the voice actors.


Characters:  We have some really awesome characters in this series with the standout being our main Sakuta.  He is a funny dude who just doesn't give a shit what people think of him.  He is a nice guy to the people he cares about was definitely fun to watch every week.  Mai was awesome too.  She kinda was like Sakuta in a lot of ways.  She didn't give a shit about what people thought of her but was really nice to the people she cared about.  She was funny as well and also a really cute character who was fun to see get flustered by Sakuta.  All the other characters were fun to watch as well.  There was no one that I didn't enjoy.


Enjoyment, Overall:  Overall it was a really great series that I highly recommend to people who want a funny, supernatural slice of life anime with sweet romance:)

Rascal Does Not Dream of Bunny Girl Senpai (Bunny Girl) surprised me in a good way. I was expecting something fanservice focused on how the poster looks and the show's title. Thankfully it eschews from that genre altogether to produce one of the best and most heartfelt anime of the fall season. 
We open this story with the main lead, Sakuta Azusagawa waking up and coming by what to him is a confusing entry into his diary. From this point, I can only assume we are taken back to the beginning of those events. While he is reading a book in the library, he spotsa girl in a bunny suit walking around wholly unnoticed by everyone else around her; something that would be considered unusual due to the showy nature of the outfit. It's here we are introduced to the show's supernatural aspect.


In  Bunny Girl's world there exists an affliction known as adolescence syndrome (aka Chuunibyou). Although unlike how it has been typically portrayed in shows like Siaki K or Love, Chuinibyou and other Delusions it does not take the form of eccentric flips of character associated with it, the syndrome here is more of an amplifier for problems these adolescents are struggling with and makes it manifest in a physical way.  This could be in the form of cuts appearing randomly on a person's body, or no one being able to see a person. It all ties to insecurities or worries that the afflicted is dealing with.  A lot of these worries are things that many may have struggled with around that age or still might be affected by so they come off as very relatable.


 It's an understatement to say how good a chemistry the two main leads Sukuta and Mai share.  The banter between the two is entertaining and cute. Often there were times I found myself chuckling at the barbs the two traded amongst each other.  Heck, the first three episodes that center on them could have been it, and I would have been satisfied. 


I enjoyed Sakuta a lot mainly because of how unabashedly straightforward he is about his feelings, sexual attraction to Mai, or how he interacts with his fellow students.  For the most part, you can see he knows what the social norms are but willfully chooses to ignore them this makes him seem like someone to aspire to.  In addition,  he a very kind person he himself has suffered through the syndrome and therefore is empathetic towards those who are going through it. The show also does an excellent job of showing this through his actions rather than the usual anime tropes.



Mai is witty, cute, industrious there is just something magnetic about her that draws me into every scene she is in. Her initial conflict is dealt with very well, and once that is done her character develops more.  She is very driven and knows what she wants, and the way she handles herself is very admirable.



Many reviewers including myself when I started watching drew comparisons between this show and the Monogatari series which while still apt are not entirely warranted. These comparisons are made because after helping out Mia Sakuta goes on to help other girls who develop the syndrome, but Bunny Girl manages to carve out its own identity as it is able to differentiate itself in crucial ways. Namely that Bunny Girl uses the Adolescence syndrome to explore its characters worries or issues whereas the Monogatari series girls were portrayed as familiar archetypes which the show subverts and the aberrations were a way of exploring that. 


Animation wise I have nothing to say. It was about par for what I usually expect. Nothing fantastic stood out to me neither was there anything phenomenally bad.


Sound wise it pretty good again nothing that stood out to me though. 


I really liked Bunny Girl  and would wholeheartedly recommend giving it a watch

Spoilerless Review

SPOILER-FREE!
Summary: This show was greatly enjoyable, but lacked in a few areas, primarily the plot. Overall, give it a watch if you're a fan of the Romance/Slice of Life/Supernatural stuff.
The story was enjoyable. It is a very simple (and surprisingly enjoyable) premise, Sakuta (the male lead) finds himself in the middle of the troubles of those around him, and does what he can to help them. It never felt monotonous or boring to watch, and the resolution of each character's arc was satisfying. This being said, my biggest gripe about this show was the story. The scientific explanations of Puberty/Adolescence Syndrome from Futaba felt plainstupid to me. I felt like the real world's science should not have been stretched as it was in order to explain the mechanism of Puberty/Adolescence Syndrome, although it was better than having nothing at all. More importantly, I felt as though this anime could have benefited from a 24-episode season, in order to really flesh things out, plot wise and character-development wise. The pacing was still good for 13 episodes, nothing felt too rushed, but I personally enjoy when a story has the chance to fully develop.


The art was very good, consistently. Not once resorting to 3D/CG crowds or environments, it was plain to see that work and passion was put into making each episode. The character designs were very faithful to the source material, and never looked blatantly bad. 


The sound was above average, in my opinion. The voice acting was superb, especially for Sakurajima, Futaba, and Sakuta. Not to mention, this show had my favorite ending song of the Fall 2018 season, and the OST placed throughout the episodes added to the atmosphere of the show very well. However, I was not as impressed by the opening song.


In my opinion, character development suffered due to the episode count, but even so, each member of the cast can be relatable and lovable in their own way. This anime does a great job in developing these characters in the time frame it is given to work with, but if you're a fan of really digging deep into motives, backgrounds, behaviors, etc. of characters, then you really don't get much outside of Sakuta and Mai. 


As far as enjoyment goes, I haven't watched an anime that commanded my attention more than this one since Steins;Gate or 3-Gatsu no Lion. It had a great balance of likeable, relatable characters and an intriguing plot for each arc, causing me to binge several episodes without the urge to switch shows. I don't believe this will be the case with everybody, because the show can be a bit dialogue-heavy (hence why Steins;Gate and 3-Gatsu no Lion commanded my attention), but if you're a fan of that kind of thing, you may enjoy it also.


Overall, if this show had been longer and had the time it needed to go deeper into the minds/backstories of its characters, it may have been one of my favorite shows I'd seen. However, check this out if you like dialogue-heavy, character-driven shows, and be sure to check the movie out if you enjoy the show!

Bunnygirl is another light novel show with a very long irrelevant title. The only difference is that Bunnygirl attempts to be meaningful though ultimately fails to resonate. 
[If you've watched some of the show then skip this part]
The show follows Sakuta, a High School student who's been the victim of a mysterious paranormal illness known as "Puberty Syndrome." He get's past his affliction with the help of a mysterious girl. Later he meets Mai Sakurajima, a teen actress who's anxiety's of fading from the public eye cause her to gradually become invisible to most people. Sakuta helps cure Mai of her puberty syndrome and thetwo become a couple. The show basically is a puberty syndrome of the week sort of deal, where Sakuta helps anime girls get past their problems. 


Puberty syndrome is really the main gimmick of the series. It acts a metaphor for the characters problems and their personalities. This isn't necessarily a problem, nothing is wrong with having a gimmick or crux if you work well around it. Anyone watching this show will recognize the Monogatari influence, cause let's be honest these two shows have very similar formats.


However there is a clear difference between what Monogatari gets right and what this show gets wrong however. And that's characters, Monogatari had people populating it's story this show has set pieces. Let's look at Mai as she is the closest this show comes to having a well written character. She is hard working, kind, sarcastic, no-nonsense, and somewhat poor at communicating her emotions. That's it she has almost no flaws, and a very normal past despite an unhealthy relationship with her mom. Compare that to Monogatari's love interest, Senjougahara. Senjougahara, is abrasive, unsociable, sarcastic, but also very sweet and protecting. Senjougahara has legitimate trust issues due to almost being raped by a cult leader that her mom was a part of. Shes was afflicted for years with weightlessness and hid it until the protagonist Araragi find out and tries to help. Senjougahara violently refuses and tries to scare Araragi away but he still tries to help her. He eventually cures her and they begin dating shortly after and we get a similar format to Bunnygirl.


It's here and what comes after is were we can draw a line of quality between Bunnygirl and Monogatari. Even after they date and Senjo is cured, she doesn't magically become perfect. She is still cruel at times, harsh towards others, difficult to read, and very sarcastic. But the fact that Araragi went the extra mile for her, when for years she pushed people means she deeply cherishes him. She understands she is flawed but she works to be better for him, it also culminates in a hilarious jealousy towards other girls. I spent 8 or more sentences describing the complexity of this character, where I could barely describe Mai with one. 


Monogatari works because those characters have depth and are fun to watch, I could analyze every other girl Monogatari like I did Senjo. Bunnygirl fails because why would I care about the problems of such flat one dimensional characters.


"Okay but Monogatari was never really about the paranormal stuff it was always about the waifus where as Bunnygirl is about personal issues." So maybe you could argue Bunnygirl has different goals but it still fails in most departments. Bunnygirl is apparently about tackling deep issues like depression, social anxiety, isolation, and relationships. I'm someone who has experiences with these issues and has consumed A LOT of media that tackles them. And I have to say this show fails at conveying these problems with any sense of profundity or depth. If anything I would say It puts more BAD ideas forwards than good.


Remember how Senjo even after being cured didn't just become the perfect girlfriend, she continued to be flawed but worked on it. In this show, characters have identity defining crises and Mr. Perfect Sakuta comes along and poof their goes your problems. There are characters like Futaba who have severe, SEVERE issues that just get fixed over a small arc. This is an awful portrayal of something like depression, because it tells us that their is a simple fix to being happy. When in reality you have to live your whole life working hard to be a better and happier person like in Senjo's case. Another annoying thing is how Sakuta is seemingly able to provide help and support to every person he runs into. I'm reminded of a scene in Haruhi where Suzumiya tells a crushing story from her childhood to Kyon, and hes just dumbfounded he wants to comfort her but doesn't know how (link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_jZbeGjoeiU). You will never ever see a scene like this in Bunnygirl. Sakuta despite never having experienced what most of these girls go through just knows exactly what to say cause hes perfect I guess.


This show might come off meaningful if you've never experienced these feelings, or if you just have consumed shows that do it better or if you're 12. But ultimately there are shows that tackle these themes and issues with far greater depth, intrigue, understanding, and resonance. Everything this shows brings to the table is painfully mediocre and I am not one to accept mediocrity as I consider it a grave sin especially in this current era of sub par anime.

Ever just get the feeling of skipping an anime due to its alluring thumbnail where a girl dresses quite lewdly to be frank? Well, this should be one of those cases and it's a complete letdown for those whom were interested in what was bound to happen in anime thumbnails like these.. BUT, this anime is far from what you would perceive it as from just the thumbnail. Not only does it contrast your given thoughts, the anime itself, is great as well. The story seems to be eloquently narrated throughout, although i haven't checked the manga, so I can't give you a full coverageon that which might clash with skipping arcs etc etc.


The story sets around a boy called Sakuta, and in the first few episodes, the first build-up of the series start to enfold. the weird phenomenon is called "the adolescence syndrome",(although inexplicable in reality, but that's what makes anime great at given times) and who would have thought, it seems to occur around the main female protagonist called Sakurajima Mai and the only one who would be able to help her would be the MC. it might not appeal at first, but it's a really interesting implication to what could happen to one due to psychological distortions and . As the anime gets further into the story, the main narrative sort of remains with focusing around developing the adolescence syndrome rather than appealing to something new, although new concepts are applied with the syndrome e.g, Laplace's demon, Schrodinger's cat and so on. 


As for the art/Animation, I'd say that the animation is done quite well, although the eyes of Mai don't really seem to appeal to me, but that's subjective to one's own. Other than that, I can say confidently that there are no ostentatious flaws for the majority, if you're not really focusing TOO much on the details.


As for the Music and VA, I think that the songs are relatively "alright", although not necessarily appealing to me, but maybe to you. One other thing that people often leave out of their reviews is the voice acting, and in this anime it's quite spot on. The implications of emotions, the mood and tone perceived from the characters alone make this show way more intriguing.


Characters, where do I start. Overall, I do think that the characters have attained development to a high extend where every character, not just the main characters, but ALSO the "side" characters other than the childhood crush but there will be an anime movie of the series which will literally make the picture perfect and that'll probably the cherry on top of this series. I really do like their personalities to be quite bold. Sakuta's somewhat perverse responses to Mai's rather questionable questions, and the fact that she goes along with it makes Mai a less generic female character, and Sakuta a less bland male protagonist in a somewhat rom-com environment, and that's the things people would LIKE to see.


In terms of Enjoyment, I regarded this as the best anime of the season by a mile, and this will probably rank pretty high in my list as well. I thank you for reading my review and am hoping you might have a different/better outlook on the anime as you've looked through it.

As a filthy degenerate weeb here's my take on this show, but first a story:
I feel that every weeb eventually hits this stage in their weeaboo life.
The stage after the initial weeb honeymoon, where there were initially seemingly endless top tier anime to watch, where everything was once fresh, exciting and new. Now to fuel your consumption of chinese cartoons you begin to start watching season to season, and eventually there will come a time after doing this where you will start to lose that spark in being a fan - you will feel that you are running dry, that you have plucked many ifnot most of the golden nuggets that the industry has to offer.


You'll then start wonder if you're burnt out on anime, as by now you will come to have seen the same shit over and over again, the same recycled ideas that were done a couple times well in the beginning be cloned in every single anime season a million times (fucking isekai), you'll start to see every sort of anime stereotype and cliche be beat to death in an endless sea of uninspired, mediocre pieces of nothing more but consumption material. 


And you'll continue to do this, if you haven't given up and moved on already, all in hopes to find the few sparks of modern brilliance that made you fall in love with this publicly deplorable medium in the first place. 

You will start to wonder more and more if you should, like many others before you, grow up and move on from anime.


This anime, and discovering others like it, are to me the weeb equivalent of finding water whilst stranded in a desert.


I have yet to type a word about this anime so far, in the interests of not having another one of my reviews be deleted I guess we should begin. 


This highschool romcom/mystery anime can be summarised by familiar, but different. Whether it be story writing, characters, character interactions or plot progression, on the outset it is everything you have come to expect from modern teenage romance-driven anime, but the difference is here although you have the classic anime lineup and plot, it is presented in a clever, fresh and engaging way. 


Although this anime can still be very much considered typical weeb bait (its literally a bunny girl as its poster and a virtually all female cast outside the protagonist, wow I wonder if I've seen this premise before!), it treats its audience like mature adults instead of just the usual filthy trash weeaboos that we very much are, and it's amazing in doing so.


Despite the whole story premise being around supernatural elements, the character interactions and story play out in a more believable way than many in its genre, even when compared to the best, and I truly am enjoying being along for the ride in a way that I haven't felt for a long, long time.


Man I really did not intend to write this much initially.......god I wish I could change my username so that I can nerd out like this, and write really long, overly serious reviews that no one really cares about on being passionate over 2d grills without the threat of some jerk searching my name and finding all of it through google............ alas woe is me.

This is, in my opinion the best anime of this year. The characters are excellent, the story is engrossing, and overall if you are looking for a slightly off-beat anime, this is the one for you.
Firstly, each character has a deep backstory. In each ark, the MC explores the reasons behind the strange supernatural occurrences that happen to each character and tries to resolve them. The attention to detail is also very good. Like that scene where Mai gets a phone call while in Sakuta's house and Kaede suddenly starts getting uneasy, referencing her past with the puberty syndrome.
I didn't like the music so much,but the story and the characters make up for it. That is why I am giving it a 9.

What a surprise, this one. Being a cynical reviewer of shows that wear the same type of socks like Monogatari and Steins;Gate, I was fairly blown away by how much I truly enjoyed Bunny Girl.
This show really panders to what I enjoy in terms of characters and character development, to the point where I feel like I'm overindulging sometimes when watching this, like eating too much cake. The interactions between characters and their individual personalities are so sweet and completely enjoyable I can almost feel my teeth hurt and find myself smiling more often than not, each new face they introduce adding something completely differentto the formula to where it never feels bland or recycled.


That being said, the only half-gripe I have about this one is the central plot mechanic, being Puberty Syndrome (or Adolescence Syndrome, depending) goes generally unexplained up to this point in the show and likely will to the end, acting as more of an invisible springboard for amazing character interactions than a real visceral plot point, but honestly it's pretty easy to overlook as I imagine hedging all their bets on trying to erase this unknown ailment would throw a wrench into the generally fluffy mood of the show, the original light novel having been written by the same LN author that wrote the equally fluffy and wonderful Pet Girl of Sakurasou, much of the same delightful pastel style of story-writing appears in this title as well.


The art is pretty wonderful, coming from a studio that only very recently been tasked with work on serious projects like this and the re-up of Fairy Tail. Very clean and pleasing to they eyeballs.


Audio is great, nothing to note really.


Overall, this show is a refreshing pool of enjoyment this season and one you should absolutely be dipping your toes into. Give it a shot.


(A final note, when watching this show I'd make it a point to find really good subtitles. I wouldn't call any animated show 'advanced' but Bunny Girl has a decent amount of humor based around Japanese history and language among other things that might fall totally flat if the translation isn't very good.)

Don't let your initial impressions turn you off. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I'm enjoying this anime.
At first the bored-sounding, monotone character voices bothered me, but I've since changed my mind. I think it's brilliant. They bury earnest desires for fears of pain and social expulsion. They retreat into a shell of generalized apathy to cope with this; however, this in turn perpetuates the atmosphere.
The "atmosphere" is a clever way of describing the status quo.
When kids graduate from middle school and go into high school, they fantasize about how much they'll change and how much their lives will improve. When they do getinto high school, they feel a bit let down--I know I was. The question hangs in the air, "Is this it?" They go about their days, dissatisfied.\n\n
This show shines when the characters do fight against the atmosphere, when they detach from their detachment. For better or worse, their suppressed desires and  frustrations find release when they whisper quiet vulnerabilities and when they shout at the top of their lungs. \n\n
It makes me want to root for them.\n
And it makes me want to root for this show, hoping that you'll enjoy it as much as me.\n\n
I can't wait to see the rest of the season.
